div1.p: Γ?̔θοοί, μεγάθυμοι, μένεα πνείοντες, ὄπιθεν κομόωντες̓. The men of Euboea Il. 2.536, 541, 542, Il. 4.464.
A sea-nymph. Mother by Boucolion of Aesepus-2 and Pedasus-3 (twins) Il. 7.22.
T. Son of Eurydamas-1. With his brother Polyidus-1 s. Diomedes Il. 5.148.
̔δικαιότατοι ἀνθρώπων̓. An unknown race so described Il. 13.6.
T. S. Antilochus Il. 7.32.
A city on the s.e. of the Hellespont, a little below Sestus on the other side Il. 2.836.
Ἀβυδόθεν [-θεν], from A. Il. 4.500.
Ἀβυδόθι [-θι], at A. Il. 16.584.
(δῖος). A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.249.
(μεγάθυμος.) Father of Epeigeus Il. 16.571.
Adj. fr. Ἀγαμέμνων Il. 10.326, Il. 23.295, 525: Od. 3.264.
Patr. fr. next. Of Orestes-3 Od. 1.30.

(ἄναξ ἀνδρῶν, βασιλεύς, δὶος, εὐρὺ κρείων, κλυτός, κοσμήτωρ λαῶν, κρείων, κύδιστος, πελώριος, ποιμὴν λαῶν). Patr. Ἀτρεΐδης, Ἀτρεΐων. King of Mycenae and great suzerain of the Greeks. Son of Atreus, brother of Mencla¨s, husband of Clytaemnestra, and father by her of Orestes-3, Chrysothemis, Laodice-2 and Iphianassa. Dismisses Chryses with menaces Il. 1.26; in the assembly summoned by Achilles abuses Calchas Il. 1.106, addresses A. and proposes to send back Chryseis 131, addresses him again and threatens to take Briseis from him 173, addresses Nestor 286; has a ship prepared to carry back Chryseis Il. 1.308, bids the people cleanse themselves 313, sends his heralds to bring away Briseis 320; Zeus sends Oneirus to beguile him Il. 2.8, he summons the council of chiefs and relates his dream 53, the sceptre bequeathed to him by Thyestes 107, addresses the assembly and counsels a return home 110, assents to the opposite counsel of Nestor 370, summons the host to the fight 441; enumeration of his followers Il. 2.569; described on the walls by Helen to Priam Il. 3.172; prays to Zeus and performs the oath-sacrifice Il. 3.276; sends for Machaon to see the wounded Menelaus Il. 4.193; goes round and inspects the host and the chiefs Il. 4.223; slays Adrestus-3 taken by Menelaus Il. 7.63; accepts Hector's challenge, but does not get the lot Il. 6.162; refuses the proposals of the Trojan herald except as to the burning of the dead Il. 6.406; reproaches the Greeks retreating before Hector Il. 8.217; calls an assembly Il. 9.9, addresses it and again counsels a return home 17, reproved by Diomedes 32, in a gathering in his hut agrees, on the suggestion of Nestor, to placate Achilles 115, an embassy is dispatched accordingly 178, but returns unsuccessful 669; A. cannot sleep (1), goes to rouse Nestor and other chiefs 17; his ἀριστεία 15, is wounded by Coon 248, but continues to fight 255, retires 280; with the other wounded chiefs encounters Nestor Il. 14.27, advises the launching of the ships 65, reproved by Odysseus 83, accepts the reproof 104; his speech in the assembly on the renunciation by Achilles of his wrath Il. 19.78, his oath about Briseis 258; receives the prize for spear-throwing without a contest Il. 23.884; etc.: after the taking of Troy advised, opposing Menelaus, delay in returning home in order to placate Athene Od. 3.141, remained accordingly 155; his death at the hands of Aegisthus Od. 1.32, 298, Od. 3.194, 234, 250, 303, Od. 4.519, Od. 11.384, 409, Od. 13.383, Od. 24.96 (see also Orestes-3); in the Shades Od. 11.387, Od. 24.19; etc.
(ξανθή). Eldest daughter of Augeias and wife of Moulius-1. Skilled in drugs Il. 11.740.
(κρείων). Son of Ancaeus-1 and leader of the Arcadians Il. 2.609.
(ἄναξ.) Patr. Αὐγηϊάδης. Son of Augeias and father of Polyxeinus Il. 2.624.
T (δουρικλυτὁς, ἴφθιμος). Patr. Παιονίδης. Wounded and slain by Diomedes Il. 11.338, 368, 373.
A Nereid Il. 18.42.

div1.head: Ἀγέλαος-1
div1.p: T. Patr. Φραδμονίδης. S. Diomedes Il. 8.257.

div1.head: Ἀγέλαος-2
div1.p: G. S. Hector Il. 11.302.

div1.head: Ἀγέλαος-3
div1.p:
Ἀγέλεως, Od. 22.131, 247 (διοτρεφής). Patr. Δαμαστορίδης-2 A suitor. Counsels the
suitors to abstain from violence Od. 13.321, 339; in the fight advises communication with the people outside Od. 22.131, 136; Od. 22.212, 241, 247; s. Odysseus Od. 22.293, 327.

T (ἀμύμων τε κρατερός τε, ἀντίθεος, δῖος, μεγάθυμος). Patr. Ἀντηνορίδης. Son of Antenor and father of Echeclus-1 Slays Elephenor Il. 4.467; Il. 11.59, Il. 12.93, Il. 13.490, 598, Il. 14.425; slays Clonius Il. 15.340; Il. 16.535, Od. 3.474; stands up to Achilles Il. 21.545, 579, is snatched away by Apollo 595, 600.

div1.head: Ἀγκαῖος-1.
div1.p: Father of Agapenor Il. 2.609.

div1.head: Ἀγκαῖος-2
div1.p: (Πλευρώνιος). Nestor beat him at wrestling Il. 23.635.
Mother of Nireus by Charopos Il. 2.672.
Son of Portheus Il. 14.117.

div1.head: Ἀγχίαλος-1
div1.p: G (εἰδὼς χάρμης). With his brother Menesthes s. Hector Il. 5.609.

div1.head: Ἀγχίαλος-2
div1.p: (δαΐφρων). Father of Mentes-2 Od. 1.180, 418.

div1.head: Ἀγχίαλος-3.
div1.p: A Phaeacian Od. 8.112.

(ἀμύμων, ἄναξ ἀνδρῶν, μεγαλήτωρ). Son of Capys and father of Aeneas by Aphrodite; father also of Hippodameia-2 Il. 2.819, 820, Il. 5.247, 268, 313, 468, Il. 12.98, Il. 13.428, Il. 17.491, Od. 3.112, 208, 239, 240.

div1.head: Ἀγχισιάδης-1
div1.p: Patr. fr. prec. Of Aeneas Il. 17.754, Od. 3.160.

div1.head: Ἀγχισιάδης-2.
div1.p: Patr. of Echepolus-2 Il. 23.296.
T. Patr. Ἀσιάδης. App. son of Asius-2 Il. 12.140; wounds Antilochus and is killed by Meriones Il. 13.560, 759, 771.
Husband of Alcestis and father of Eumelus Il. 2.713, 714, Il. 23.289, 391, 532.
A plain at the mouth of the Grenicus Il. 2.828.
A handmaid of Helen at Sparta Od. 4.123.
Patr. fr. next. Of Aegialeia Il. 5.412.

div1.head: Ἄδρηστος-1
div1.p: King of Sicyon, and father of Aegialeia Il. 2.572; father also of the wife of Tydeus (Deipyle) Il. 14.121; his horse Arion Il. 23.347.

div1.head: Ἄδρηστος-2
div1.p: Son of Merops and with his brother Amphius-1 the leader of the men of Adresteia, etc. Il. 2.830; both s. Diomedes Il. 11.328.

div1.head: Ἄδρηστος-3
div1.p: T. Taken by Menelaus Il. 7.37, 45; s. Agamemnon Il. 7.63.

div1.head: Ἄδρηστος-4
div1.p: T. S. Patroclus Il. 16.694.
Patr. of Actor-1 Il. 2.513.
also Ἀθήνη-1Od. 6.80 (ἐϋκτίμενον πτολίεθρον, εὐρυάγυια, ίεραί, δῆμος Ἐρεχθῆος) Athens Il. 2.546, 549: Od. 3.278, 307, Od. 6.80, Od. 11.323.

div1.head: Ἀθηναίη-2
div1.p: , Ἀθήνη, also Παλλὰς Ἀθηναίη Il. 1.200, Il. 10.275, Il. 11.438, Il. 15.614: Od. 3.42, Od. 4.828, Od. 13.190, 252, 300, 371, Od. 16.298, Od. 24.547. And Π. Ἀθήνη Il. 1.400, Il. 4.78, Il. 5.510, Il. 18.217, Il. 21.290, etc. : Od. 1.125, Od. 3.222, Od. 8.7, Od. 15.1, Od. 24.520, etc. (Never Π. alone.) (ἀγελείη, (αἰγιόχοιο) Dio\s te/kos, )Alalkomenhi/+s, )Atrutw/nh, (θεὰ) glaukw=pis, di=a qea/wn, Dio\s e)kgegaui=a, e)rusi/ptolis, h)u)+komos, quga/thr Dio/s, kou/rh Dio\s (αιγιόχοιο), κυδίστη, λαοσσόος, ληῗτις, μεγάθυμος, πολύβουλος, πότνια, Τριτογένεια.) Daughter of Zeus (her mother not named). Sent by Hera checks the wrath of Achilles in the assembly Il. 1.194; sent by her to stop the flight of the Greeks Il. 2.156; sent by Zeus to induce the Trojans to break the truce Il. 4.78; inspires spirit into Diomedes Il. 5.1, 121, leads Ares from the fight Il. 5.35, arms herself 733, mounts the chariot of Diomedes 835, they put Ares to flight 855; the prayer to her of the aged Trojan women Il. 7.297; again arms herself Od. 8.384, Hera and she start for the field to aid the Greeks 392, they are stopped by Iris sent by Zeus 413; she checks Ares in his wrath at the death of Ascalaphus Il. 15.121; kindles fire from the head of Achilles Il. 18.203; introduces nectar and ambrosia into his body Il. 19.349; in the Battle of the Gods Ares attacks her Il. 21.391, she fells him with a stone 403, she knocks down Aphrodite 423; comes to the aid of Achilles against Hector Il. 22.214, in the likeness of Deiphobus beguiles Η. 226; in the chariotrace disables Eumelus Il. 23.391; etc. : in the likeness of Mentes appears to Telemachus Od. 1.102, urges him to go to Pylus and Sparta 284, accompanies him in the likeness of Mentor-2 Od. 2.399, her advice to him at Pylus Od. 3.14, her prayer to Poseidon 55, she returns to the ship 357; meets Odysseus and conducts him to the city of the Phaeacians Od. 6.18; marks Odysseus's throw of the δίσκος Od. 8.193; in the likeness of a youth appears to O. on his landing in Ithaca Od. 13.221, reveals herself 296, they consult 372, she transforms him into a beggar 429; she departs for Sparta Od. 13.439, where she urges Telemachus to go home and warns him of the ambush of the suitors Od. 15.10; she appears to Odysseus and retransforms him Od. 16.155; she transforms him back to a beggar Od. 16.454; she suggests to Penelope to appear before the suitors Od. 18.158; she bears the light while the arms are being removed Od. 19.33; she appears to Odysseus while he lies in the πρόδομος Od. 13.30; she appears in the crisis of the fight with the suitors Od. 22.205; is advised by Zeus to make peace between the Ithacans and Odysseus and his followers Od. 24.472, stops the fight 531; etc.
G (μήστωρες ἀϋτῆς). The Athenians Il. 2.551, 558, Il. 4.328, Il. 13.196, 689, Il. 15.337.

div1.head: Ἀθήνη-1
div1.p: See Ἀθῆναι.

div1.head: Ἀθήνη-2
div1.p: See Ἀθηναίη.
The mountain terminating the peninsula Acte running out from Chalcidice Il. 14.229.
An epithet or name of uncertain meaning (cf. Αἰήτης). Of Circe Od. 9.32, Od. 12.268, 273.
Of her island Od. 10.135, Od. 11.70, Od. 12.3.
Patr. fr. next. Of Peleus Il. 16.15, Il. 18.433, Il. 21.189.
Son of Zeus and father of Peleus Il. 21.189.

div2.p:
Voc. αἶαν?̔ἄλκιμος, ἀντίθεος,?̓αρήϊος, βοὴν ἀγαθός, δαΐφρων, διογενής, ἕρκος?̓αχαιῶν, κοίρανος λαῶν, κυδάλιμος, μεγάθυμος, μεψαλήτωρ,
μέγας, πελώριος, ταχύς, τελαμώνιος?̔υἱός̓, φαίδιμος̓. Patr. Τελαμωνιάδης. (1) Son of Telamon and leader of the men of Salamis Il. 2.557; after Achilles the most soldierly of the Greeks Il. 2.768; described by Helen to Priam Il. 3.225; he and Aias-2 visited by Agamemnon in his inspection Il. 4.273; chosen by lot to fight Hector Il. 6.181, the fight 206, they exchange gifts 303; his brother the archer Teucrus shoots from behind his shield Il. 8.267, he rescues him when wounded 330; is one of the embassy to Achilles Il. 9.169, makes the final appeal 622; with Menelaus comes to the rescue of Odysseus Il. 11.465, retires panic-stricken 544; goes with Teucrus to the help of Menestheus Il. 12.364; disables Hector Il. 14.409; makes a stand on the platforms of the ships Il. 15.674, retires to a gangway 727, abandons the ship Il. 16.102; with Menelaus comes to the rescue of the corpse of Patroclus Il. 17.123, his cry for light 645, the corpse is at last rescued Il. 18.231; his drawn wrestling-match with Odysseus Il. 23.708, meets Diomedes in the fight in armour 811, is second in putting the weight 838; etc. : Od. 3.109; in the Shades Od. 11.469, avoids Odysseus 543, 550; in the second νέκυιαOd. 24.17.

In dual Αἴαντε and pl. Αἴαντες (with dat. Αἰάντεσσιν) the two ̔ομώνυμοι (P 720) spoken of or acting together (θεράποντες Ἄρηος, θοῦριν ὲπιειμένοι ἀλκήν, μεμαότε θούριδος ἀλκῆς, κορυστά, πολέμου ἀκορήτω) Il. 2.406, Il. 4.273, Il. 6.164, Il. 12.265, Il. 13.126, Il. 16.555, Il. 18.157, etc.

div1.head: Αἴας-2
div1.p: Voc. Αἶαν?̔δουρικλυτός, ταχύς, φαίδιμος̓. Patr. Ὀϊλιάδης. Son of Oieus-1 and leader of the Locrians. Described Il. 2.527; recognizes a god in the guise of Calchas Il. 13.66; stands firm with his namesake Il. 13.701; does much execution Il. 14.520; slays Cleoboulus Il. 16.330; watching the chariot-race abuses Idomeneus Il. 23.473, comes in second in the foot-race 754; etc.: his death at the Gyraean Rock Od. 4.499, 509.
See also prec. (2).
A seat of the worship of Poseidon of disputed site Od. 8.203, Il. 13.21: Od. 5.381.
A hundred-handed being called by the gods Βριάρεως. Saved Zeus from bonds Il. 1.403, 404.
Patr. fr. Αἰγεύς, king of Athens. Of Theseus Il. 1.265.
(περίφρων). Patr. Ἀδρηστίνη. Daughter of Adrestus-1 and wife of Diomedes Il. 5.412.

div1.head: Αἰγιαλός-1
div1.p: A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.575.

div1.head: Αἰγιαλός-2
div1.p: A Paphlagonian town Il. 2.855.
(τρηχεῖα). App. a town of Ithaca Il. 2.633.
The Aegean island. In the realm of Diomedes Il. 2.562.
Atown in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.574.

(ἀμύμων, ἄναλκις, δολόμητις). Patr. Θυεστιάδης. Son of Thyestes and cousin of Agamemnon and Menelaus. Seduced Clytaemnestra and with her aid killed A. (C. killing Cassandra (Od. 11.422)) on A. 's return, all his and A. 's followers also being killed Od. 1.35, 42, 300, Od. 3.194, 198, 235, 250, 256, 263, 303, Od. 4.518, 525, 529, 537, Od. 11.389, 409, Od. 24.22, 97; slain with Clytaemnestra by Orestes-3 Od. 1.29, 300, Od. 3.195, 198, 306, 310.

div1.head: Αἰγύπτιος-1
div1.p: Father of Antiphus-4 and Eurynomus Od. 2.15.

div2.p: (1) Adj. fr. Αἴγυπτος (1). Of Proteus Od. 4.385.
Adj. fr. Αἴγυπτος (2), Egyptian Od. 4.229. Of Thebes-2 Od. 4.127.
In pl., the Egyptians Od. 4.83.
So Αἰγύπτιοι ἄνδρες 263, 286, Od. 17.432.
(1) (διιπετὴς ποταμός, ἐϋρρείτης). In masc., the river Nile Od. 3.300, Od. 4.477, 581, Od. 14.257, 258, Od. 17.427.
Αἴγυπτόνδε [-δε], to the N. Od. 4.483, Od. 14.246, Od. 17.426.
In fem., the land of Egypt Od. 4.351, 355, Od. 14.275, Od. 17.448.

div1.p: -αο, -εω. Also genit. Ἄϊδος?̔ἆ and dat. Ἄϊδι?̔ἆ?̔ἀδάμαστος, ἀμείλιχος, ἐνέροισιν ἀνάσσων, ἴφθιμος, κλυτότωλος, κρατερός, πελώριος, πυλάρτης, στυγερός). Hades, son of Cronus and Rhea, brother of Zeus, Poseidon, Hera and Demeter, and husband of Persephoncia. By lot (Il. 15.187, 191) got the underworld as his realm. Wounded by Heracles with an arrow Il. 5.395; πύλαι Ἀΐδαο Il. 5.646, Il. 9.312, Il. 23.71: Od. 14.156; Ἄϊδος κυνέη Il. 5.845; his dog carried off by Heracles Il. 8.367, 368; etc.: Od. 10.534, Od. 11.47, etc.
In local sense Il. 23.244.
His δόμος or δόμοι, δῶ, δῶμα, see δόμος (2), δῶ (2), δῶμα (2) in Lex.
See also εἰς Π̔̓ (2), εἴσω (3), ἐκ Π̔̓ (1) in Lex.
(ὀλοόφρων). King of Colchis, son of Eelius and Perse and brother of Circe Od. 10.137; the voyage of the Argo from his land Od. 12.70.
(καλλίθριξ). A mare of Agamemnon's. Driven by Menelaus in the chariot-race Il. 23.295, 409, 525.
A people of Thessaly. The Centaurs driven to their land by Peirithous Il. 2.744.

Αἰθιοπῆες A 423 (ἀμύμονες, ἔσχατοι ἀνδρῶν). A people represented as dwelling by Ocean on the extreme limits of the world. Zeus and the gods go thither for a sacrifice Il. 1.423; so Iris Il. 23.206: and Poseidon Od. 1.22, Od. 5.287.
Divided into two peoples Od. 1.22.
Visited by Menelaus Od. 4.84.
Returning from them Poseidon desries Odysseus Od. 5.282.
Daughter of Pittheus. A handmaid of Helen at Troy Il. 3.144.

div1.head: Αἴθων-1
div1.p: One of Hector's horses Od. 8.185.

div1.head: Αἴθων-2
div1.p: The name assumed by Odysseus in his tale to Penelope Od. 19.183.

div1.head: Αἱμονίδης-1
div1.p: Patr. of Maeon Il. 4.394.

div1.head: Αἱμονίδης-2
div1.p: Patr. of Laerces-1 Il. 16.467.
G (κρείων) Il. 4.296.

Αἰνέας N 541 (ἄναξ ἀνδρῶν, ἀτάλαντος Ἄρηϊ, βονηφόος, δαΐφρων, ἐΰς, μεγάθυμος, μεγαλήτωρ, πόδας ταχύς, Τρώων ἀγός?̔βουληφόρος̓̓. Patr. Ἀγχισιάδης. Son of Anchises and Aphrodite. Leader of the Dardanians Il. 2.820; with Pandarus
attacks Diomedes Il. 5.166, is wounded by Δ. 305, but rescued by Aphrodite 311, his horses driven off by Capaneus 319, Il. 8.108, Il. 23.292, D attacks him again Il. 5.432, but retires before Apollo 443; A. 's resentment against Priam Il. 13.459; he meets Achilles in fight Od. 3.160, tells his parentage 199, is rescued by Poseidon 320; etc.
T. A Paeonian. S. Achilles Il. 21.210.
The mod. Enos, a Thracian town at the mouth of the Hebrus.
Αἰνόθεν [-θεν], from Ae. Il. 4.520.
Patr. fr. Αἴολος (no doubt different from the Aeolus below; but the Aeolus legends can hardly be disentangled). Of Sisyphus Il. 7.154.
Of Cretheus Od. 11.237.
Adj. fr. next Od. 10.1, 55.
(μεγαλήτωρ, φίλος ἀθανάτοισι θεοῖσιν). Patr. Ἱπποτάδης. Dwelt with his sons and daughters on a floating island Od. 10.2; made by Zeus controller of the winds Od. 10.21; Od. 10.36, 44, 60, Od. 23.314.
(καλή). A town of Pylus Il. 9.152, 294.
(ἐΰκτιτον). A town of Pylus Il. 2.592.
Adj. fr. Αἴπυτος, son of Elatus, an Arcadian Il. 2.604 (Αἰπύτιον παρὰ τύμβον).
See Ἶρος.
See Ἀΐδης.

div1.head: Αἴσηπος-1
div1.p: A river of the Troad flowing into the Propontis Il. 2.825, Il. 4.91 Il. 12.21.

div1.head: Αἴσηπος-2
div1.p: T. Son of Boucolion and Abarbaree. With his twin brother Pedasus-3 s. Euryalus-1 Il. 7.21.

div1.head: Αἰσυήτης-1
div1.p: (γέρων). His tomb Il. 2.793.

div1.head: Αἰσυήτης-2
div1.p: (διοτρεφής) Father of Alcathous Il. 13.427.
A Paeonian town, or perh. rather an unknown town of the Troad. The home of Castianeira.
ὲξ Αἰσύμηθεν [-θεν], from Ae. Il. 8.304.
G. S. Hector Il. 11.303.
Son of Cretheus and Tyro Od. 11.259.
=next. Of Tydeus Il. 4.399.
Of Trechus Il. 5.706.
Of Aetolia, a district of Greece having the Achelous on the w., and bounded by the Gulf of Corinth on the s. Of Thoas-1 Il. 4.527.
Of Diomedes Il. 23.471.
Of one who beguiled Eumaeus Od. 14.379.
In pl., the men of Aetolia G (μεγάθυμοι, μενεχάρμαι) Il. 2.638, 643, Il. 5.843; their strife with the Couretes (see Κουρῆτες) Il. 9.529, 531, 549, 575, 597; Il. 13.218, Il. 15.282, Il. 23.633.

div1.head: Ἀκάμας-1
div1.p: T (ἐπιείκελος ἀθανάτοισιν, ἠΐθεος). Patr. Ἀντηνορίδης. Son of Antenor. A leader of the Dardanians Il. 2.823, Il. 11.60, Il. 12.100, Il. 14.476, 478, 488; s. Meriones Il. 16.342.

div1.head: Ἀκάμας-2
div1.p: T (ἠΰς τε μἑγας τε, θοός). Son of Eussorus. A leader of the Thracians Il. 2.844, Il. 5.462; s. Aias-1 Il. 7.8.
King of Doulichium Od. 14.336.
Father of Periboea-1 Il. 21.142.
Patr. of Danae, daughter of Acrisius Il. 14.319.
A Phaeacian Od. 8.111.
A Nereid Il. 18.41.
Patr. of Echeclees Il. 16.189.
A servant given by her father to Penelope on her marriage Od. 23.228.

In form a patr. ; but the occurrence against analogy of two such words together in Il. 11.750 (Ἀκτορίωνε Μολίονε) makes it doubtful whether it is a patr. The words have not been satisfactorily explained. Of Cteatus and Eurytus-2 Il. 11.750, Il. 23.638.
Of Cteatus Il. 13.185.
Of Amphimachus and Thalpius (sons of C. and E.) Il. 2.621.

div1.head: Ἄκτωρ-1
div1.p: Patr. Ἀζεΐδης. App. father of Astyoche Il. 2.513.

div1.head: Ἄκτωρ-2
div1.p: Father of Menoetius Il. 11.785, Il. 16.14.
See Lexicon.
Patr. of Tros-2 Od. 3.463.

div1.head: Ἀλάστωρ-1
div1.p: G (δῖος) Il. 4.295; assists Mecisteus-2 in carrying off the wounded Teucrus Il. 8.333, and Hypsenor-2 Il. 13.422.

div1.head: Ἀλάστωρ-2
div1.p: T. S. Odysseus Il. 5.677.
Patr. of Promachus Il. 14.503.
(μεγάθυμος). Father of Leitus Il. 16.602.
A Spartan. Megapenthes married his daughter Od. 4.10.
See Πάρις.
πεδίον.. A plain not localized. 'A. is app. formed to agree in sound with ἀλᾶτο in the same line Il. 7.201. ‘The plain of wandering.’
A hill on the confines of Bouprasion Il. 2.617, Il. 11.757.
Wife of Oeneus and mother of Tydeus and Meleagrus Il. 9.555. A brother of A. slain by M. and her curses thereupon Il. 9.565.
̔ποιήεις̓ A Bocotian town Il. 2.503.
T. Perh. a people of the s. shore of the Euxine beyond the Paphlagonians Il. 2.856, Il. 5.39.
̔βοῶπις̓. A Nereid Il. 18.40.
Patr. Μαστορίδης-1 An Ithacan elder. His speech in the assembly Od. 2.157; Od. 2.253, Od. 17.68; advises against attacking Odysseus Od. 24.451.

div1.head: Ἅλιος-1
div1.p: T. S. Odysseus Il. 5.678.

div1.head: Ἅλιος-2
div1.p: Son of Alcinous Od. 8.119, 370.
Son of Aesyetes-2, husband of Hippodameia-2 and son-in-law of Anchises Il. 12.93; s. Idomeneus Il. 13.428, 465, 496.
Wife of Polybus-3 Od. 4.126.
T. S. Odysseus Il. 5.678.
(δῖα γυναικῶν, Πελίαο θυγατρῶν εἶδος ἀρίστἠ. Daughter of Pelies, wife of Admetus and mother of Eumelus Il. 2.715.
(ἀμύμων). Son of Laerces-1 A leader under Achilles Il. 16.197; comes to the aid of Automedon Il. 17.467, 475, 481, 500, 501.
Patr. of Mentor-2 Od. 22.235.
(ὄζος Ἄρηος). θεράπων of Achilles Il. 19.392, Il. 24.474, 574.

(ἀμύμων, βασιλεύς, δαΐθρων, θεοειδής,
θεοείκελος, θεῶν ἄπο μήδεα εἰδώς, ίερὸν μένος, κρείων, μεγαλήτωρ, πάντων ἀριδείκετος λαῶν). King of the Phaeacians. Son of Nausithous, husband of Arete (the daughter of his brother Rhexenor) and father of Laodamas-2 Halius-2, Clytoneus and Nausicaa. His parentage Od. 6.56; his house described Od. 6.84, and his orchard and garden 112; Odysseus approaches him and Arete Od. 6.141, he raises O. from the hearth 167, promises him conduct to his home 317, Od. 8.26; entertains him with games Od. 8.97, and with the singing of Demodocus 254; proposes the giving of gifts to him Od. 8.389; asks for his tale Od. 8.572; puts the gifts on board the ship Od. 13.20, dispatches Il. 15.64 ; for fear of Poseidon proposes to give up conducting strangers Od. 13.171; etc.
A handmaid of Helen at Sparta Od. 4.124.

div1.head: Ἀλκμάων-1
div1.p: G. Patr. Θεστορίδης-2. S. Sarpedon Il. 12.394.

div1.head: Ἀλκμάων-2
div1.p: Son of Amphiaraus Od. 15.248.

Wife of Amphitryon and mother of Heracles by Zeus Il. 14.323; H 's birth delayed by contrivance of Here, whereby H. became subject to Eurystheus Il. 19.99, 119: A. brought into comparison with Penelope Od. 2.120; in the Shades Od. 11.266.
A name for Cleopatra. The reason given Il. 9.562.
A town of Argos-2 on the n. shore of the entrance to the Malian Gulf Il. 2.682.
A town of Argos-2 on the w. shore of the Pagasaean Gulf Il. 2.682.
(ὀνομάκλυτος). King of the Leleges and father of Laothoe Il. 21.85, 86, Il. 22.51.
Of uncertain site. Odysseus in his tale to Laertes claims to have come thence Od. 24.304.
A town of the Halizonians Il. 2.857.
(ἱερός). A river of w. Peloponnesus flowing through the (app. n.) extremity of Nestor's realm Il. 2.592; father of Ortilochus-3 Il. 5.545: Od. 3.489, Od. 15.187; Il. 11.712, 726, 728.
Husband of Iphimedeia and nominal father of Otus-1 and Ephialtes Il. 5.386: Od. 11.305.
(ἀντιάνειραι). A race of warlike women. Invaded Phrygia Il. 3.189; Bellerophon's fight with them Il. 7.186.
(ὲϋπλόκαμος). A Nereid Il. 18.48.
See Lexicon.
Patr. fr. next. Of Diores-1 Il. 2.622, Il. 4.517.
(κρείων). Father of Diores-1. His funeral games Il. 23.630.
Father of Atymnius and Maris. Reared the Chimaera Il. 16.328.
The port of Cnosus Od. 19.188.
T. Patr. Πολυαιμονίδης. S. Teucrus Il. 8.276.
The city of the Paeonians Il. 2.849, Il. 16.288.
(ἱππιοχάρμης). Son of Cretheus and Tyro Od. 11.259. Was father of Melampus.
A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.584.
Patr. Ὀρμενίδης. Ruler of Hellas (but in Il. 10.266 he is spoken of as living in Eleon) and father of Phoenix-1 Il. 9.448, Il. 10.266.
Son of Polyneus. A Phaeacian Od. 8.114, 128.
(λαοσσόος). The seer, son of Oicles, husband of Eriphyle and father of Alcmaon-2 and Amphilochus. Perished by the treachery of his wife Od. 15.244, 253.
A town of Pylus Il. 2.593.

div1.head: Ἀμφιδάμας-1
div1.p: A Cytherian Il. 10.268, 269.

div1.head: Ἀμφιδάμας-2
div1.p: His son killed in a quarrel by Patroclus Il. 23.87.
Wife of Autolycus and mother of Anticleia Od. 19.416.
A Nerei Il. 18.42.
T. S. Meges Il. 16.313.
Son of Amphiaraus Od. 15.248.

div1.head: Ἀμφίμαχος-1
div1.p: (μεγαλήτωρ) See Ἀκτορίων. Son of Cteatus and grandson of Poseidon, and a leader of the Epeians Il. 2.620; s. Hector Il. 13.185, 189, 195, 203; Poseidon's wrath at his slaying Il. 13.206.

div1.head: Ἀμφίμαχος-2
div1.p: (ἀγλαός). Son of Nomion and a leader of the Carians Il. 2.870, 871; s. Achilles Il. 2.874.
(ἀγακλυτός) A suitor, son of Melaneus Od. 24.103; Od. 22.242; wounds Telemachus Od. 22.277, who slays him 284; in the Shades Od. 24.103, 106, 120.
A Nereid Il. 18.44.

(Δουλιχιεύς, φαίδιμος). Son of Nisus, and the leader of the suitors from Doulichium. First sees the ship returning from the ambush laid for Telemachus Od. 16.351; pleasing to Penelope Od. 16.394; wishes Odysseus well after the fight with Irus Od. 18.119, his presentiment of evil 153, Ο. takes refuge with him when threatened by Eurymachus 395; s. Telemachus Od. 22.89, 96; etc.

div1.head: Ἄμφιος-1
div1.p: (λινοθώρηξ). See Ἄδρηστος-2.

div1.head: Ἄμφιος-2
div1.p: T. Son of Selagus. S. Aias-1 Il. 5.612.
(ἀγάστονος, κλυτός, κυανῶπις). A divine marine being Od. 3.91, Od. 5.422, Od. 12.60, 97.
Husband of Alcmene and putative father of Heracles Il. 5.392: Od. 11.266, 270.

div1.head: Ἀμφίων-1
div1.p: A leader of the Epeians Il. 13.692.

div1.head: Ἀμφίων-2
div1.p: Son of Zeus and Antiope. With his brother Zethus represented as having founded Thebes-1 Od. 11.262.

div1.head: Ἀμφίων-3
div1.p: Patr. Ἰασίδης-1 King of Orchomenus-1 and father of Chloris Od. 11.283.
T. S. Patroclus Il. 16.415.
A Phaeacian Od. 8.113.
Patr. fr. next. Of Thoas-1 Il. 6.168.

(λευκώλενος, πολύδωρος). Daughter of Eetion-1, wife of Hector and mother of Astyanax. Absent when H. visited his house
Il. 7.371, 377, her meeting and conversation with him 395, 405; her care of his horses Il. 8.187; Il. 17.208; sees his corpse being dragged to the ships Il. 22.460, her lament for him and Astyanax 477; her lament over his ransomed corpse Il. 24.723.
A town of Phocis Il. 2.521.
(βαθύλειμος). A town of Pylus Il. 9.151, 293.
Patr. fr. next. Of Simocisius Il. 4.488.
Father of Simoeisius Il. 4.473.
(ἐσχατόωσα). A Boeotian town Il. 2.508.
(δῖα). Daughter (app.) of a king of Lycia and wife of Proetus (see under Βελλεροφόντης) Il. 7.160.
Patr. fr. next. Of Helicaon Il. 3.122, 123.
Of Laodocus-1 Il. 4.87.
Of Polybus-1 Il. 11.59.
Of Agenor Il. 11.59.
Of Acamas-1 Il. 11.59.
Of Iphidamas Il. 11.221.
Of Coon Il. 11.249, Il. 19.53.

(ἀγαυός, ἱππόδαμος, πεπνυμένος). A Trojan elder. Husband of Theano and father of Acamas-1 Agenor, Archelochus, Coon, Demoleon, Helicaon, Iphidamas, Laodocus-1, Laodamas-1, Pedaius (bastard), and Polybus-1 Il. 2.822, Il. 3.148; had entertained Odysseus and Menelaus Il. 3.203; Il. 3.262, 312, Il. 7.299; counsels the restoration of Helen Il. 6.347; Il. 6.357, Il. 11.262, Il. 12.99, Il. 14.463, 473, Il. 15.517, Od. 3.396, Il. 21.546, 579.
Daughter of Autolycus, wife of Laertes and mother of Odysseus and Ctimene. Her death Od. 15.356; O. sees her in the Shades Od. 11.85.
G. In the Trojan horse Od. 4.286.

(ἀγλαός, ἀμύμων, δαΐφρων, διοτρεφής, θείειν ταχύς, θοὸς πολεμιστής, κρατερός, κυδάλιμος, μαχητής, μενεχάρμης, μήστωρ ἀϋτῆς, Νηλήϊος, πεπνυμένος). Patr. Νεστορίδης. Son of Nestor. Slays Echepolus-1 Il. 4.457; comes to the rescue of Menelaus Il. 5.565; slays Mydon-1 Il. 5.580; slays Ablerus Il. 7.32; slays the chariot-driver of Asius-2 Il. 13.396; slays Thoon-3 Il. 13.545; slays Phalces and Mermerus Il. 14.513; slays Melanippus-2 Il. 15.575; slays Atymnius Il. 16.318; hears from Menelaus of the death of Patroclus Il. 17.685, announces the death to Achilles Il. 18.18; takes part in the chariot-race Il. 23.301, Nestor's advice to him 306, addresses his horses 402, gains the advantage of Menelaus and comes in second 417, objects to Achilles' proposal to give Eumelus the second prize 541, Menelaus accuses him of foul driving 566, A. pacifies him 586, takes part in the foot-race 756, comes in last 785; etc.: Nestor speaks of his death at Troy Od. 3.112; was slain by Memnon Od. 4.187, 202; in the Shades Od. 11.468, Od. 24.16; Od. 24.78.
(δαΐφρων). Father of Hippolochus-2, Peisandrus-1 and Hippomachus. Corrupted by Paris opposed the restoration of Helen Il. 11.123, 132, 138; Il. 12.188.

(βασιλεύς, θεοειδής, ἱερὸν μένος Ἀντινόοιο, πεπνυμένος). Son of Eupeithes. With Eurymachus leader of the suitors. Taunts Telemachus among the suitors Od. 1.383; answers T. in the Ithacan assembly Od. 2.84; proposes to waylay T. Od. 4.660, gets a ship ready for this 778, reports ill success Od. 16.363; the disguised Odysseus begs from him Od. 17.414, he strikes him with a stool 458; his gift to Penelope Od. 18.292; refrains from trial of the bow Od. 21.186 (he does not seem to make the trial at all); s. Odysseus Od. 22.8, Od. 24.179; etc.
Daughter of the Asopus and mother by Zeus of Amphion-2 and Zethus Od. 11.260.

div1.head: Ἀντιφάτης-1
div1.p: T. S. Leonteus Il. 12.191.

div1.head: Ἀντιφάτης-2
div1.p: (κλυτός), also called Λάμος (Od. 10.81). The king of the Laestry gonians Od. 10.81, 106, 114, 199.

div1.head: Ἀντιφάτης-3
div1.p: (κραταιός). Son of Melampus and father of Oicles Od. 15.242, 243.
A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.250.

div1.head: Ἄντιφος-1
div1.p: Son of Thessalus and with his brother Pheidippus a leader of the men of Nisurus, Cos, etc., Il. 2.678.

div1.head: Ἄντιφος-2.
div1.p: Son of Talaemenes and a leader of the Maeonians (Μῄονες) Il. 2.864.

div1.head: Ἄντιφος-3
div1.p: (αἰολοθώρηξ). Patr. Πριαμίδης. A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 4.489; had been taken with his brother Isus on Ida and released on ransom, now both slain by Agamemnon Il. 11.101, 104, 109.

div1.head: Ἄντιφος-4
div1.p: (αἰχμητής). Son of Aegyptius-1. Devoured by the Cyclops Od. 2.19.

div1.head: Ἄντιφος-5.
div1.p: A comrade in Ithaca of Odysseus Od. 17.68.
(ἀγχίαλος). A town in the realm of Protesilaus Il. 2.697.
(εὐρὺ ῥέων, εὐρυρέεθρος). A river flowing into the Thermaic Gulf Il. 2.849, 850, Il. 16.288; father of Pelegon by Periboea-1 Il. 21.141, 157, 158.
T. Patr. Τευθρανίδης. Dwelt by the roadside in Arisbe. With his charioteer Calesius s. Diomedes Il. 7.12.
Παισός Il. 5.612. A dist. of the Troad on the western extremity of the Propontis Il. 2.828, Il. 5.612.
Adj. fr. next. Of Eurymedousa Od. 6.8.
A mythical land.
Ἀπείρηθεν [-θεν], from A. Od. 6.9.

div1.head: Ἀπισάων-1
div1.p: T (ποιμὴν λαῶν). Patr. Φαυσιάδης. S. Eurypylus-2 Il. 11.578, 582.

div1.head: Ἀπισάων-2
div1.p: T (ποιμὴν λαῶν). Patr. Ἱππασίδης-3. S. Lycomedes Il. 17.348.

Voc. Ἄπολλον?̔ἄναξ, ἀργυρότοξος, Δῒ φίλος, ἑκάεργος, ἑκατηβελέτης, ἑκατηβόλος, ἕκατος, ἑκηβόλος, κλυτότοξος, λαοσσόος, Λυκηγενής, χρυσάορος). Called also Φοῖβος (ἀκερσεκόμης, ἤϊος) Il. 1.443, Il. 15.221, 365, Il. 16.667, 788, Od. 3.39, 152, Il. 21.436, 448. Ἀπόλλων Φοῖβος Il. 16.700, Od. 17.68, Il. 21.515, 545. Φοῖβος) Ἀπόλλων Il. 1.43, Il. 5.344, Il. 9.560, Il. 12.24, Il. 15.59, Od. 3.118, Il. 23.188, etc.: Od. 3.279, Od. 8.79, Od. 9.201. Son of Zeus and Leto and brother of Artemis. Identified
with Smintheus Il. 1.39. Besought by Chryses (Il. 1.37) sends pestilence on the Greeks Il. 1.43, is appeased 457; saves Aeneas from Diomedes Il. 5.440; with Poseidon destroys the Greek wall Il. 12.17; sent by Zeus heartens Hector Il. 15.236; cures Glaucus-2 Il. 16.527; cares for Sarpedon's corpse Il. 16.676; repels Patroclus from the walls Il. 16.698; strikes and unarms P. Il. 16.788, Il. 18.454; his death-dealing shafts (always directed against men, for those of Artemis see Ἄρτεμις) Il. 21.278, Il. 24.605, 758 (cf. Od. 3.279, Od. 6.64, Od. 15.410, Od. 17.251, 494); in the Battle of the Gods Poseidon challenges him Il. 21.436, but he declines 461; beguiles Achilles while the Trojans flee Il. 21.599; Achilles destined to fall before him and Paris Il. 22.359; in the chariot-race disables Diomedes Il. 23.382; cares for Hector's corpse Il. 24.18; etc.: Od. 7.162 Od. 8.79, Od. 9.198, Od. 15.245, etc.
(ἐρατεινή). A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.571.
Patr. of Polymelus Il. 16.417.

div2.p: Of Hera Il. 4.8, Il. 5.908.
In pl., the Argives

div3.p: The people of Argos-1 (1) Il. 19.122, 124: Od. 3.309, Od. 15.240.
The people of Proetus (his seat being Tiryns in Argos-1 (1)) Il. 7.159.
The Greeks on their way to Troy Od. 1.211, Od. 2.173, Od. 18.253, Od. 19.126.
The Greeks preparing for or on their return (Ἀχαιός (2) (b) (d)) Od. 3.133, Od. 8.502.

div1.p: See Lexicon.
A town of Thessaly. Its men led by Polypoetes and Leonteus Il. 2.738.

div2.p: (ἱππόβοτον, κλυτόν, οὖθαρ ἀρούρης, πολυδίψιον, πολύπυρον). (1) The Argolic plain in the Peloponnesus stretching inwards from the Argolic gulf, and, app., adjoining lands Il. 1.30, Il. 2.108 (here app. the whole of the mainland over which Agamemnon's sway extended), 115, 559 (the realm of Diomedes (cf. Il. 7.224, Il. 14.119: Od. 3.180)), Il. 4.171, Il. 7.224, Il. 9.22, 141, 283, Il. 13.379, Il. 14.119, Il. 15.30, Il. 19.115: Od. 3.180, 251, 263, Od. 15.224, 239, 274.
The city Argos still known by the same name Il. 4.52: Od. 21.108.
Of southern Greece, esp. the Pelopnnesus, in contrast to northern Greece Il. 7.152: Od. 4.174, 562.
App. also Od. 4.246.
Esp. in phrase καθ̓?̔ἀν̓ Ἑλλάδα καὶ μέσον Ἄργος 344, Od. 4.726, 816, Od. 15.80.
App. also Il. 3.75, 258 (Argos and Achaeis being app. to be regarded as the same).
Ἄργοσδε [-δε], to Greece Il. 2.348.

div1.head: Ἄργος-2
div1.p: Πελασγικόν. App. a general name for the realm of Peleus, including Phthia and Hellas Il. 2.681.

div1.head: Ἄργος-3.
div1.p: The dog of Odysseus. The only creature to recognize O. in his disguise Od. 17.292, 300; dies 326.
(πασιμέλουσα). The ship of the Argonauts Od. 12.70.
A spring in Ithaca near the dwelling of Eumaeus and the Κόρακος πέτρη 408.
T (δῖος). S. Teucrus Il. 7.31.

div1.head: Ἀρηΐθοος-1
div1.p: (ἄναξ, δῖος). Named the clubbearer. Father by Phylomedousa of Menesthius-1 Il. 6.8, 10; was slain by Lycourgus-2 Il. 6.137, 138.

div1.head: Ἀρηΐθοος-2.
div1.p: Chariot-driver to Rhigmus. S. Achilles Od. 3.487.

div1.head: Ἀρηΐλυκος-1.
div1.p: Father of Prothoenor-2 Il. 14.451.

div1.head: Ἀρηΐλυκος-2
div1.p: T. S. Patroclus Il. 16.308.
(α) (ἐρατεινή). A town of Pylus Il. 2.591, Il. 11.723.

(ᾶ). Genit. Ἄρεος?̔ἆ, Ἄρηος?̔ᾶ). Dat. Ἄρεϊ?̔ἆ, Ἄρει?̔ἀ, Ἄρηϊ?̔ἆ, Ἄρῃ?̔ᾶ). Acc. Ἄρηα?̔ᾶ). Voc. Ἆρες, Ἄρες?̔ἀΐδηλος, ἀλλοπρόσαλλος, ἀνδροφόνος, ἆτος πολέμοιο, βριήπυος, βροτολοιγός, ἐγχέσπαλος, θοός, θοῦρος, κορυθαίολος, κρατερός, λαοσσόος, μιαιφόνος, ὄβριμος, ὀξύς, οὖλος, πελώριος, πτολίπορθος, ῥινοτόρος, ταλαύρινος πολεμιστής, τειχεσιπλήτης, χάλκεος, χρυσήνιος). See also Ἐνυάλιος. Son of Zeus and Her and father by Astyoche of Ascalaphus and Ialmenus. Athene leads him from the fray Il. 5.30; Aphrodite begs the use of his horses Il. 5.355; had been put in bonds by Otus-1 and Ephialtes Il. 5.385; Athene and Diomedes go against him Il. 5.840, D. wounds him and puts him to flight 855, his complaint to Zeus 872, he is cured 899; his rage on hearing of the death of Ascalaphus Il. 15.113, restrained by Athene 125; in the Battle of the Gods attacks Athene Il. 21.391, who lays him low 403, Aphrodite leads him off 416, Ath. lays them both low 423; etc: Od. 8.115; Demodocus's tale of Ares and Aphrodite Od. 8.266, 276, 285, 309, 330, 345, 353, 355; Od. 8.518, Od. 11.537, Od. 14.216, Od. 16.269, Od. 20.50.
See also Ἄρης in Lexicon.

(ἀ?̔λευκώλενος). Daughter of Rhexenor and niece and wife of Alcinous. Her parentage Od. 6.54, how she was honoured by A. and the people 67; Odysseus supplicates her Od. 6.142; she recognizes the robe given to O. by Nausicaa Od. 6.233; packs up O.'s gifts Od. 8.438; etc.
Patr. of Nisus Od. 16.395, Od. 18.413.

div1.head: Ἄρητος-1
div1.p: (ἀ T (θεοειδής) Il. 17.494; s. Automedon Il. 17.517, 535.

div1.head: Ἄρητος-2
div1.p: (α). Son of Nestor Od. 3.414, 440.
(καλή, καλλιπλόκαμος). Daughter of Minos. Her dancing-floor at Cnosus Il. 18.592: carried off by Theseus but slain by Artemis in Dia Od. 11.321.
A mythical people in whose country Typhoeus was put in bonds by Zeus Il. 2.783.
Father of Leiocritus-1 Il. 17.345.

(δῖα). A town of the Troad between
A bydus and Percote Il. 2.836, Il. 7.13, Il. 21.43.
Ἀρίσβηθεν [-θεν], from A. Il. 2.838, Il. 12.96.
(δῖος). The swift horse of Adrestus-1 of divine origin Il. 23.346.
G (ἐγχεσίμωροι). The Arcadians, an inland people of central Peloponnesus, to whom Agamemnon furnished ships Il. 2.611; Il. 6.134.
The country of the Arcadians Il. 2.603.
Patr. fr. next. Of Laertes Od. 4.755, Od. 24.270, 517.
(ἀντίθεος). Father of Laertes Od. 14.182, Od. 16.118.
A leader of the Boeotians Il. 2.495; s. Hector Il. 15.329.
See ἄρκτος (2) in Lexicon.
A Boeotian town Il. 2.499.
Patr. of Tecton Il. 5.60.
The real name of Irus Od. 18.5.
(πολυστάφυλος). A Boeotian town Il. 2.507; the home of Menesthius-1 Il. 6.9.
T. Son of Pylaemenes. S. Meriones Il. 13.644.
See Lexicon.
(μεγαλήτωρ). Father of Hecamede Il. 11.626.
(καλλιρέεθρος). The fountain of the Laestrygonians Od. 10.108.

(ἁγνή, ἀγροτέρη, ἐϋπλόκαμος, ἰοχέαιρα, κελαδεινή, πότνα θεά, χρυσηλάκατος, χρυσήνιος, χρυσόθρονος). Daughter of Zeus and Leto and sister of Apollo Il. 5.51, 53, 447, Il. 7.205; her death-dealing shafts, always (except Od. 5.123) directed against women (those of Apollo against men) Il. 7.428, Il. 19.59, Il. 24.606 (cf. Od. 11.172, 324, Od. 15.410, 478, Od. 18.202, Od. 20.60, 61, 80); Il. 9.533, Il. 16.183, Od. 3.39, 71; in the Battle of the Gods reproaches Apollo Il. 21.471, Hera assaults her 489: Od. 4.122, Od. 7.102, 151, Od. 17.37, Od. 19.54, Od. 20.71.
(ῥυδὸν ἀφνειός). A Sidonian, father of the Phoenician woman who stole Eumaeus away Od. 15.426.
T. Son of Antenor. A leader of the Dardanians Il. 2.823, Il. 12.100; s. Aias-1 Il. 14.464.
T (θρασύς). Patr. Ἰφιτίδης. Hector takes him as his chariot-driver Il. 8.128; s. Teucrus Il. 8.312.
(α) G. S. Hector Il. 11.301.
(α). Patr. fr. Ἄσιος-2. Of Phaenops-3 Il. 17.583.
And app. of Adamas Il. 12.140, Il. 13.561, 759, 771.
A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.560.

div1.head: Ἄσιος-1
div1.p: (ἀ?̔αἰζηός τε κρατερός τε). Son of Dymas-1 full brother of Hecabe and uncle of Hector. Apollo takes his form Il. 16.717.

div1.head: Ἄσιος-2
div1.p: (ἀ?̔ἄναξ, μέγας, ὄρχαμος ἀνδρῶν). Patr. ̔γρτακίδης. Son of Hyrtacus and father of Phaenops-3. Leader of the men of Percote, Abydus, etc. Il. 2.837, 838, Il. 12.95, 96; eagerly attacks the Greeks at the ships Il. 12.110, 136, 139, 163; s. Idomeneus Il. 13.384, 403, 414, 759, 771.

div1.head: Ἄσιος-3
div1.p: Ἀσίω (α). Adj. fr., the second form genit. of, Ἀσίας, said to have been a king of Lydia Il. 2.461.
Son of Ares and Astyoche. A leader of the men of Orchomenus-1, etc. Il. 2.512, Il. 9.82, Il. 13.478; s. Deiphobus Il. 13.518, 526, 527, Il. 15.112.
(ἐριβῶλαξ). A lake (and its district) connected with the Propontis, on which lake lay the later town of Nicaea Il. 2.863, Il. 13.793.
(θεοειδής). Came from Ascania, son of Hippotion. A leader of the Phrygians Il. 2.862, Il. 13.792.
Patr. fr. next. Of Machaon Il. 4.204, Il. 11.614, Il. 14.2.
(ἀμύμων ἰητήρ). Father of Podaleirius and Machaon Il. 2.731, Il. 4.194, Il. 11.518.
A Boeotian town near Orchomenus-1 Il. 2.511.
Son of Tros-1, father of Capys and grandfather of Anchises Od. 3.232, 239.
A town of Thessaly. Its men led by Eurypylus-2 Il. 2.735.
(πετρήεσσα). An island represented as lying between Ithaca and Same Od. 4.846.
(ἀρήϊος, περιδέξιος, φαίδιμος). Son of Pelegon and a leader of the Paeonians Il. 12.102, Il. 17.217, 351, 352; s. Achilles Il. 21.140, 163, 170; Il. 23.560, 808.
T. S. Polypoetes Il. 7.29.
(ἀγαπητός, ἀλίγκιος ἀστέρι καλῷ). Infant son of Hector and Andromache (called Scamandrius by his father). The name explained Il. 7.403; Il. 22.500, 506.

div1.head: Ἀστύνοος-1
div1.p: T. S. Diomedes Il. 5.144.

div1.head: Ἀστύνοος-2
div1.p: T. Son of Protiaon Il. 15.455.
Captured by Heracles at Ephyre-1 and bore him Tlepolemus-1 Il. 2.658.
Daughter (app.) of Actor-1 and mother by Ares of Ascalaphus and Ialmenus Il. 2.513.
T. A Paeonian. S. Achilles Il. 21.209.
θεράπων of Menelaus at Sparta Od. 4.216.
(ἀ?̔βαθύσχοινος λεχεποίης). A river of s. Boeotia Il. 4.383, Il. 10.287: father of Antiope Od. 11.260.
(ἀ. πρέσβα Διὸς θυγάτηρ 91. See further in Lexicon.
(ὀλοόφρων). Father of Calypso Od. 1.52, Od. 6.245.
Of Orestes-3 (grandson) Od. 1.40.
Patr. fr. next, = prec. Of Agamemnon Il. 1.387, Il. 2.192, 445, Il. 23.233, Il. 24.395.

(δαΐφρων, ἱππόδαμος, ποιμὴν λαῶν). Son of Pelops, brother of Thyestes and father of
Agamemnon and Menelaus Il. 2.23; the sceptre given to him by Pelops and by him to Thyestes Il. 2.105, 106; Il. 3.37, Il. 7.46, Il. 17.1; etc.: Od. 4.462, 543, Od. 11.436.
See Lexicon.
Patr. of Mydon-1 Il. 5.581.
T (ἀκοντιστης). Son of Amisodarus and brother of Maris. S. Antilochus Il. 16.317.

div1.head: Αὐγειαί-1
div1.p: (ἐρατειναί). A Locrian town Il. 2.532.

div1.head: Αὐγειαί-2
div1.p: (ἐρατειναί). A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.583.
(ἄναξ ἀνδρῶν). Ruler of Elis and father of Agasthenes and Agamede. Detained Neleus's race-horses Il. 11.701, 739.
Patr. fr. prec. Of Agasthenes Il. 2.624.
-ίδος?̔πετρήεσσα). A Boeotian town on the Euripus by which the Greek ships assembled Il. 2.303, 496.

(μεγαλήτωρ). Husband of Amphithee and father of Anticleia Od. 11.85; dwelt by Parnassus Od. 19.394; gives a name to the babe Odysseus, his grandson Od. 19.399; O. goes to visit him and is wounded by a boar Od. 19.413, Od. 21.220, Od. 24.334.
His skill in thieving and false swearing Il. 10.267: Od. 19.394.

(ἄλκιμος, δουρικλυτός). Son of Diores-2. θεράπων of Achilles Il. 9.209, Il. 16.864; acts as chariot-driver to Patroclus Il. 16.145, 148, 219, 472, 684; after P. 's death drives alone Il. 17.429, 452, 459; takes up Alcimedon Il. 17.468, 469, 474; stands up to Hector and Aeneas Il. 17.483, 498; kills Aretus-1 Il. 17.516, 536; escapes Hector Il. 17.525; retires Il. 17.540; acts as chariot-driver to Achilles Il. 19.392, 397; Il. 23.563, Il. 24.474, 574, 625.
A handmaid of Penelope Od. 18.182.

div1.head: Αὐτόνοος-1
div1.p: G. S. Hector Il. 11.301.

div1.head: Αὐτόνοος-2
div1.p: T. S. Patroclus Il. 16.694.
Father of Polyphontes Il. 4.395.
G. Patr. Καλητορίδης 83, Il. 13.478; s. Aeneas Il. 13.541.
(ἄναξ). Patr. Πολυπημονίδης. Alleged father of the alleged Eperitus Od. 24.305.

(ἆ?̔δῖα, Διὸς θυγάτηρ?̔κούρἠ, ἐϋστέφανος, φιλομμειδής, χρυσέη, χρυσείη). Called also Κύπρις Il. 5.330, 422, 458, 760, 883; and Κυθέρεια Od. 8.288, Od. 18.193. Daughter of Zeus and Dione and by Anchises mother of Aeneas (Il. 2.820). In Od. (Od. 8.266) the wife of Hephaestus. Her seat Paphos Od. 8.363. Saves Paris from Menelaus Il. 3.374; summons Helen to Paris Il. 3.389; carries off Aeneas from Diomedes Il. 5.311, D. attacks and wounds her 330, her complaint to Dione 370; gives Hera her κεστὸς ιμάς 188; in the Battle of the Gods leads off the wounded Ares Il. 21.416, is smitten by Athene 423; etc.: Od. 4.14, 261; Demodocus's tale of Ares and Aphrodite Od. 8.266, 308, 337, 342, 362; Od. 17.37, Od. 19.54, Od. 20.68, 73.
See also Ἀφροδίτη in Lexicon.
(ἐΰπεπλοι). Achaean women (Ἀχαιός (2) (b) (a)) Il. 5.422, 424: Od. 3.261.
The women of the realm of Odysseus (Ἀχαιός (2) (b)) Od. 2.101, Od. 19.146, Od. 21.160, Od. 24.136.

div2.p: Achaean. (1) λαὸς Ἀχαιϊκός Ἀχαιός (2) (b) (γ̓) Il. 9.521, Il. 13.349, Il. 15.218.
Fem. adj. (1) Achaean. Ἀχαιῒς γαῖα?̔αἶἀ Ἀχαιός (2) (b) (a)) Il. 1.254, Il. 6.124: Od. 13.249, Od. 21.107.
Absol. (καλλιγύναιξ) Il. 3.75, 258 (for these cf. under Ἄργος-1 (4)): Od. 11.166, 481, Od. 23.68.
App. in particular of the realm of Peleus (πουλοβότειρα) Il. 11.770.
In pl., (the) Achaean women Il. 2.235, Il. 6.96.
App. in particular of the maidens of the realm of Peleus Il. 9.395: of the realm of Odysseus Od. 21.251.
(1) In sing., of the Achaeans (see (2) (b) (g) below) Il. 3.167, 226.
Absol. in pl.

div3.p: Applied with Μυρμιδόνες and Ἕλληνες to the followers of Achilles Il. 2.684.
(ἀρήϊοι, ἀρηΐφιλοι, δῖοι, ἑλίκωπες, ἐϋκνήμιδες, κάρη κομόωντες, μεγάθυμοι, μένεα πνείοντες, μένος ἄσχετοι, ὑπερκύδαντες, φιλοπτόλεμοι, χαλκοχίτωνες, χαλκοκνήμιδες). The Greeks.

div2.p: The race in gen.

div3.p: The followers of Odysseus on his way to Troy (in O.'s tale to Penelope) Od. 19.199.
The Greeks preparing for and on their return (Ἀργεῖος (2) (e)) Od. 1.286, 326, Od. 3.131, 137, 141, 149, 185, Od. 4.487, 496, Od. 9.59, 259, Od. 10.15, Od. 13.317, Od. 14.242.
The people of Neleus or Nestor at Pylus Il. 11.759: Od. 3.372.
The ruling race in Argos-1 (1) (3) Od. 15.274, Od. 18.246.
Said by Odysseus in his tale to Penelope to be one of the five divisions of the inhabitants of Crete Od. 19.175.

div1.head: Ἀχελώϊος-1
div1.p: (κρείων). The largest Greek river flowing s. from the Pindus range to the Ionian Sea Il. 21.194.

div1.head: Ἀχελώϊος-2.
div1.p: An unknown river of Lydia Il. 24.616.
A river of the underworld Od. 10.513. See Κώκυτος.

(ἀγαυός, ἀμύμων, ἄναξ, Ἀρήϊος, δαΐφρων, διίφιλος, δῖος, θεῖος, θεοείκελος, θεοῖς ἐπιείκελος, θυμολέων, κλυτός, καρτερός, κυδάλιμος, μεγάθυμος, μέγα φέρτατος Ἀχαιῶν, ἄβριμος, ὀλοός, ὄρχαμος ἀνδρῶν, πελώριος, ποδάρκης, πόδας ταχύς?̔ὠκύς̓, ποδώκης, ποιμὴν λαῶν, πτολίπορθος, ῥηξήνωρ, ταχύς, ὑπέρθυμος, φαίδιμος, ὠκύς). Patr. Πηλεΐδης, Πηλεΐων, Πηληϊάδης, Αἰακίδης. Son of Peleus and Thetis and father of Neoptolemus. Leader of the Myrmidons and the great bulwark of the Greeks. Calls an assembly Il. 1.54, addresses Agamemnon 59, and Calchas 85, A. again 122, abuses A. 149, questions with himself whether to slay A. 188, Athene appears 194, and restrains him 207, he abuses A. again 225, his final speech to A. 293, retires to his ships from the fight 306; yields Briseis to the heralds of Agamemnon Il. 1.337, calls to his mother 352, she promises her intercession with Zeus 414; he receives the embassy Il. 9.193, his speech 308, he rejects finally the proposals 644; Patroclus approaches him Il. 16.2, and asks to be sent to the fight 21, Achilles accedes 49, and marshals the Myrmidons 155, his prayer to Zeus 233; he hears from Antilochus of the death of Patroclus Il. 18.18, his mother comes to him 70, and promises armour from Hephaestus 136; Iris urges him to come to the rescue of the corpse of Patroclus Il. 18.170, Athene kindles fire from his head 203, he shouts from the ditch 215, and accompanies the rescued corpse 234, his lament 316; his mother brings the divine armour Il. 19.8, he rouses the host 40, he renounces his wrath 146; his further lament Il. 19.315; he assumes the armour Il. 19.367, and addresses his horses 400; he and Aeneas meet in fight Od. 3.158, Poseidon withdraws Aeneas 325; Achilles and Hector meet Od. 3.422, Apollo withdraws Η. 443, Achilles does much execution 455; he drives a part of the foe into the Xanthus-1 Il. 21.7, he encounters Lycaon-2 34, and slays him 116, after doing much execution is addressed by the river 214, the river rises upon him 240, he is saved by the fire of Hephaestus 342; Agenor stands up to him 550, is withdrawn by Apollo 596, Apollo in his guise beguiles Achilles to a vain pursuit 599; he approaches the city Il. 22.21, Hector awaits him 35, but flees before him and is chased thrice round the walls 136, they fight 273, Achilles slays Η. 326, and drags the corpse to the ships 395; the shade of Patroclus appears to him Il. 23.65, he places his lock dedicated to the Spercheius in the hands of P.'s corpse 140, he summons the winds to fan the pyre 192; he sets the prizes for the funeral games Il. 23.262; Thetis sent by Zeus persuades him to accept ransom for Hector's corpse from Priam Il. 24.128, he hearkens to P.'s appeal 483, he gives directions for releasing the corpse 572; etc.: Od. 3.106, 109, 189, Od. 4.5; his strife with Odysseus Od. 8.75; O. encounters him in the Shades Od. 11.467, 478, 482, 486, his lament to Odysseus 488; Od. 11.546, 557; in the second νέκυια 15, 36, 72, 76, 94.
A Nereid Il. 18.46.
(μεγάθυμος). A Myrmidon, son of Chalcon. S. Glaucus-2 Il. 16.594.
One of the horses of Achilles, by Zephyrus out of Podarge Il. 16.149, Il. 19.400.
(αἰπεῖα). A hill in the Trojan plain Il. 2.813. So called by mortals; called by the gods (Il. 2.814) the grave-mound of Myrine.

(ἀμύμων, δαΐφρων). Son of Glaucus-1 and father of Isandrus, Hippolochus-1 and Laodameia. His beauty and valour Il. 7.155; repulsed the love of Anteia, wife of Proetus Il. 7.160, by her contrivance sent by P. to P.'s father-in-law the king of Lycia with a secret message importing his death 163, the dangerous tasks set him 178, and the ambush laid for him 187, received the king's daughter to wife and half of the kingdom 191, his children 196, his fate 200; had been entertained by Oeneus Il. 7.216, 220.
A Locrian town Il. 2.532.

div1.head: Βίας-1
div1.p: G. (ποιμὴν λαῶν). Il. 4.296.

div1.head: Βίας-3
div1.p: T. Father of Laogonus-2 and Dardanus-2 Od. 3.460.
T (ποιμὴν λαῶν). With his comrade Oileus-2 s. Agamemnon Il. 11.92.
A Locrian river Il. 2.533.
Patr. of Eteoneus Od. 4.31, Od. 15.95, 140.
A town of the realm of Eumelus lying on the Boebean Lake (see next) Il. 2.712.
λίμνη. A lake lying w. of and under the range of Pelion and Ossa Il. 2.711.
Boeotian Il. 14.476, Il. 17.597.
G. The Boeotians. Their leaders Il. 2.494, Il. 15.330; Il. 2.510, 526, Il. 5.710, Il. 13.685, 700.
(εὖ ναιόμενον). A town of uncertain site. The original home of Epeigeus Il. 16.572.
Patr. of Sphelus Il. 15.338.
(ἀμύμων). Bastard son of Laomedon and father by Abarbaree of Aesepus-2 and Pedasus-3 (twins) Il. 7.22, 23.
(πολύπυρον). A region of Elis Il. 2.615, Il. 11.756, 760; the scene of the funeral of Amarynceus Il. 23.631.
(ὀψὲ δύων). See Lexicon.
See Αἰγαίων.
Father of next Il. 1.392, Il. 9.132, 274.

(ἠΰκομος, ἰκέλη Ἀφροδίτῃ, καλλιπάρῃος). Patr. fr. prec. Captured by Achilles at Lyrnessus Il. 2.689; Il. 1.184; taken from A. by Agamemnon's heralds Il. 1.323, 336, 346, Il. 9.106; restored Il. 19.246, 261; her lament over Patroclus Il. 19.282; Il. 24.676.
A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.583.

div1.head: Βῶρος-1.
div1.p: A Maeonian (Μῄων), father of Phaestus Il. 5.44.

div1.head: Βῶρος-2.
div1.p: Son of Perieres, husband of Polydore and nominal father of Menesthius-2 Il. 16.177.
ΓαιήϊοςΓῆ. See Lexicon.
(ἀγακλειτή). A Nereid Il. 18.45.
(αντίθεος). Son of Tros-1. Carried off by the gods to be their cup-bearer Il. 5.266, Od. 3.232.
A peak of Mt. Ida Il. 8.48, Il. 14.292, 352, Il. 15.152.
The s. w. point of Euboea Od. 3.177.

Adj. from (app.) the name of an unknown place, said to have been in Elis and to have sheltered Nestor when an exile from Pylus. Of Nestor Il. 2.336, Il. 4.317, Il. 6.170, Il. 11.516, Il. 14.52, Il. 15.370, etc. : Od. 3.68, 102, 210, Od. 4.161, etc.
(ἄγρια φῦλα, ὑπέρθυμοι). A gigantic and savage race, represented (Od. 6.206) as being with the Cyclopes near the gods. Destroyed under Eurymedon-3 Od. 6.59; Od. 10.120.
A Nereid Il. 18.39.

div1.head: Γλαῦκος-1
div1.p: Son of Sisyphus, father of Bellerophon and grandfather of Hippolochus-1 Il. 7.154, 155.

div1.head: Γλαῦκος-2
div1.p: (ἀμύμων, κρατερός, ποιμήν λαῶν, φαίδιμος). Son of Hippolochus-1. Comrade of Sarpedon and a leader of the Lycians Il. 2.876; fights Diomedes Il. 7.119, they exchange arms 234; Il. 6.13, Il. 12.102, 309, 310, 329; wounded by Teucrus Il. 12.387; 392; Il. 14.426; the wounded Sarpedon appeals to him Il. 16.492, 508, he cries to Apollo 514, and is cured 527, 530; slays Bathyclees Il. 16.593, 597; reproves Hector Il. 17.140, 170; Il. 17.216.
A town of the realm of Eumelus, prob. lying by the Boebean Lake Il. 2.712.
A Boeotian town Il. 2.504.
(αἰπεινή). A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.573.
Adj. fr. Γοργώ Il. 5.741: Od. 11.634.
(ἀμύμων, ἐΰς). Son of Priam by Castianeira. S. Teucrus Il. 8.302.
(βλοσυρῶπις). A frightful phantom Il. 8.349, Il. 11.36.
(τειχιόεσσα). A city of Crete Il. 2.646 : part of the fleet of Menelaus wrecked near it Od. 3.294.
G. Leader of the Enienes and Peraebians Il. 2.748.
A Boeotian town Il. 2.498.
A river of the Troad west of the Aesepus-1 Il. 12.21.
λίμνη. A lake to the n. of Sardis. To Talaemenes bore Mesthles and Antiphus-2 Il. 2.865, Od. 3.391.
A rock of unknown site on which Aias-2 was destroyed by Poseidon Od. 4.500.
Adj. fr. prec. Od. 4.507.
Patr. of Hyrtius Il. 14.512.
A town of Thessaly. Its men led by Polypoetes and Leonteus Il. 2.738.
Made Ariadne's dancing - place Il. 18.592.
T. S. Teucrus Il. 8.275.
T. S. Polypoetes Il. 12.183.

div1.head: Δαμαστορίδης-1.
div1.p: Patr. of Tlepolemus-2 Il. 16.416.
(καλλίσφυρος.) Patr. Ἀκρισιώνη. Mother of Perseus-1 by Zeus Il. 14.319.
(αἰχμηταί, θεράποντες Ἄρηος, ἴφθιμοι, ταχύπωλοι, φιλοπτόλεμοι.)

div2.p: The Greek race in gen. (Ἀχαιός (2) (b) (a)) Od. 4.725, 815.

div1.p: Patr. fr. Δάρδανος-1. Of Priam (descendant of D.) Il. 3.303, Il. 5.159, Il. 6.366, Il. 13.376, Il. 21.34, Il. 22.352, Il. 24.171, 354, 629, 631.
Similarly of Ilus-1 (descendant) Il. 11.166, 372.
A district occupying the middle valley of the Scamander. Peopled by Dardanus-1 Od. 3.216.
Adj. fr. prec.

div2.p: πύλαι Δαρδάνιαι, one of the gates of Troy, not identified Il. 5.789, Il. 22.194, 413.
In pl. ͂ Δάρδανοι (see Δάρδανος-3 (2)). Aeneas their leader Il. 2.819.

div1.p: Fem. adj. In pl., the Dardanian women (βαθύκολποι) Il. 18.122, 339.
Patr. fr. next. In pl., Dardanians Il. 6.414, Il. 8.154.

div1.head: Δάρδανος-1.
div1.p: Son of Zeus, father of Erichthonius, grandfather of Tros-1 and great-grandfather of Ilus-1 Od. 3.215, 219; the favourite child of Zeus Od. 3.304.

div1.head: Δάρδανος-2
div1.p: Τ. Son of Bias-3. S. Achilles Od. 3.460.

div2.p: Dardanian Il. 2.701, Il. 16.807.
In pl., Δάρδανοι Τ (ἀγχιμαχηταί), the men of Dardania Il. 3.456, Il. 6.348, 368, Il. 8.173, 497, Il. 11.286, Il. 13.150, Il. 15.425, 486, Il. 17.184.

div1.p: (ἀφνειὸς ἀμύμων). Priest of Hephaestus, app. at Troy. Father of Phegeus and Idaeus-2 Il. 5.9, 27.
A town of Phocis Il. 2.520.
A Nereid Il. 18.44.
Patr. of Iphinous Il. 6.15.
Patr. fr. next. Of Idomeneus Il. 12.117, Il. 13.307, Il. 17.608.

div1.head: Δευκαλίων-1
div1.p: (ἁμύμων, μεγάθυμος). Son of Minos and father of Idomeneus Il. 13.451, 452 : in Odysseus's tale to Penelope he says that he was D. 's son Od. 19.180, 181.

div1.head: Δευκαλίων-2
div1.p: T. S. Achilles Od. 3.478.
T. Patr. Περγασίδης.. A comrade of Aeneas. S. Agamemnon Il. 5.534.
T (ἀμύμων). S. Odysseus Il. 11.420.
G. S. Paris Il. 15.341.
Companion of Sthenelus-1 Il. 5.325.

(θεοειδής, θεοείκελος). Patr. Πριαμίδης. Son of Priam and Hecabe Il. 12.94, Il. 13.156, 162, 258, 402, 413, 446, 455, 490, 517, 527, 758, 770, 781; Athene takes his form in approaching Hector in
his last fight Il. 22.277; Il. 22.233, 294, 298, Il. 24.251: accompanied Helen when she visited the Trojan horse Od. 4.276; when the city was taken Odysseus and Menelaus proceeded to his house Od. 8.517.
The Aegean island, sacred to Apollo Od. 7.162.

(ἄνασσα, ἐϋπλόκαμος, καλλιπλόκαμος, ξανθή). Daughter of Cronus and Rhea, sister of Zeus, Hades, Poseidon and Here, and mother by Zeus of Persephoneia. The corn-goddess (Il. 5.500, Il. 13.322, Il. 21.76).
Her τέμενος at Pyrasus-1 Il. 2.696; the love of Zeus for her Il. 14.326; her love for Iasion Od. 5.125.
(θεῖος (έρος) ἀοιδός). The Phaeacian bard Od. 8.44, 106, 254, 262; his tale of Ares and Aphrodite Od. 8.266; Od. 8.472, 478, 483, 486, 487, 537, Od. 13.28.
Bastard son of Priam. S. Odysseus Il. 4.499.
T (ἐσθλὸς ἀλεξητὴρ μάχης). Son of Antenor. S. Achilles Od. 3.395.
A suitor Od. 22.242; S. Odysseus Od. 22.266.
T (ἠΰς τε μέγας τε). Patr. Φιλητορίδης. S. Achilles Od. 3.457.
(ἀμφιρύτη). A small island (now Standia) off the n. coast of Crete Od. 11.325.
Also identified with Naxos.
See Ζεύς.
(μεγάθυμος). Son of Ortilochus-3 and father of Crethon and Ortilochus-4; dwelt at Pherae-2 Il. 5.542, 547, 548: Telemachus and Peisistratus pass the night in his house Od. 3.488, Od. 15.186.
(καλλιπάρἡος). Daughter of Phorbas-1. Captured by Achilles at Lesbos Il. 9.665.

(ἀγαθός, Αἰτωλός (see Οἰνεύς), ἄλκιμος, Ἀρήϊος, ἄριστος Ἀχαιῶν, βοήν ἀγαθός, δαΐφρων, δῖος, δουρικλειτός, δουρικλυτός, ἱππόδαμος, καρτερόθυμος, κρατερός, μεγάθυμος, μενοπτόλεμος, ποιμὴν λαῶν, ὑπέρθυμος). Patr. Τυδεΐδης. Son of Tydeus and husband of Aegialeia (who was his aunt, her sister (Deipyle) being the wife of Tydeus. See Adrestus-1). Leader of the men owning his sway in Argos-1 (1) Il. 2.563, 567; visited by Agamemnon in his inspection Il. 4.365, reproves Sthenelus-1 411; his feats under Athene's protection Il. 5.1, wounded by Pandarus 95, P. aims at him again 280, he slays Ρ. 290, attacks and wounds Aphrodite 330, 335, attacks Aeneas 432, but retires before Apollo 443, Ares attacks him 849, he wounds Ares and drives him off 855; fights Glaucus-2 Il. 7.119, they exchange arms 235; accepts Hector's challenge but does not get the lot Il. 6.163; speaks against accepting the offer of the Trojan herald Il. 6.399; comes to the rescue of Nestor Il. 8.91, he and N. are put to flight by a thunderbolt from Zeus 130; declares in the Assembly that he will fight to the end Il. 9.31; his speech on the announcement by Odysseus of the result of the embassy Il. 9.697; wakened by Agamemnon Il. 10.150, offers to penetrate the hostile lines 219, sets out with Odysseus 272, they encounter and capture and slay Dolon 339, they do execution and slay Rhesus-1 482, and return safely 540; strikes Hector Il. 11.349, is wounded by Paris 369; relates his family history Il. 14.110; takes part in the chariot-race Il. 23.290, is disabled by Apollo 383, but comes in first 499, meets Aias-1 in the fight in armour 812; etc.: his return from Troy Od. 3.167, 181; in ambush in the Trojan horse Od. 4.280.
(αἰπὺ πτολίεθρον). A town of Euboea Il. 2.538.
Διώνυσος (χάρμα βροτοῖσιν). Son of Zeus and Semele (Il. 14.325). He and his attendants scattered by Lycourgus-1 Il. 7.132, 135: his part in the death of Ariadne Od. 11.325; Od. 24.74.
(ἀγαυός). A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.251.
etc. Genit., etc., of Ζεύς.
(δῖα θεάων). Mother by Zeus of Aphrodite Il. 5.370, 381.

div1.head: Διώρης-1
div1.p: (κρατερός). Patr. Ἀμαρυγκεΐδης. Son of Amarynceus and a leader of the Epeians Il. 2.622; s. Peiroos Il. 4.517.

div1.head: Διώρης.-2.
div1.p: Father of Automedon Il. 17.429, 474.
Patr. Ἰασίδης-2. Odysseus's name for an alleged king of Cyprus Od. 17.443.

div1.head: Δολίος-1
div1.p: (γέρων). A bondman of Penelope given to her by her father and in charge of the garden and orchard Od. 4.735, Od. 24.222; his six sons Od. 24.387, 497; he and his sons welcome Odysseus Od. 24.397, 409, 411; a son reports the approach of the Ithacans Od. 24.492, D. arms 498.

div1.head: Δολίος-2.
div1.p: Father of Melanthius-1 Od. 17.212, Od. 22.159, and Melantho Od. 18.322.
A people on the w. borders of the realm of Peleus Il. 9.484.
(ὑπέρθυμος). Priest of the Scamander and father of Hypsenor-1 Il. 5.77.

div1.head: Δόλοψ-1
div1.p: G. Patr. Κλυτίδης-1. S. Hector Il. 11.302.

div1.head: Δόλοψ-2
div1.p: T. (αἰχμῆς ἐΰ εἰδώς). Patr. Λαμπετίδης. S. Menelaus Il. 15.525, 540, 555.
(πολύχρυσος πολύχαλκος). Son of Eumedes. Described Il. 10.314; undertakes to Hector to penetrate the Greek lines Il. 10.319, captured by Diomedes 369, gives information 412, s. Δ. 454; etc.
Patr. Πριαμίδης. Bastard son of Priam. S. Aias-1 Il. 11.489.
Adj. fr. next. Of Nisus Od. 18.127.
Of Amphinomus Od. 18.395.
Of Moulius-4 Od. 18.424.
(ποιῆεν, πολύπυρον). An island not identified the men from which were led by Meges Il. 2.625.
Δουλίχιόνδε [-δε], to D. Il. 2.629: Od. 14.397.
In Od. associated with Same, Zacynthus and Ithaca Od. 1.246, Od. 9.24, Od. 16.123, 247, Od. 19.131.
Its king Acastus Od. 14.335.
The home of Amphinomus Od. 16.396.
In Odysseus's tale to Eumaeus Od. 14.335, to Penelope Od. 19.292.
A leader of the Epeians Il. 13.692.
T. S. Euryalus-1 Il. 7.20.

div1.head: Δρύας-1
div1.p: (ποιμὴν λαῶν). A warrior of Nestor's youth Il. 1.263.

div1.head: Δρύας-2.
div1.p: Father of Lycourgus-1 Il. 7.130.
T. S. Achilles Od. 3.455.

div1.head: Δύμας-1.
div1.p: Father of Asius-1 and Hecabe Il. 16.718.

div1.head: Δύμας-2
div1.p: (ναυσικλειτός). Athene takes the form of his daughter in Nausicaa's dream Od. 7.22.
A Nereid Il. 18.43.
See Lexicon.
Adj. fr. next. Of Zeus Il. 16.233.

(δυσχείμερος). In Epeirus with an oracle of Zeus (but (Il. 2.750) the Thessalian Enienes and Peraebians are said to have dwelt about it). The prayer of Achilles to Zeus of Dodona Il. 16.234: its oak and Odysseus's consultation Od. 14.327, Od. 19.296.
(τριχάϊκες). In Odysseus's tale to Penelope one of the five divisions of the inhabitants of Crete Od. 19.177.
A town of Pylus where the Muses took from Thamyris his power of song Il. 2.594.
A Nereid Il. 18.45.
A Nereid Il. 18.43.
Daughter of Proteus. Encounters Menelaus in Pharos Od. 4.366, her advice to him 371, how he carried it out 431.
See Lexicon.
A Boeotian town Il. 2.499.
A town of Euboea Il. 2.537.

(ἠπιόδωρος). Daughter of Dymas-1, full sister of Asius-1 and wife of Priam (for her children see under Πρίαμος) Il. 7.251; collects the aged women to pray to Athene Il. 7.286, her gift to Α. 288, 293; Il. 7.451, Il. 16.718; vainly beseeches Hector to take refuge from Achilles Il. 22.79; Il. 22.234; she sees H. 's corpse being dragged away Il. 22.405, her lament 430; summoned by Priam Il. 24.193, she tries to dissuade him from going to the ships 200, she speeds him on his way 283; her lament over Hector's ransomed, corpse Il. 24.747.
(ἐϋπλόκαμος). Daughter of Arsinous. Given to Nestor when Tenedos was sacked. Doing service in N. 's hut Il. 11.624, Il. 14.6.
Adj. fr. Ἕκτωρ. Of or pertaining to Hector Il. 2.416, Il. 10.46, Il. 24.276, 579.
Patr. fr. next. Of Astyanax Il. 7.401.

(ἀνδροφόνος, βοὴν ἀγαθός, βροτολοιγῷ ἶσος Ἄρηϊ, Διὶ μῆτιν ἀτάλαντος, διίφιλος, δῖος, θοῷ ἀτάλαντος Ἄρηϊ, θρασύς, ἱππόδαμος, κλυτός,?̔μέγας̓ κορυθαίολος, κρατερὸς μήστωρ φόβοιο, μεγάθυμος, μέγας, ὄβριμος, πελώριος, ποιμὴν λαῶν, φαίδιμος, φλογὶ εἴκελος ἀλκήν, χαλκοκορυστής). Patr. Πριαμίδης. Son of Priam and Hecabe and father of Astyanax. The leader of the Trojans Il. 2.816; reproaches Paris for shrinking from Menelaus Il. 3.38, proposes a duel between P. and Il. 12.86; Sarpedon reproaches him for neglecting the allies Il. 5.471, he leads the fight 590, the wounded Sarpedon appeals to him in vain 684, he does much execution 703; Helenus-1 advises him to retire to the city and collect the aged women to pray to Athene Il. 7.77, he goes 116, he encounters the Trojan wives 237, and his mother, whom he charges to collect the aged women 251, he proceeds to the house of Paris and reproaches him 313, his conversation with Helen 343, he proceeds to his own house but does not find Andromache there 370, he encounters her with Astyanax on his way back 392, their conversation 405, he leaves her 494, and encounters Paris returning also to the field 514, they join in the fight Il. 6.1; he proposes a duel between himself and a Greek champion Il. 6.67, Aias-1 meets him 206, the fight broken off by the heralds 279, H. and A. exchange arms 303; H. comes to attack Nestor Il. 8.87, who is rescued by Diomedes 99; H. urges the Trojans on Il. 8.173, and addresses his horses 185, he hems in the Greeks 213, disables Teucrus 320, drives the Greeks to the ships 337; after sunset summons an assembly Il. 8.485, advises his people to bivouac on the field 497; he induces Dolon to go as a scout to the ships Il. 10.303, 314; in the morning leads his people to the fight Il. 11.56, Zeus withdraws him 163, and sends Iris to advise him to refrain while Agamemnon is in the field 186, when A. is disabled leads his people on 284, is struck by Diomedes and retires 349, but with Cebriones renews the fight 521, Il. 12.40; his horses refuse the ditch Il. 12.50, on the advice of Poulydamas advances on foot 80, an unfavourable omen 200 does not deter him 231, 251, he leads an attack on the wall 438, and breaks down the gate with a stone 445; he leads the fight within the wall Il. 13.136, Il. 14.388, Aias-1 disables him with a stone Il. 14.409; Apollo sent by Zeus restores his strength and he renews the fight Il. 15.244, 262, lays hold of the ship of Protesilaus 704, and calls for fire 718; the ship set on fire Il. 16.122; after he has retreated to the Scaean gate Apollo in the guise of Asius-1 urges him back to the fight Il. 16.721, he gives the final blow to Patroclus 818, urged by Apollo in the guise of Mentes-1 he joins the fight round the corpse of P. Il. 17.75, he strips the corpse 122, 125, and assumes the armour 188, Apollo in the guise of Phaenops-3 urges him on 582; the corpse is rescued by the Greeks Il. 18.231; he spurns the advice of Poulydamas to retire to the city Il. 18.285; on the advice of Apollo shrinks from Achilles Od. 3.379, but advances to meet him on seeing the wounded Polydorus-1 419, Apollo snatches H. away 443; he awaits Achilles under the walls in spite of the entreaty of his father Il. 22.35, and of his mother 79, he flees before Α. 136, Athene in the guise of Deiphobus beguiles him 226, Achilles wounds him fatally 326, his dying speech 356; A. drags his corpse to the ships Il. 22.395; he drags the corpse thrice daily round the grave-mound of Patroclus Il. 24.14; Priam bears the ransomed corpse to the city Il. 24.689, the lament of Andromache 725, of Hecabe 748, of Helen 762, the funeral 785; etc.
T. S. Patroclus Il. 16.696.

div1.head: Ἔλατος-1
div1.p: T. S. Agamemnon Il. 7.33.

div1.head: Ἔλατος-2.
div1.p: A suitor. S. Eumaeus Od. 22.267.
A Phaeacian Od. 8.111, 129.

(Ἀργείη, δῖα γυναικῶν, Διὸς ἐκγεγαυῖ, εὐπατέρεια, ἠΰκομος, καλλίκομος, καλλιπάρῃος, κούρη Διός, λευκώλενος, ῥιγεδανή, τανύπεπλος). Daughter of Leda by Zeus (nominally by Tyndareus), wife of Menelaus (but carried off by Paris) and mother by M. of Hermione-1. Summoned by Iris to the walls to view the duel between Paris and Menelaus Il. 3.121, the Trojan elders see her and what they said 146, she names the Greek leaders to Priam 161, cannot see her brothers Castor-1 and Polydeuces 234; summoned by Aphrodite to Paris Il. 3.383; Hector finds her with P. Il. 7.323, her conversation with Η. 343; her lament over H. Il. 24.761; etc.: Hermione-1 her only child Od. 4.12; her conversation at Sparta with Menelaus and Peisistratus Od. 4.121, her soothing drug 219, she tells how Odysseus came disguised to Troy 235; her gift to Telemachus on his departure Od. 15.100, her speech to him 123; Penelope on her infatuation Od. 23.218; etc.

div1.head: Ἕλενος-1
div1.p: (ἄναξ). Patr. Πριαμίδης. Son of Priam and Hecabe. Skilled in auguries Il. 7.76; Il. 6.44 Il. 12.94, Il. 13.576, 582, 758, 770, 781, Il. 24.249.

div1.head: Ἕλενος-2
div1.p: G. Patr. Οἰνοπίδης. S. Hector Il. 5.707.
(κρείων, ὄζος Ἄρηος). Patr. Χαλκωδοντιάδης. Leader of the Abantes Il. 2.540; s. Agenor Il. 4.463.
A Boeotian town Il. 2.500, Il. 10.266.
T (κρείων). Patr. Ἀντηνορίδης. Son of Antenor and husband of Laodice-1 Il. 3.123.
(εὐρεῖα). A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.575; a seat of the worship of Poseidon Il. 8.203.
Adj. fr. prec. Od. 3.404.
(εὐρύχορος, καλλιγύναιξ).

div2.p: Part of the realm of Peleus, the valley of the Spercheius Il. 2.683, Il. 9.395, 447, 478, Il. 16.595: Od. 11.496.
Of northern in contrast to southern Greece, in phrase καθ̓?̔ἀν̓ Ἑλλάδα καὶ μέσον Ἄργος. See Argos-1 (3).

div1.p: The men of prec. (1). Applied with Μυρμιδόνες and Ἀχαιοί to the followers of Achilles Il. 2.684.
(ἀγάρροος, ἀπείρων, ἰχθυόεις, πλατύς). The Hellespont Il. 2.845, Il. 6.86, Il. 9.360, Il. 12.30, Il. 15.233, Il. 17.432, Il. 18.150, Il. 23.2, Il. 24.346, 545 : Od. 24.82.
See Σελλοί.

div1.head: Ἕλος-1
div1.p: (ἔφαλον πτολίεθρον). A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.584.

div1.head: Ἕλος-2.
div1.p: A town of Pylus Il. 2.594.
A comrade of Odysseus in his ship. Killed by mishap at Circe's house Od. 10.552; his shade begs for funeral rites Od. 11.51, 57; the funeral Od. 12.10.
Prob. a Paphlagonian port Il. 2.852.
G. A people of n. Thessaly led by Gouneus Il. 2.749.
(θεῖος). A river of Thessaly rising in Mt. Othrys and flowing into the Peneius Od. 11.238, 240.
(ἠνεμόεσσα). A town of Arcadia Il. 2.606.

div1.head: Ἔννομος-1
div1.p: (οἰωνιστής). A leader of the Mysians Il. 2.858, Il. 17.218. S. Achilles Il. 2.860.

div1.head: Ἔννομος-2
div1.p: T. S. Odysseus Il. 11.422.
A town of Pylus Il. 9.150, 292.
(ἀνδρειφόντης, κορυθάϊξ πτολεμιστής). A name of Ares Il. 2.651, Il. 6.166, Il. 8.264, Il. 13.519, Il. 17.259, Od. 3.69, Il. 22.132.
An epithet of A. Il. 17.211.
War or battle personified Il. 18.309.
King of Scyrus-2 Il. 9.668.
(πότνια, πτολίπορθος). A female counterpart of Ares (Euyalius) Il. 5.333, 592.
A warrior of Nestor's youth Il. 1.264.
T. S. Patroclus Il. 16.415.
(δῖος). A Myrmidon, son of Agaclees Il. 16.571. Came as a suppliant to Peleus and Thetis Il. 16.573; s. Hector Il. 16.577.
G (μεγάθυμοι, φαιδιμόεντες, χαλκοχίτωνες). The people of Elis Il. 2.619, Il. 4.537, Il. 11.688, 694, 732, 737, 744, Il. 13.686, 691, Il. 15.519, Il. 23.630, 632: Od. 13.275, Od. 15.298, Od. 24.431.
(δῖος, ἠύς τε μέγας τε, μεγάθυμος). Son of Panopeus-2. Wins the boxing-match Il. 23.665, 689, 694; is last in putting the weight Il. 23.838, 839: made the Trojan horse Od. 8.493, Od. 11.523.
The name assumed by Odysseus in his tale to Laertes Od. 24.306.
(ἀμπελόεις). A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.561.
The later Iocaste (καλή). Mother and wife of Oedipodes (Oedipus). Her incestuous marriage and suicide Od. 11.271.
T (μεγάθυμος). S. Aias-1 Il. 12.379.

div1.head: Ἐπίστροφος-1
div1.p: Son of Iphitus-1. With his brother Schedius-1 leader of the men of Phocis Il. 2.517.

div1.head: Ἐπίστροφος-2
div1.p: (ἐγχεσίμωρος). Son of Euenus and brother of Munes Il. 2.692.

div1.head: Ἐπίστροφος-3.
div1.p: A leader of the Halizonians Il. 2.856.
T. S. Patroclus Il. 16.695.
An unknown river Il. 12.20.
Genit. Ἐρέβευς Il. 8.368: Od. 11.37. Abl. Ἐρέβεσφιν Il. 9.572. The underworld, the realm of Hades Il. 8.368, Il. 9.572, Il. 16.327: Od. 10.528, Od. 11.37, 564, Od. 12.81.
Ἔρεβόσδε [-δε], to E. Od. 20.356.
A people, otherwise unknown, visited by Menelaus Od. 4.84.
A Phaeacian Od. 8.112.
(δῖος, ἰσόθεος). An Arcadian slain in the armour of Areithous-1 (given to him by Lycourgus-2 (Il. 6.137, 149)) by Nestor in his youth Il. 4.319, Il. 6.136, 154.
(μεγαλήτωρ). An autochthonous hero of Athens Il. 2.547: Od. 6.81.
See Lexicon.
See ἔρις (4) in Lexicon.
(στυγερή). Wife of Amphiaraus. Bribed by a golden necklace persuaded A. to take part in the expedition of the Seven against Thebes Od. 11.326, Od. 15.247.

Son of Dardanus-1, father of
Tros-1, and grandfather of Ilus-1, Assaracus and Ganymedes Od. 3.219, 230.
Wife of Oileus-1, mother of Aias-2 and stepmother of Medon-1 Il. 13.697, Il. 15.336.
λόφος. An eminence above the city of Ithaca Il. 16.471.

Ἑρμῆς Od. 3.72 : Od. 5.54, Od. 8.334, Od. 14.435, Od. 24.1. Dat. Ἑρμέᾳ Il. 5.390 (ἀκάκητα, ἄναξ, ἀργεϊφόντης, διάκτορος?̔ἀ?̓, ἐΰσκοπος ἀ., κρατὺς ἀ., δώτωρ ἑάων, ἐριούνης, ἐριούνιος, Κυλλήνιος, σῶκος, χρυσόρραπις). Son of Zeus and Maia, and father of Eudorus by Polymele. The sceptre given by him to Pelops Il. 2.104; rescues Ares from bonds Il. 5.390; sent by Zeus to conduct Priam to the ships Il. 24.334, rouses P. and urges him to return 679; etc. : sent by Z. to bid Calypso let Odysseus go Od. 5.28, his conversation with Il. 14.85; meets Ο. on his way to Circe's house Od. 10.277; conducts the souls of the suitors to the Shades Od. 24.1; etc.

div1.head: Ἑρμιόνη-1
div1.p: (ἐρατεινή). Only child of Menelaus and Helen Od. 4.14. Her marriage to Neoptolemus Od. 4.5.

div1.head: Ἑρμιόνη-2.
div1.p: A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.560.
(δινήεις). A river flowing near Sardis and into the Aegean Od. 3.392.
(ὑψηλοί). Prob. cliffs bordering Cape Carambis in Paphlagonia Il. 2.855.
A Boeotian town Il. 2.499.
T. S. Patroclus Il. 16.411.
A mountain range in n. -w. Peloponnesus Od. 7.103.

div1.head: Ἐρύμας-1
div1.p: T. S. Idomeneus Il. 16.345.

div1.head: Ἐρύμας-2
div1.p: T. S. Patroclus Il. 16.415.
βίη Ἐτεοκλῆς. King of Thebes-1, son of Oedipodes and Epicaste Il. 4.386.
(μεγαλήτορες). Etymologically, ‘the true Cretans.’ In Odysseus's tale to Penelope applied to one of the five divisions of the inhabitants of Crete Od. 19.176.
(κρείων). Patr. Βοηθοΐδης. θεράπων of Menelaus at Sparta Od. 4.22, 31, Od. 15.95.:
(πολύκνημος). A Boeotian town Il. 2.497.
Patr. fr. next. Of Eurypylus-2 Il. 5.76, Il. 11.810.
Father of Eurypylus-2 Il. 2.736, Il. 5.79, Il. 6.167, Il. 8.265, Il. 11.575.
Father of Maron Od. 9.197.
(ἱερή). The island Euboea Il. 2.535; the home of the Abantes Il. 2.536: Od. 3.174; Od. 6.321 (see Ῥαδάμανθυς, Τιτυός).
(ἀρήϊος, θείειν ταχὺς ἠδὲ μαχητής, παρθένιος). Son of Hermes and Polymele. A leader under Achilles Il. 16.179, 186.
Patr. of Marpessa Il. 9.557.
Patr. of Leocritus Od. 2.242, Od. 22.294.
(ἄναξ). Patr. Σεληπιάδης. Father of Munes and Epistrophus-2 Il. 2.693.
T S. Patroclus Il. 16.417.

(δῖος, ὄρχαμος ἀνδρῶν). Odysseus's swineherd (συβώτης, συφορβός, ὑφορβός). Son of Ctesius. Athene directs O. to go to his dwelling Od. 13.404; the dwelling described Od. 14.5, receives Ο. 29; O. tells him his tale Od. 14.192; he tells O. his tale Od. 15.403; receives Telemachus Od. 16.11; is dispatched to tell Penelope of T. 's safe arrival 130, returns 452; accompanies O. to the town Od. 17.200, they encounter Melantheus 212, they reach the city 260; he enters O.'s house first Od. 17.324; summons O. to Penelope Od. 17.551; leaves the house to return to his own Od. 17.604; returns to O. 's house Od. 20.162; sets down the bow etc. before the suitors for the contest Od. 21.80, O. tests him 188, he pledges himself to support Il. 15.203, O. reveals himself 207; he carries the bow to O. that O. may take part in the contest Od. 21.359; during the fight he and Philoetius seize Melantheus in the θάλαμος Od. 22.178, ranges himself by O. for the final fight 201, slays Elatus-2 267, is wounded by Ktesippus 279, slays Polybus-5 284; takes part in the slaying of the unfaithful maids Od. 22.454; accompanies O. to the country Od. 23.366; at Laertes) house when O. comes to it Od. 24.363, prepares to fight the oncoming suitors 497, but Athene stops the fight 528; etc.
(κῆρυξ θεῖος). Father of Dolon Il. 10.314, 412, 426.

(ἄναξ ἀνδρῶν, κρείων). Patr. Φηρητιάδης. Son of Admetus and Alcestis and husband of Iphthime. Leader of the men of Phe=rae, etc. Il. 2.714; his fine horses reared by Apollo Il. 2.764; takes part in the chariot-race Il. 23.289, his chariot disabled by Athene 391, comes in last 532, but is awarded an extra prize 558; etc.: married Iphthime Od. 4.798.
Patr. Ἰησονίδης Son of Ieson and Hypsipyle. Sent wine to the Greeks from Lemnos Il. 6.468; purchased Lycaon-2 Il. 21.41, Il. 23.747.
Father of Antinous Od. 1.383; leads a section of the Ithacans to attack Odysseus Od. 24.422, 465, 469, s. Laertes 523; etc.
A suitor. S. Telemachus Od. 22.267.

div1.head: Εὐρύαλος-1
div1.p: (ἰσόθεος φώς). Patr. Μηκιστηϊάδης. Son of Mecisteus-1 and companion of Diomedes Il. 2.565; slays Dresus, Opheltius-1, Aesepus-2 and Pedasus-3 Il. 7.20; beaten in boxing by Epeius Il. 23.677.

div1.head: Εὐρύαλος-2
div1.p: (βροτολοιγῷ ἶσος Ἄρηϊ). Patr. Ναυβολίδης-2. A Phaeacian. The fairest after Laodamas-2 Od. 8.115; Od. 8.127, 140; taunts Odysseus Od. 8.158, they are reconciled 396, 400.

div1.head: Εὐρυβάτης-1
div1.p: (ὀτρηρός). A herald of Agamemnon. Sent with Talthybius to bring away Briseis Il. 1.320.

div1.head: Εὐρυβάτης-2
div1.p: (Ἰθακήσιος). A herald who accompanied Odysseus to Troy Il. 2.184, Il. 9.170: Od. 19.247.

div1.head: Εὐρυδάμας-1
div1.p: (ὀνειροπόλος γέρων). Father of A bas and Polyidus-1 Il. 5.149.

div1.head: Εὐρυδάμας-2.
div1.p: A suitor. His gift to Penelope Od. 18.297; s. Odysseus Od. 22.283.
Daughter of Clymenus and wife of Nestor Od. 3.452.

(περίφρων, φίλη τροφός). Odysseus's nurse, daughter of Ops. Puts Telemachus to
bed Od. 1.429; in charge of the store-room Od. 2.347, T. bids her prepare provisions for his voyage 348; she encloses the maids while Odysseus and T. remove the arms Od. 19.15; washes O. Od. 19.357, recognizes his scar 392, 467; encloses the maids before the fight Od. 21.380; enumerates the unfaithful maids Od. 22.419; brings sulphur Od. 22.480; tells Penelope of O.'s return and the slaughter of the suitors Od. 23.1; etc.

(θεοειδής, μεγαλήτωρ). A comrade of Odysseus in his ship. Leads one half of the ship's company to Circe's house Od. 10.205, remains when the others enter 232, tells their fate 244, follows O. to the house 447; at the sacrifice on the borders of Ocean Od. 11.23; with Perimedes-2 binds O. more firmly at the Sirens' island Od. 12.195; insists on landing at the island of the oxen of the Sun Od. 12.278; etc.

(θεοειδής, πεπνυμένος). Son of Polybus-2. With Antinous leader of the suitors. In the Ithacan assembly threatens Halitherses Od. 2.177; Penelope urged to marry him Od. 15.17; falsely comforts P. Od. 16.434; his gift to P. Od. 18.295; abuses the disguised Odysseus Od. 18.349, throws a stool at him 387; cannot string the bow Od. 21.245; addresses O. on the slaying of Antinous Od. 22.44; heads the suitors Od. 22.69, s. Ο. 81; etc.
Chamber-maid of Alcinous Od. 6.8.

div1.head: Εὐρυμέδων-1
div1.p: Son of Ptolemaeus and chariot-driver of Agamemnon Il. 4.228.

div1.head: Εὐρυμέδων-2
div1.p: (ἀγαπήνωρ). Chariot-driver of Nestor Il. 8.114, Il. 11.620.

div1.head: Εὐρυμέδων-3
div1.p: (υεγαλήτωρ). King of the Gigantes and father of Periboea-2 Od. 6.58.
Patr. of Telemus Od. 9.509.

div1.head: Εὐρυνόμη-1.
div1.p: Daughter of Oceanus. She and Thetis kept Hephaestus secretly when he was rejected by Hera Il. 18.398, 399, 405.

div1.head: Εὐρυνόμη-2
div1.p: (θαλαμηπόλος, ταμίη). Odysseus's house-keeper Od. 17.495, Od. 18.164, 169, 178, Od. 19.96, 97, Od. 20.4, Od. 23.154, 289, 293.
A suitor, son of Aegyptius-1 Od. 2.22, Od. 22.242.

div1.head: Εὐρύπυλος-1.
div1.p: His city, i.e. Cos Il. 2.677.

div1.head: Εὐρύπυλος-2
div1.p: (ἀγαπήνωρ, ἀγλαός, διογενής). Patr. Εὐαιμονίδης. Son of Euaemon and leader of the men of Ormenium, etc. Il. 2.736; slays Hypsenor-1 Il. 5.76, 79, and Melanthius-2 Il. 7.36; accepts Hector's challenge but does not get the lot Il. 6.167; Il. 8.265; comes to the rescue of Aias-1 and slays Apisaon-1 Il. 11.576, 580; wounded by Paris Il. 11.583, 592, 662, 809, 819, 822, Il. 16.27; is tended by Patroclus Il. 11.838, Il. 12.2, Il. 15.392, 399.

div1.head: Εὐρύπυλος-3.
div1.p: Patr. Τηλεφίδης. Son of Telephus by Astyoche, daughter of Priam. S. Neoptolemus, his mother having been bribed by Priam with a golden vine to induce him to go to Troy Od. 11.520.
Son of Sthenelus-2. By contrivance of Hera born before Heracles, who thus became subject to him Il. 8.363, Il. 15.639, Il. 19.123, 133.
Patr. fr. Εὔρυτος-1. Of Iphitus-2 Od. 21.14, 37.
(ἀγακλυτός). A centaur. Punished in the house of Peirithous by the Lapiths Od. 21.295.

div1.head: Εὔρυτος-1
div1.p: (μέγας). Father of Iphitus-2. The ruler of Oechalia Il. 2.596, 730: skilled with the bow Od. 8.224; challenged Apollo to a contest with the bow and was slain by him Od. 8.226; left his bow to his son Od. 21.32.

div1.head: Εὔρυτος-2.
div1.p: See Ἀκτορίων, Μολίων-2. Son (with Cteatus) of Poseidon (Il. 11.751). Father of Thalpius Il. 2.621. See also Il. 11.709, 750, Il. 23.638 under Κτέατος.
Father of Acamas-2 Il. 7.8.
A Boeotian town Il. 2.502.
Son of Troezenus and leader of the Cicones Il. 2.846.
(ἄναξ ἀνδρῶν). Gave Phyleus a breastplate Il. 15.532.

(ἐϋμμελίης). Patr. Πανθοΐδης. Son of Panthous. Wounds Patroclus Il. 16.808, 850; bids Menelaus. quit P.'s body Il. 17.12; will avenge the slaying by M. of his brother Hyperenor Il. 17.34; s. M. Il. 17.45, 59, 81.
G. Son of Polyidus-2. S. Paris Il. 13.663.
(κρατερός, τηλεκλειτός). Son of Poseidon (nominally of Aloeus) and Iphimedeia. See Ὦτος-1.

div1.head: Ἐφύρη-1
div1.p: A town on the Selleis-2, the home of Astyocheia Il. 2.659, Il. 15.531.

div1.head: Ἐφύρη-2.
div1.p: A town of Argos-1 (3), the home of Sisyphus Il. 7.152, 210.

div1.head: Ἐφύρη-3
div1.p: (πίειρα ἄρουρα). A city or district, perh. in Thesprotia, the seat of Ilus-2 Od. 1.259, Od. 2.328.
A people represented as warred on by Ares Il. 13.301.
(κρατερός). Patr Ἀκτορίδης. Husband of Polymele Il. 16.189.

div1.head: Ἔχεκλος-1
div1.p: T. Son of Agenor. S. Achilles Od. 3.474.

div1.head: Ἔχεκλος-2
div1.p: T. S. Patroclus Il. 16.694.
Son of Priam (his mother not named). With his brother Chromius-2 s. Diomedes Il. 5.160.
A Phaeacian elder Od. 6.155, Od. 11.342.

div1.head: Ἐχέπωλος-1
div1.p: T. Patr. Θαλυσιάδης. S. Antilochus Il. 4.458.

div1.head: Ἐχέπωλος-2.
div1.p: Patr. Ἀγχισιάδης-2. Gave Agamemnon the mare Aethe to escape service Il. 23.296.
(βροτῶν δηλήμων πάντων). A mythical destructive king Od. 18.85, 116, Od. 21.308.
(δῖος). Son of Nestor Od. 3.413, 439.
νῆσοι?̔ἱεραί). The Echinean Islands, represented as lying off Elis Il. 2.625.

div1.head: Ἐχίος-1.
div1.p: Father of Mecisteus-2 Il. 8.333, Il. 13.422.

div1.head: Ἐχίος-2
div1.p: G. S. Polites-1 Il. 15.339.

div1.head: Ἐχίος-3
div1.p: T. S. Patroclus Il. 16.416.
(ὑλήεις, ὑλήεσσα). The mod. Zante. An island forming part of the realm of Odysseus Il. 2.634.
In Od. associated with Doulichium, Same and Ithaca Od. 1.246, Od. 9.24, Od. 16.123, 250, Od. 19.131.
(ἱερή). A town of the Troad on the Aesepus-1 Il. 2.824, Il. 4.103, 121.
