Genit. Ζηνός 408, Il. 11.795, Il. 12.235, Il. 13.449, etc. : Od. 1.27, Od. 2.68, Od. 4.74, etc. Dat. Ζηνί 49, Il. 4.1, Il. 6.443, etc.: Od. 4.78, Od. 9.552. Acc. Ζῆνα 756, Il. 8.22, Il. 14.157, etc.: Od. 20.339, Od. 24.472. Ζῆν 206, Il. 14.265, Il. 24.331. Voc. Ζεῦ 503, Il. 2.371, Il. 3.298, Il. 5.421, etc.: Od. 1.62, Od. 4.341, Od. 5.7, Od. 6.331, etc. Genit. Διός 5, Il. 2.26, Il. 3.107, Il. 4.128, etc.: Od. 1.10, Od. 2.296, Od. 3.42, Od. 4.27, etc. Dat. Διί 419, Il. 2.102, Il. 3.104, Il. 4.23, etc.: Od. 4.472, Od. 6.164, Od. 8.432, etc. Acc. Δία 394, Il. 2.2, Il. 5.419, etc. : Od. 14.389, 406, Od. 20.75. Διόθεν [-θεν], from Z. Il. 24.194, 561. By his power or will Il. 15.489. (ἀθάνατος, αἰγίοχος, ἄναξ, ἀργικέραυνος, ἄριστος, ἀστεροπητής, ἐριβρεμέτης, ἐρίγδουπος, ἐρισθενής, εὐρύοπα, Ἰδαῖος, ἱκετήσιος, καταχθόνιος, κελαινεφής, κρείων, κύδιστος, μέγας, μέγιστος, Ἴδηθεν (Δωδώνης) μεδέων, μητίετα, αἰθέρι?̔τηλόθἰ ναίων, νεφεληγερέτα, ξείνιος, ξένιος, Ὀλύμπιος, πανομφαῖος, πατήρ, π. ἀνδρῶν τε θεῶν τε, στεροπηγερέτα, τελεσφόρος, τερπικέραυνος, ὕπατος, ὕ. κρειόντων, ὑπερμενής, ὑψιβρεμέτης, ὑψίζυγος, ὑψόθ̓ ἐών.) Patr. Κρονίδης, Κρονίων. The supreme god, son of Cronus and Rhea, brother of Poseidon, Hades, Hera and Demeter, and husband (and brother) of Here. Father (1) by Hera of Ares, Hebe and Hephaestus; (2) by Leto of Apollo and Artemis; (3) by Dione of Aphrodite; (4) by Semele of Dionysus; (5) by Maia of Hermes; (6) by Demeter of Persephoneia; (7) by Europa (daughter of Phoenix-2) of Minos and Rhadamanthys; (8) by Leda of Helen; (9) by Alemene of Heracles; (10) by Laodameia of Sarpedon; (11) by Danaee of Perseus-1; (12) by Antiope of Amphion-2 and Zethus; (13) by Dia of Peirithous; and (14) by unnamed mothers of Athene, Dardanus-1, Aeacus and Tantalus.
Father also of Ate Il. 19.91; of the river Xanthus-1 Il. 14.434; of the Muses Il. 2.491, 598: Od. 8.488; of nymphs Il. 7.420: Od. 7.105, Od. 9.154, Od. 13.356, Od. 17.240; of Λιταί 502.
Protector of heralds. See under κῆρυξ in Lex. And of strangers, beggars and suppliants Od. 7.207, Od. 9.270, etc.
See also ξείνιος (1), ξένιος (2) in Lex.
His scales. See τάλαντον (1) in Lex. His thunderbolts Il. 8.133, Il. 21.198, etc.: Od. 5.128, Od. 12.415, etc.
Sender of rain Il. 12.25, etc.: Od. 9.111, etc. Of snow Il. 10.5, Il. 12.279, Il. 19.357. Of winds Il. 12.252, Il. 13.795, etc. : Od. 9.67, Od. 15.297, etc. And of the rainbow Il. 11.27, Il. 17.547.
By lot (Il. 15.187, 192) got the heavens and the upper air as his realm (but he is called καταχθόνιος 457).

The attempt of Here, Athene and Poseidon to put him in bonds Il. 1.399; Thetis goes to him on behalf of Achilles Il. 1.493, his promise to her 518; sends Oneirus to beguile Agamemnon Il. 2.8; sends Athene to induce the Trojans to break the truce Il. 4.70; with threats forbids the assembled gods to help either side Il. 8.1; sends a thunderbolt which falls before the chariot of Diomedes Il. 8.133; sends an omen to comfort Agamemnon Il. 8.247; sends Iris to turn back Hera and Athene Il. 8.399; sends Eris to encourage the Greeks Il. 11.3; sends Iris to Hector with advice Il. 11.185; beguiled and lulled to sleep by Hera Il. 14.292, his rage when he awakes Il. 15.4; summons Iris and Apollo Il. 15.54, sends her to bid Poseidon retire from the fight 158, and him to aid Hector 221; debates with himself as to Sarpedon's fate Il. 16.433, resolves on his death 458, charges Apollo with his funeral rites 667; Hera tricked him in the matter of the birth of Heracles Il. 19.95, his rage thereat 125; sends Athene to comfort Achilles Il. 19.342; summons an assembly of the gods Od. 3.4, allows the gods to take sides in the fight 20; pities Hector's plight Il. 22.168, but allows Athene to go to the assistance of Achilles 183; sends Thetis to Achilles to induce him to give up Hector's corpse Il. 24.104, and Iris to Priam to bid him go to the ships and ransom the corpse 144, sends Hermes to aid Il. 17.334, etc. : speaks of Aegisthus to the assembled gods Od. 1.31; sends an eagle as a good omen to Telemachus Od. 2.146; sends Hermes to bid Calypso let Odysseus go Od. 5.29, Od. 6.261; thunders as a good sign to O. Od. 20.103; gives his voice for peace between O. and his people Od. 24.478, and sends a thunderbolt to stop the fighting 539; etc.
(ἄναξ). Son of Zeus and Antiope. With his brother Amphion-2 represented as having founded Thebes-1 Od. 11.262; Od. 19.523 (see also Πανδάρεος).

(καλλίσφυρος, πότνια). Daughter of Zeus and Here. Acts as cup-bearer to the gods Il. 4.2; helps Hera to prepare a chariot Il. 5.722; tends Ares when cured of his wound Il. 5.905: Heracles her husband Od. 11.603.

Ἥλιος Od. 8.271 (ἀκάμας, παμφανάων, τερψίμβροτος,?̔γπερίων,?̔γπεριονίδης, φαέθων, φαεσίμβροτος). The Sun, father by Perse of Aeetes and Circe Od. 10.138, and by Neaera of Phaethousa and Lampetie Od. 12.132. Brings to Hephaestus news of his dishonour by Ares Od. 8.271; his oxen Od. 1.8, Od. 12.128, they are killed by the companions of Odysseus 353.
See further in Lexicon.
(περικαλλής). Stepmother of (app.) Otus-1 and Ephialtes. Her rescue of Ares Il. 5.389.

div1.head: Ἠετίων-1
div1.p: (μεγαλήτωρ). King of Thebe-2 and father of Andromache. His city taken by Achilles and himself slain Il. 1.366, Il. 7.416, Il. 9.188, Il. 16.153; Il. 7.395, 396, Il. 8.187, Il. 22.472, 480, Il. 23.827.

div1.head: Ἠετίων-2.
div1.p: A Trojan, father of Podes Il. 17.575, 590.

div1.head: Ἠετίων-3.
div1.p: An Imbrian. Ransomed Lycaon-2 Il. 21.43.
A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.561.

div1.head: Ἠϊονεύς-1
div1.p: G. S. Hector Il. 6.11.

div1.head: Ἠϊονεύς-2.
div1.p: Father of Rhesus-1 Il. 10.435.
The people of Elis Il. 11.671.
See Ἠέλιος.

(δῖα, εὐρύχορος, ἱππόβοτος). A town and country in the n. w. extremity of the
Peloponnesus Il. 2.615, 626, Il. 11.673, 686, 698: Od. 4.635, Od. 13.275, Od. 15.298, Od. 21.347, Od. 24.431.
πεδίον. See Lexicon.
A town of Thessaly. Its men led by Polypoetes and Leonteus Il. 2.739.
(ἐρατεινή). A district adjoining Pieria Il. 14.226.
Son of Thebeus-1. Chariot-driver to Hector. S. Diomedes Il. 8.120.
Patr. fr. next. Of Satnius Il. 14.444.

div1.head: Ἦνοψ-1.
div1.p: Father of Satnius by a naiad Il. 14.445; and father also of Thesto Il. 16.401.

div1.head: Ἦνοψ-2.
div1.p: Father of Clytomedes Il. 23.634.
Patr. of Periphas-2 Il. 17.324.

Ἡρακλῆς (θεῖος, θρασυμέμνων θυμολέων, κρατερός, κρατερόφρων, μεγάλων ἐπιίστωρ ἔργων, μένος αἰὲν ἀτειρής). Son of Alemene by Zeus (nominally by Amphitryon) Il. 14.324: Od. 11.267. Father of Tlepolemus-1 by Astyocheia Il. 2.658, 666; father also of Thessalus Il. 2.679: husband of Hebe Od. 11.603. His birth delayed by contrivance of Here, whereby he became subject to Eurystheus Il. 19.95, Il. 15.640; wounded Hera with an arrow Il. 5.392; being wronged by Laomedon sacked Troy Il. 5.638, his return thence hindered by Hera Il. 14.249, 266, Il. 15.25; carried off the dog of Hades Il. 8.366: Od. 11.623; vexed Pylus Il. 11.690; the wall built for him against the sea monster Od. 3.145; his fate Il. 18.117: Od. 8.224; his phantom in the Shades Od. 11.601; killed Iphitus-2 Od. 21.26.
Patr. fr. prec. Of Tlepolemus-1 Il. 2.653, Il. 5.628.
Of Thessalus Il. 2.679.
Adj. fr. Ἡρακλέης. βίη Ἡρακλείη, Ἡρακλέης 658, 666, Il. 5.638, Il. 11.690, Il. 15.640, Il. 19.98: Od. 11.601.
So βίη Ἡρακλῆος 117.
See Ἡρακλέης.

(Ἀργείη, βοῶπις, Διὸς κυδρὴ παράκοιτις, ἠΰκομος, θεά, λευκώλενος, πότνια, πρέσβα θεά, χρυσόθρονος, χρυσοπέδιλος). Daughter of Cronus and Rhea, sister of Zeus, Hades, Poseidon and Demeter, and wife (and sister) of Zeus. For her children see under Ζεύς. Reared by Oceanus and Tethys Il. 14.200, 302. She suspects the promise of Zeus to Thetis Il. 1.536; reproaches Zeus for favouring the Trojans Il. 4.20, they come to terms 31; she urges Athene to the fray Il. 5.711, prepares a chariot 720, consults Zeus 753, conveys A. to the field 767; urges A. again to the field Il. 8.350, they are stopped by Iris sent by Zeus 413; arrays herself to beguile Zeus Il. 14.166, gets the aid of Aphrodite 188, and of Sleep 231, the beguilement 292, Zeus wakens Il. 15.4, and sends her to summon Iris and Apollo 54; how she tricked Zeus in the matter of the birth of Heracles Il. 19.95; summons Hephaestus to quell Xanthus-1 Il. 21.328; in the Battle of the Gods assaults Artemis Il. 21.489; etc. : Od. 4.513, Od. 8.465, Od. 11.604, Od. 12.72, Od. 15.112, 180, Od. 20.70.

(ἀμφιγυήεις, ἄναξ, κλυτοεργός, κλυτοτέχνης, κυλλοποδίων, περικλυτός, πολύμητις, πολύφρων, χαλκεύς). Son of Zeus and Here. Husband in Il. (Il. 18.382) of Charis, in Od. (Od. 8.267) of Aphrodite. His lameness Il. 18.394, Od. 3.36, etc. : Od. 8.308, etc. His craftsmanship Il. 1.607, Il. 14.166, Il. 18.417, 468, etc.: Od. 8.272, etc. Persuades his mother to conciliate Zeus Il. 1.571; his fall from Olympus Il. 1.590; made Agamemnon's sceptre Il. 2.101, and the breastplate of Diomedes Il. 8.195, and the aegis Il. 15.310; Thetis goes to beg him for armour for her son Il. 18.369, which he makes 468; he tells how Eurynome-1 and Thetis tended him when rejected by Hera Il. 18.394; Hera summons him to quell Xanthus-1 Il. 21.330; etc. : Od. 4.617, Od. 7.233, Od. 6.92; Demodocus tells how Ares and Aphrodite deceived him and how he punished them Od. 8.266, 270, 286, 287, 293, 297, 327, 330, 345, 355, 359; Od. 15.117, Od. 23.160, Od. 24.71, 75.
See also in Lex.
(δῖα, ἐΰθρονος, ἐϋπλόκαμος, ἠριγένεια, κροκόπεπλος, ῥοδοδάκτυλος, χρυσόθρονος). The Dawn. Wife of Tithonus and mother of Memnon. Carried off Orion Od. 5.121, and Cleitus-2 Od. 15.250.
See also ἠώς (5) in Lexicon.
A Nereid Il. 18.39.
See Ἀκτορίων. Son of Eurytus-2 and grandson of Poseidon. A leader of the Epeians Il. 2.620.
Patr. of Echepolus-1 Il. 4.458.
A Thracian bard deprived by the Muses at Dorium of his power of song Il. 2.595.
See Lexicon.
A town of uncertain site in the realm of Philoctetes Il. 2.716.

(δῖα, καλλιπάρῃος). Patr. Κισσηΐς. Daughter of Cisses (Il. 11.224), wife of Antenor, mother of Iphidamas and priestess at Tory of Athene. Brought up Pedaeus Il. 5.70; opens Athene's temple for the aged women Il. 7.298, 302.
See θέμις (7) in Lexicon.

(θεοειδής, μάντις). Son of Polypheides and great-grandson of Melampus. In flight from Argos-1 (1) encounters Telemachus embarking for home at Pylus Od. 15.223, 256, 271, is taken on board 286, asks as to his disposal 508, announces a good omen 529, is committed to the care of Peiraeus 540; his prediction to Penelope Od. 17.151; his vision among the suitors Od. 20.350, he leaves the suitors 363.
T. A Paeonian Il. 17.216; s. Achilles Il. 21.209.
A deformed Greek described Il. 2.212. Abuses Agamemnon Il. 2.225, Odysseus deals with him 244, 246.
A Boeotian town Il. 2.498.
The inhabitants of Thesprotia, a part of Epeirus extending s.e. from the Thyamis Od. 14.315, 316, 335, Od. 16.65, 427, Od. 17.526, Od. 19.271, 287, 292.
Patr. Ἡρακλεΐδης. Son of Heracles and father of Pheidippus and Antiphus-1 Il. 2.679.

div1.head: Θεστορίδης-1.
div1.p: Patr. of Calchas Il. 1.69.

div1.head: Θεστορίδης-2.
div1.p: Patr. of Alcmaon-1 Il. 12.394.
T. Son of Enops-1. S. Patroclus Il. 16.401.

(ἁλοσύδνη, ἀργυρόπεζα, ἠΰκομος, θεά, καλλιπλόκαμος, τανύπεπλος). Daughter of the ἅλιος γέρων (Nereus) Il. 1.556. Wife of Peleus and mother of Achilles. Comes when called upon by Achilles on his loss of Briseis Il. 1.357, A. reminds her how she saved Zeus from bonds 396, she promises to induce Zeus to favour the Trojans 413, goes to him and gets his promise 495; received Dionysus when terrified by Lycourgus-1 Il. 7.136; the chest given by her to Achilles Il. 16.222; comes to A. on the death of Patroclus Il. 18.35, promises him armour from Hephaestus 127, goes to Η. 369, how Eurynome-1 and she preserved Η. 398, she brings away the armour 616, and gives it to A. Il. 19.3; summoned by Zeus Il. 24.74, and sent to bid A. release Hector's corpse 104, etc. : appears and takes part in the funeral rites of Achilles Od. 24.47, the jar given by her to receive A.'s bones 73, the prizes given by her for his funeral games 85, 92.

div1.head: Θῆβαι-1
div1.p: Θήβη-1 Il. 4.378, 406, Il. 14.323, Il. 19.99: Od. 11.263, 265, 275 (ἑπτάπυλος, εὐρύχορος, ἐϋστέφανος, ἱερὰ τείχεα, πολυήρατος). The Boeotian city, traditionally said to have been founded by Cadmus (represented as having been founded by Amphion-2 and Zethus Od. 11.262) Il. 4.378, 406, Il. 5.804, Il. 7.223, Il. 10.286, Il. 14.114, 323, Il. 19.99: Od. 11.263, 265, 275, Od. 15.247.
Θήβασδε [-δε], to Th. Il. 23.679.

div1.head: Θῆβαι-2
div1.p: (ἑκατόμπυλοι). The city of Upper Egypt Il. 9.381: Od. 4.126.

div1.head: Θηβαῖος-1
div1.p: (ὑπέρθυμος). Father of Eniopeus Il. 8.120.

div1.head: Θήβη-1.
div1.p: See Θῆβαι-1.

div1.head: Θήβη-2
div1.p: Θῆβαι-3 Il. 22.479 (ἱερή, γποπλακίη, ὑψίπυλος). A town (inhabited by the Cilices), of which Eetion-1 was king, in the plain of Thebe in which Adramyttium afterwards stood. Taken by Achilles and Eetion slain and Chryseis captured Il. 1.366, Il. 2.691, Il. 7.397, 416; Il. 22.479.

(ἐπιείκελος ἀθανάτοισιν, ἐρικυδής). Patr. Αἰγεΐδης. Son of Aegeus, king of Athens, and husband of Phaedra. The great legendary hero of Athens. Named as a warrior of Nestor's youth Il. 1.265: carried off Ariadne from Crete Od. 11.322; Od. 11.631.
(πολυτρήρων). A Boeotian town Il. 2.502.

div1.head: Θόας-1
div1.p: (Αἰτωλός). Patr. Ἀνδραιμονίδης. Son of Andraemon and leader of the Aetolians Il. 2.638; slays Peiroos Il. 4.527, 529; accepts Hector's challenge but does not get the lot Il. 6.168; Il. 13.92; Poseidon takes his guise Il. 13.216, 222, 228; Th. advises the chiefs to stand up to Hector, sending the general body back Il. 15.281; Il. 19.239: in Odysseus's tale to Eumaeus and his companions Od. 14.499.

div1.head: Θόας-2
div1.p: (θεῖος). King of Lemnos Il. 14.230, Il. 23.745.

div1.head: Θόας-3
div1.p: T. S. Menelaus Il. 16.311.
A Nerei Il. 18.40.

div1.head: Θόων-1
div1.p: T. Son of Phaenops-1. With his brother Xanthus-3 s. Diomedes Il. 5.152.

div1.head: Θόων-2
div1.p: T. S. Odysseus Il. 11.422.

div1.head: Θόων-3
div1.p: T. Il. 12.140; s. Antilochus Il. 13.545.

div1.head: Θόων-4.
div1.p: A Phaeacian Od. 8.113.
(νύμφη). A nymph, daughter of Phorcys-2 and by Poseidon mother of Polyphemus-1 Od. 1.71.
(δῖος). A Greek herald Il. 12.342, 343.
T. A Paeonian. S. Achilles Il. 21.210.

(ἀντίθεος, δῖος, ἱππόδαμος, κυδάλιμος, μενεπτόλεμος, ποιμὴν λαῶν, ὑπέρθυμος). Patr. Νεστορίδης. Son of Nestor Il. 9.81, Il. 10.255, Il. 14.10; slays Maris Il. 16.321; Il. 17.378, 705: Od. 3.39, 414, 442, 448.
T (ἀγακλειτός). S. Patroclus Il. 16.463.
Θρῇξ. Thracian Il. 2.595.
Θρήϊκες, Θρῇκες Τ (ἀκρόκομοι, ἱπποπόλοι). The Thracians Il. 2.844, Il. 4.519, 533, 537, Il. 5.462, Il. 7.7, Il. 10.434, 464, 470, 487, 506, 518, Il. 13.4, Il. 14.227, Il. 24.234.
(ἐριβῶλαξ, μήτηρ υν́λων). Thrace Il. 11.222, Il. 13.301, Od. 3.485.
Θρῄκηθεν [-θεν], from Th. Il. 9.5, 72.
Θρῄκηνδε [-δε], to Th. Od. 8.361.
Epithet or the name of the island containing the oxen of the Sun Od. 11.107, Od. 12.127, 135, Od. 19.275.
A Locrian town Il. 2.533.
(Ἀλφειοῖο πόρος). A town of Pylus Il. 2.592, app. identical with Θρυόεσσα (αἰπεῖα κολώνη) Il. 11.711.
Θυέστα Il. 2.107 (πολύαρνι). Son of Pelops, brother of Atreus and father of Aegisthus. The sceptre left to him by Atreus and by him to Agamemnon Il. 2.106, 107: his dwelling Od. 4.517.
Patr. fr. prec. Of Aegisthus Od. 4.518.
T. S. Diomedes Il. 11.320.
A town on the Scamander Il. 10.430.
A Trojan elder Il. 3.146.
An Egyptian, husband of Polydamna Od. 4.228.
A Nereid Il. 18.42.
Son of Ares and Astyoche. A leader of the men of Orchomenus-1, etc. Il. 2.512, Il. 9.82.
(ι) T. Il. 12.139; s. Leonteus Il. 12.193.
A Nereid Il. 18.47.
A Nereid Il. 18.47.
G (ἑλκεχίτωνες). The Ionians Il. 13.685 (app. identified with the Athenians 689).
(ι). A Titan. In Tartarus Il. 8.479.

div1.head: Ἰάρδανος-1.
div1.p: An unknown river, app. on the borders of Pylus and Arcadia Il. 6.135.

div1.head: Ἰάρδανος-2.
div1.p: A river of n. Crete Od. 3.292.

div1.head: Ἰασίδης-1
div1.p: (ι). See Δμήτωρ.
(ι). Demeter's love for him and his death by lightning Od. 5.125.

div1.head: Ἴασος-1
div1.p: (ι). Son of Sphelus and a leader of the Athenians. S. Aeneas Il. 15.332, 337.

div1.head: Ἴασος-2
div1.p: (ι). Ἴασον Ἄργος, of doubtful origin, app. denoting all s. Greece (Argos-1 (3)) Od. 18.246.
(ἐϋκτιμένη, εὐρύχορος). A town of the realm of Eumelus at the head of the Pagasaean Gulf Il. 2.712: was the home of Pelies Od. 11.256.

div1.head: Ἰδαῖος-1
div1.p: (ι) (δαΐφρων, πεπνυμένος). A Trojan herald. Summons Priam to take the oath to the Greeks Il. 3.248; with Talthybius stops the fight between Aias-1 and Hector Il. 6.276, 278, 284; sent to carry Paris's proposal to the Greeks Il. 6.372, 381, 405, 406, 413, 416; accompanies Priam to the ships Il. 24.281, 325, 470.

div1.head: Ἰδαῖος-2
div1.p: (ι) (μάχης εὖ εἰδὼς πάσης). Son of Dares. With his brother Phegeus attacks Diomedes Il. 5.11, is saved by Hephaestus 20.

(ι) (μήτηρ θηρῶν, πιδήεσσα, πολυπῖδαξ, πολύπτυχος, ὑλήεσσα, ὑψηλή). A mountain of the Troad with many branches Il. 2.821, 824, Il. 8.47, 75, 207, Il. 11.105, 112, 183, 337, Il. 13.13, Il. 14.157, 162, 283, 287, 293, 307, 332, Il. 15.5, 146, 151, 255, Il. 17.594, Od. 3.59, 91, 218, Il. 21.449, 559, Il. 22.171, Il. 23.117.
Ἴδηθεν [-θεν], from I. Il. 4.475, Il. 8.397, 438.
App. as genit. : 'I. μεδέων 276=320=Il. 6.202=Il. 24.308.
(ι). Husband of Marpessa and father of Cleopatra Il. 9.558. Fought with Apollo for Marpessa Il. 9.559.

(ι) (ἀγαπήνωρ, ἀγαυός, ἀγὸς ἀνδρῶν, ἀγακλυτός, ἄναξ, ἀρήϊος, ἀτάλαντος Ἄρηϊ, δαΐφρων, δουρικλυτός, μεσαιπόλιος). Son of Deucalion-1 and leader of the Cretans Il. 2.645; described by Helen to Priam Il. 3.230; visited by Agamemnon in his inspection Il. 4.252; accepts Hector's challenge but does not get the lot Il. 6.165; Poseidon reproaches him Il. 13.219, he urges Meriones to the fight 249, slays Othryoneus 363, and Asius-2 384, and Alcathous 424, fights Aeneas 500; slays Erymas-1 Il. 16.345; strikes Hector Il. 17.605, retreats to the ships 624; while watching the chariot-race is abused by Aias-2 Il. 23.474; etc.: brought his surviving comrades safe home Od. 3.191; in Odysseus's tale to Athene Od. 13.259, to Eumaeus Od. 14.237, in Eumaeus's comment 382, and in O. 's tale to Penelope Od. 19.181, 190.
A town of Rhodes Il. 2.656.
Patr. fr. next. Of Euneus Il. 6.468, 471, Il. 23.747.
(ποιμὴν λαῶν). The Argonaut, father by Hypsipyle of Euneus Il. 6.469, Il. 21.41: Od. 12.72.
Father of Sthenelaus Il. 16.586.

mod. Ithaki (ἀμφίαλος, εὐδείελος, ἐϋκτιμένη, κραναή, παιπαλόεσσα, πίων δῆμος, τρηχεῖα, ὑπονήϊος). The island home of Odysseus, containing the mountain Neritum (Neium) Il. 2.632, Il. 3.201: Od. 1.18, Od. 2.167, Od. 3.81; its condition described Od. 4.605; its position Od. 9.22; Od. 11.111, Od. 13.97; its features pointed out by Athene to O. Od. 13.344; Od. 14.98, Od. 15.36, Od. 16.419, Od. 17.250, Od. 19.399, Od. 20.340, Od. 21.18, Od. 22.30, Od. 23.176, Od. 24.104, etc.
Ἰθάκης πόλις?̔ἄστυ) Od. 10.416, Od. 18.2, Od. 22.223.
πόλις alone Od. 1.185, Od. 15.37, Od. 24.205, etc.
ἄστυ alone Od. 2.77, Od. 17.25, Od. 22.77, etc.
Associated with Doulichium, Same and Zacynthus Od. 1.247, Od. 9.21, Od. 16.124, 251, Od. 19.132.
See also Ἀρέθουσα, Κόρακος πέτρη.
Adj. fr. prec., Ithacan Il. 2.184: Od. 2.246, Od. 22.45.
With Neritus and Polyctor-2 constructed a fountain above the city of Ithaca Od. 17.207.
(κλωμακόεσσα). A town of Thessaly. Its men led by Podaleirius and Machaon Il. 2.729.

div1.head: Ἰκάριος-1
div1.p: πόντος?̔ι). A part of the Aegean s. of Icaria and Samos, said to be named from Icarus, son of Daedalus, who fell into it from the air Il. 2.145.

div1.head: Ἰκάριος-2
div1.p: (ἰ?̔μεγαλήτωρ). Father of Penelope and Iphthime Od. 1.329, Od. 2.53, 133, Od. 4.797, etc.
Patr. fr. next. Of Melanippus-2 Il. 15.546.
(ὄζος Ἄρηος). Son of Laomedon and father of Melanippus-2 Il. 3.147, Il. 15.576, Od. 3.238.
Made Penelope's κλισίη 57.
(ι). Adj. fr. an unknown Ἰλεύς. The Ileian plain cannot be identifed Od. 21.558.
See Ἴλιος.
̔ἰ?̔ἀλαυός̓. Only son of Phorbas-2. S. Peneleos Il. 14.489, 492, 501.

(ι), Ἴλιον (ι) Il. 15.71 (αἰπεινή, αἰπύ, ἐρατεινή, ἐϋκτίμενον?̔εὖ ναιόμενον̓ πτολίεθρον, εὔπωλος, εὐτείχεος, ἠνεμόεσσα, ἱρή, ὀφρυόεσσα). Another name for Τροίη (1) Il. 1.71, Il. 2.113, Il. 4.33, Il. 6.20, Il. 11.196, Il. 14.46, Il. 18.58, Il. 23.64, etc. : Od. 2.18, Od. 8.495, Od. 11.86, Od. 14.71, Od. 17.104, Od. 24.117, etc.
For Ἰλιόθεν and for Ἰλιόθι as locative and Ἰλιόφι as genit. see Lexicon.

div1.head: Ἶλος-1
div1.p: (ι). Patr. Δαρδανίδης. Son of Tros-1 and father of Laomedon. His tomb Il. 10.415, Il. 11.166, 372, Il. 24.349; Od. 3.232, 236.

div1.head: Ἶλος-2.
div1.p: Patr. Μερμερίδης. A ruler of Ephyre-3 represented as having command of poisons Od. 1.259.
Patr. of Peiroos Il. 4.520.

div1.head: Ἴμβριος-1
div1.p: (αἰχμητής). Son of Mentor-1. From Pedaeum. Husband of Medesicaste. S. Teucrus Il. 13.171, 197.

div1.head: Ἴμβριος-2.
div1.p: Adj. fr. next. Il. 21.43.
(παιπαλόεσσα). An island lower in height than Samothrace between S. and Troy and n.w. of Tenedos Il. 13.33, Il. 14.281, Il. 24.78, 753.
(ι), called also Λευκοθέη (καλλίσφυρος). Daughter of Cadmus. Made immortal Od. 5.334; comes to the aid of Odysseus when his raft is shattered Od. 5.333, 461.
Adj. fr. Ἰξίων. (Wife) of Ixion. Of Dia (see Πειρίθοος) Il. 14.317.

div1.head: Ἱππασίδης-1.
div1.p: Patr. fr. Ἵππασος. Of Charops and Socus Il. 11.426, 431.

div1.head: Ἱππασίδης-2.
div1.p: Patr. of Hypsenor-2 Il. 13.411.

div1.head: Ἱππασίδης-3.
div1.p: Patr. of Apisaon-2 Il. 17.348.
(δαΐφρων ἱππόδαμος). Father of Charops and Socus Il. 11.450.
(ἀγαυοί). An unknown race described as living on (mare's) milk Il. 13.5.
T. S. Achilles γ> 401.

div1.head: Ἱπποδάμεια-1
div1.p: (κλυτός). Wife of Peirithous and mother of Polypoetes Il. 2.742.

div1.head: Ἱπποδάμεια-2.
div1.p: The eldest and the fairest and most skilful of the daughters of Anchises. Wife of Alcathous Il. 13.429.

div1.head: Ἱπποδάμεια-3
div1.p: A handmaid of Penelope Od. 18.182.
T S. Odysseus Il. 11.335.

div1.head: Ἱππόθοος-1
div1.p: T. (φαίδιμος). Son of Lethus. A leader of the Pelasgians (1) Il. 2.840, 842; Il. 17.217; tries to drag off the body of Patroclus Il. 17.289; s. Aias-1 Il. 17.293; Il. 17.313, 318.

div1.head: Ἱππόθοος-2
div1.p: A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.251.
(ἐσθλός). Cousin of Rhesus-1 Il. 10.518.

div1.head: Ἱππόλοχος-1
div1.p: Son of Bellerophon, grandson of Glaucus-1 and father of Glaucus-2 Il. 7.119, 144, 197, 206, Il. 6.13, Il. 12.309, 387, Il. 17.140.

div1.head: Ἱππόλοχος-2
div1.p: T. (μενεχάρμης). Son of Antimachus. With his brother Peisandrus-1 s. Agamemnon Il. 11.122, 145.
T. Son of Antimachus. S. Leonteus Il. 12.189.
G (μενεχάρμης). S. Hector Il. 11.303.
Patr. of Aeolus Od. 10.2, 36.
T Father of Ascanius and Morys Il. 13.792; s. Meriones Il. 14.514.
(ποιήεσσα). A town of Pylus Il. 9.150, 292.

(ἀελλόπος, θεά,?̔πόδας̓ ὠκέα, ποδήνεμος, ταχεῖα, χρυσόπτερος). The messenger of the gods. Comes to the Trojans from Zeus Il. 2.786; calls Helen to the walls Il. 3.121; leads Aphrodite from the fray Il. 5.353; sent by Zeus to stop Hera and Athene Il. 8.398; sent by him to encourage Hector Il. 11.185; summoned by him Il. 15.55, and sent to cause Poseidon to retire 157; sent by Hera to Achilles Il. 18.166; summons the winds to the pyre of Patroclus Il. 23.198; summons Thetis to Zeus Il. 24.77; sent by Zeus to Priam Il. 24.143; etc.

App. masc. form of prec.; the nickname of Arnaeus. A beggar employed as a messenger by the young men in Ithaca. His fight with Odysseus Od. 18.6, 25, 38, 56, 73 (Ἶρος Ἄϊρος, that will soon be Irus no more), 75, 96, 233, 239, 333, 334, 393.
(ι.) Son of Bellerophon Il. 7.197; killed fighting with the Solymi Il. 7.203.
The town of the Cicones Od. 9.40, 198.
Bastard son of Priam Il. 11.101. See Ἄντιφος-3
(πολυστάφυλος). A town of Euboea Il. 2.537.
Od. 19.522. See Πανδάρεος.
(ι) (ἐσθλός). Patr. ̔γπειροχίδης. An Eleian slain by Nestor in his youth Il. 11.672.
(μήτηρ μήλων). A town in the realm of Protesilaus Il. 2.696.
(ι) T. S. Patroclus Il. 16.417.
Daughter of Icarius-2, sister of Penelope and wife of Eumelus. Appears to P. in a dream Od. 4.797.
(ι). Daughter of Agamemnon Il. 9.145, 287.

(ι) T (ἠΰς τε μέγας τε). Patr. Ἀντηνορίδης. Son of Antenor and Theano; brought up in Thrace by his maternal grandfather Cisses and married a sister of Theano Il. 11.221; s. Agamemnon Il. 11.234; Il. 11.257, 261.
(ι). Adj. fr. next. βίη Ἰφικληείῆ next. His oxen and Melampus Od. 11.290, 296.

div1.head: Ἴφικλος-1
div1.p: (ι) (πολύμηλος). Patr. Φυλακίδης. Son of Phylacus-2 and father of Protesilaus and Podarces Il. 2.705, Il. 13.698.
See also prec.

div1.head: Ἴφικλος-2
div1.p: (ι) Nestor beat him in a foot-race Il. 23.636.
(ι). Wife of Aloeus and by Poseidon mother of Otus-1 and Ephialtes Od. 11.305.
(ι) G. Patr. Δεξιάδης. S. Glaucus-2 Il. 6.14.
(ὲΰζωνος). When Achilles took Scyrus-2 given by him to Patroclus Il. 9.667.
(ι). Patr. of Archeptolemus Il. 8.128.
(ι) T. Patr. Ὀτρυντεΐδης. Son of Otrunteus and a naiad. S. Achilles Od. 3.382.

div1.head: Ἴφιτος-1
div1.p: (ι) (μεγάθυμος). Patr. Ναυβολίδης-1 Father of Schedius-1 and Epistrophus-1 Il. 2.518, Il. 17.306.

div1.head: Ἴφιτος-2
div1.p: (ι) (ἐπιείκελος ἀθανάτοισιν). Patr. Εὐρυτίδης. Son of Eurytus-1. Inherited his father's bow Od. 21.32; met Odysseus in the house of Ortilochus-3 in Messene Od. 21.14, when he was seeking for lost horses 22 (though his and his father's home is stated to have been in Oechalia, far from Messene (see Εὔρυτος-1)); gave O. his father's bow Od. 21.31; s. Heracles Od. 21.24, 37.
The home of Othryoneus of unknown site
Καβησόθεν [-θεν], from C. Il. 13.363.
(κέντορες ἵππων). The Thebans (see Κάδμος) Il. 4.388, 391, Il. 5.807, Il. 10.288: Od. 11.276.
Traditional founder of Thebes-1 (but see under Θῆβαι-1). Father of Ino and Semele Od. 5.333.
A Carian woman Il. 4.142.
Patr. fr. next. Of Coronus Il. 2.746.
Father of Coronus. A warrior of Nestor's youth Il. 1.264.
‘Evil Ilius.’ App. formed by Penelope Od. 19.260, 597, Od. 23.19.
Charioteer of Axylus. S. Diomedes Il. 7.18.
Patr. of Aphareus Il. 13.541.
T. Son of Clytius-1. S. Aias-1 Il. 15.419.
A Nereid Il. 18.46.
A Nereid Il. 18.44.
A Locrian town Il. 2.531.
A hill or mound on the Trojan plain of uncertain site Od. 3.53, 151.
A group of Aegean islands, part of the Sporades Il. 2.677.
(αἰπεινή, ἐραννή, πετρήεσσα). A town of Aetolia Il. 2.640; the scene of the strife of the Couretes and the Aetolians Il. 9.530, 531, 577; Il. 13.217, Il. 14.116.

(δεινὴ φεὰ?̔αὐδήεσσἀ, δῖα?̔φεάων̓, δολόεσσα, ἠΰκομος, ἐϋπλόκαμος, νύμφη, πότνια). Daughter of Atlas; dwelt in the Ogygian island. Odysseus reaches her island and is detained by her there Od. 12.448; Od. 1.14, Od. 4.557, Od. 5.14, Od. 6.245, 254, Od. 21.452, Od. 9.29, Od. 12.389, Od. 17.143, Od. 23.333; at the bidding of Hermes sent by Zeus she dispatches him to Phaeacia Od. 5.78, 85, 116, 180, 202, 242, 246, 258, 263, 276, 321, 372, Od. 6.260.

(οἰωνοπόλων ὄχ̓ ἄριστος). Patr. Θεστορίδης-1. The chief Greek seer. Having invoked the protection of Achilles against Agamemnon Il. 1.69, 86, declares Apollo's purpose 92, Agamemnon's reply 105; C.'s prophecy at Aulis Il. 2.300, 322; Il. 13.45, 70.
(ἀργινόεις). A town of Rhodes Il. 2.656.
(ἀγακλειτός, κυδάλιμος). Father of Sthenelus-1 Il. 2.564, Il. 4.403, Il. 5.319.
Patr. fr. prec. Of Sthenelus-1 Il. 5.109.
Adj. fr. Καπανεύς. Of Sthenelus-1 Il. 4.367, Il. 5.108, 241.
Son of Assaracus and father of Anchises Od. 3.239.
A town of Pylus Il. 9.150, 292.
T (βαρβαρόφωνοι). The Carians, a people of s.w. Asia Minor about the Maeander Il. 2.867, Il. 10.428.
An unknown river Il. 12.20.
A town of Euboea Il. 2.539.
An Aegean island, one of the Sporades Il. 2.676.

(Πριάμοιο θυγατρῶν εἶδος ἀρίστη, ἰκέλη χρυσέῃ Ἀφροδίτη). Daughter of Priam and Hecabe. Sought in marriage by Othryoneus Il. 13.366; was the first to see her father approaching with Hector's corpse Il. 24.699: her murder Od. 11.422.
(καλή, δέμας ἐϊκυῖα θεῇσιν). Married from Aesyme. Mother by Priam of Gorgythion Il. 21.305.

div1.head: Κάστωρ-1
div1.p: (ἰππόδαμος, κρατερόφρων). Son of Tyndareus and Leda, brother of Polydeuces and Clytaemnestra and half-brother of Helen. H. misses him and his brother Polydeuces from the Greek host Il. 3.237.
The alternate immortality of C. and P. Od. 11.300.

div1.head: Κάστωρ-2.
div1.p: Patr. ̔γλακίδης. An alleged noble of Crete said by Odysseus in his tale to Eumaeus to be his father Od. 14.204.

div2.p: An unknown people on the Trojan side Il. 10.429, Od. 3.329.
(μεγάθυμοι) A people said to be in debt to Mentor-2 Od. 3.366.

div1.p: A river flowing by Ephesus and into the Aegean Il. 2.461.
Patr. of Troezenus Il. 2.847.

(δαί͂φρων). Bastard son of Priam. Acts as chariot-driver to Hector Il. 8.318, Il. 11.521, Il. 12.91, 92, Il. 16.727; Il. 13.790; s. Patroclus Il. 16.738, the fight over his body 751, 754, 756, 759, 772, 781.
(ὠκύροος). An unknown river, app. on the borders of Pylus and Arcadia Il. 6.133.

called also Φῆρες Il. 1.268, Il. 2.743 (λαχνήεντες, ὀρεσκῷοι). A savage race (but see Χείρων) app. inhabiting the regions about Pelion (Il. 2.744, Il. 16.143, Il. 19.390). Contrasted with ἄνδρες Od. 21.303. Fought with by Nestor in his youth Il. 1.268; through the evil acts of Eurytion punished by Peirithous Il. 2.743: Od. 21.295, 303.
In sing., of Eurytion Od. 21.295.
G (μεγάθυμοι). Etymologically the people of Cephallenia (Same). The general name of the peoples over whom Odysseus ruled Il. 2.631, Il. 4.330; Od. 20.210, Od. 24.355, 378, 429.
(ἔφαλος). A town of Euboea Il. 2.538.
A Mysian people Od. 11.521.
λίμνη= L. Copais Il. 5.709.
(δῖος). A river of Phocis Il. 2.522, 523.
T (αἰχμηταί). A Thracian people dwelling under Mt. Ismarus Il. 2.846, Il. 17.73: their town Ismarus raided by Odysseus Od. 9.39, 47, 59, 66, 165, Od. 23.310.
The inhabitants of Thebe-2 Il. 7.397, 415.
(ζαφέη). Prob. at the head of the Gulf of Adramyttium Il. 1.38, 452.
A people dwelling in darkness on the borders of Ocean. Visited by Odysseus Od. 11.14.
Of Cyprus. His gift of a breastplate to Agamemnon Il. 11.20.

(ἀθανάτη, Αἰαίη, δεινὴ θεὸς αὐδήεσσα, ἐϋπλόκαμος, πολυφάρμακος, πότνια). Daughter of Eelius and Perse and sister of Aeetes. Her island reached by Odysseus and his surviving comrades Od. 10.135, half the force led by Eurylochus to her house 203, all but E. turned by her into swine 233, O. proceeds to the house 261, Hermes meets and instructs him 275, he is not affected by C.'s enchantments 314, his transformed comrades restored 388, he brings his other comrades from the ship 406; after a year C. dispatches him and his comrades to the Shades 488; she receives them on their return Od. 12.16, gives directions for their further voyage 37, they leave the island 144; etc.
Patr. fr. next. Of Theano Il. 7.299.
Κισσεύς. Father of Theano and maternal grandfather of Iphidamas. Brought up I. in Thrace Il. 11.223.

div1.head: Κλεῖτος-1
div1.p: (ἀγαυός). Son of Peisenor-1 and comrade of Poulydamas. S. Teucrus Il. 15.445.

div1.head: Κλεῖτος-2.
div1.p: Son of Mantius Od. 15.249; carried off by Eos Od. 15.250.
T. S. Aias-2 Il. 16.330.
(ἐΰζωνος, καλή). Called also Alcyone. Daughter of Ides and Marpessa and wife of Meleagrus Il. 9.556, she prevails on M. to beat off the Couretes Il. 9.590.
(ἐϋκτίμεναι). A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.570.
A leader of the Boeotians Il. 2.495; s. Agenor Il. 15.340.

div1.head: Κλυμένη-1
div1.p: (βοῶπις). A handmaid of Helen at Troy Il. 3.144.

div1.head: Κλυμένη-2.
div1.p: A Nereid Il. 18.47.

div1.head: Κλυμένη-3.
div1.p: Wife of Phylacus-2 and mother of Iphiclus-1 Od. 11.326.
Father of Eurydice Od. 3.452.

(δῖα, δολόμητις). Daughter of Tyndareus and Leda, sister of Castor-1 and Polydeuces, half-sister of Helen, and wife of Agamemnon, A. prefers Chryseis to her Il. 1.113: her treachery to A. and his murder and the murder of Cassandra Od. 3.266, Od. 11.409, 422, 439, Od. 24.199.

div1.head: Κλυτίδης-1.
div1.p: Patr. of Dolops-1 Il. 11.302.

div1.head: Κλυτίδης-2.
div1.p: Patr. fr. Κλυτίος-2. Of Peiraeus Od. 15.540.

div1.head: Κλυτίος-1.
div1.p: Son of Laomedon and father of Caletor Il. 3.147, Il. 15.419, 427, Od. 3.238.

div1.head: Κλυτίος-2.
div1.p: Father of Peiraeus Od. 16.327.
Son of Enops-2. Nestor beat him at boxing Il. 23.634.
(ἀμύμων, ἀντίθεος). Son of Alcinous Od. 8.119, 123.
See Lexicon.
(εὐρεῖα, μεγάλη πόλις). The chief town of Crete Il. 2.646; Ariadne's dancing-floor there Il. 18.591: the seat of Minos Od. 19.178.

div1.head: Κοίρανος-1
div1.p: T. S. Odysseus Il. 5.677.

div1.head: Κοίρανος-2.
div1.p: Chariot-driver to Meriones. Saves M.'s life but loses his own Il. 17.611, 614.
Father of Periphetes-2. Carried orders to Heracles from Eurystheus Il. 15.639.
πέτρη. A rock in Ithaca near the dwelling of Eumaeus and the spring Arethousa Od. 13.408.
(ἀφνειός). Corinth. In Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.570.
Κορινθόθι [-θι], at C. Il. 13.664.
A Boeotian town Il. 2.503.
(ὑπέρθυμος). Patr. Καινεΐδης. Son of Caeneus and father of Leonteus Il. 2.746.
A people, app. neighbours of the Aetolians. They joined with them in hunting the Calydonian boar, but strife arose over the division of the spoils Il. 9.529, 532, 549, 551, 589.
T (ἀριδείκετος ἀνδρῶν). Patr. Ἀντηνορίδης. Son of Antenor. Avenging his brother Iphidamas wounds Agamemnon Il. 11.248, Il. 19.53; s. A. Il. 11.256.
An island not identified Il. 3.445.
Later Κάρπαθος, an Aegean island, one of the Sporades Il. 2.676.
Mother of Scylla Od. 12.124.
Patr. fr. next. Of Lycomedes Il. 19.240.

div1.head: Κρείων-1.
div1.p: Father of Lycomedes Il. 9.84.

div1.head: Κρείων-2
div1.p: (ὑπέρθυμος). King of Thebes-1 (not the same as the kinsman of Oedipus) and father of Megare Od. 11.269.
Patr. Αἰολίδης. Husband of Tyro and father of Aeson, Phe=res and Amythaon Od. 11.237, 258.
Son of Diocles. With his brother Ortilochus-4 s. Aeneas Il. 5.542, 549.

Κρῆται Od. 14.199, Od. 16.62 (ἑκατόμπολις, εὐρεῖα, καλή, περίρρυτος, πίειρα). Crete Il. 2.649; the realm of Minos Il. 13.450, 453: Od. 3.191, 291, Od. 11.323; in Odysseus's tale to Athene Od. 13.256, 260; in his tale to Eumaeus Od. 14.199, 252, 300, 301, Od. 16.62, Od. 17.523; in his tale to Penelope Od. 19.172, 338.
Κρήτηνδε [-δε], to C. Od. 19.186.
Κρήτηθεν [-θεν], from C. Il. 3.233.
(ζαθέη). A town of Phocis Il. 2.520.
T. S. Meges Il. 15.523.
App. a town of Ithaca Il. 2.633.

Genit. Κρονίονος Il. 14.247: Od. 11.620. Κρονίωνος Il. 21.184, 230: Od. 8.289. Dat. Κρονίωνι Il. 1.397, Il. 2.102, etc. Acc. Κρονίωνα Il. 1.502, Il. 2.350, etc.: Od. 14.406, Od. 24.472. Patr. of next. Of Zeus Il. 1.528, Il. 2.419, Il. 5.753, Il. 7.267, Il. 6.194, Il. 21.175, etc.: Od. 1.386, Od. 3.88, Od. 4.207, Od. 10.21, etc.

(ἀγκυλομήτης, μέγας). A Titan, son of Uranus and Ge, and by Rhea father of Zeus, Hades, Poseidon, Hera and Demeter Il. 2.205, Il. 4.59; in Tartarus Il. 21.479, Il. 14.203, 274, Il. 15.225; his sons enumerated Il. 15.187; etc.: Od. 21.415.
Χαλκίς-3. Places passed by Telemachus on his return from Pylus Od. 15.295.
A Paphlagonian town Il. 2.855.

See Ἀκτορίων, Μολίων-2. Son (with Eurytus-2) of Poseidon (Il. 11.751). Father of Amphimachus-1 Il. 2.621, Il. 13.185; in Nestor's tale of the fighting between the Pylians and the Epeians Il. 11.709, 750; at the funeral games of Amarynceus Il. 23.638.
(ἐπιείκελος ἀθανάτοισιν). Patr. Ὀρμενίδης. Named as ruler of the island Syria and father of Eumaeus Od. 15.414.

(ἀθεμίστια εἰδώς, φιλοκέρτομος). Patr. Πολυθερσεΐδης. A suitor. Dwelt in Same Od. 20.288; throws an ox's foot at the disguised Odysseus Od. 20.292, 303, 304; wounds Eumaeus Od. 22.279, s. Philoetius 285.
(ἰφθίμη, τανύπεπλος). Daughter of Laertes and Anticleia and sister of Odysseus Od. 15.363.
A people represented by Menelaus as dwelling by the Iardanus-2 Od. 3.292; in Odysseus's tale to Penelope one of the five divisions of the inhabitants of Crete Od. 19.176.
See Ἀφροδίτη.
τά?̔ζάθεἀ. An island off the s.e. extremity of the Peloponnesus Il. 15.432: Od. 9.81.
Κυθηρόθεν [-θεν], from C. Il. 15.438.
Adj. fr. prec. Il. 10.268, Il. 15.431.

(ἀθέμιστοι, ὑπερηνορέοντες, ὑπερφίαλοι). A gigantic and savage race, represented (Od. 6.206) as being with the giants near the
gods. Their manners described Od. 9.106; an island off their land described Od. 9.116; Odysseus lands on the island Od. 9.142; goes in his ship to visit the Cyclopes Od. 9.177; etc.
See further under Πολύφημος-1.
(ὄρος αἰπύ). A mountain of n. Arcadia, sacred to Hermes Il. 2.603.

div1.head: Κυλλήνιος-1.
div1.p: Adj. fr. prec. Of Hermes Od. 24.1.

div1.head: Κυλλήνιος-2.
div1.p: Adj. fr. Κυλλήνη, a town of Elis Il. 15.518.
Κυμοθόη. Nereids Il. 18.39, 41.
A Locrian town Il. 2.531.
A town of Pylus Il. 2.593.
A town of Phocis Il. 2.519.
App. fr. next. See Ἀφροδίτη.
Cyprus. Visited by Menelaus Od. 4.83; its town Paphos a seat of Aphrodite Od. 8.362; its king Dmetor (according to Odysseus) Od. 17.442, 443; Od. 17.448.
Κύπρονδε [-δε], to (i.e. from as far as) C. Il. 11.21.
A Paphlagonian town Il. 2.853.
A town of the Peraebians Il. 2.748.
Πυριφλεγέθων. Rivers of the underworld flowing into the Acheron, the A. being a tributary of the Styx Od. 10.513, 514.
A Boeotian town Il. 2.502.
(εὖ ναιομένη). An Aegean island, one of the Sporades Il. 2.677.
Κόωνδε [-δε], to C. Il. 14.255 Ο 28.
A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.585.

div1.head: Λαέρκης-1.
div1.p: Patr. Αἱμονίδης-2. Father of Alcimedon Il. 16.197, Il. 17.467.

div1.head: Λαέρκης-2.
div1.p: A goldsmith at Pylus Od. 3.425.

(μεγαλήτωρ, πεπνυμένος). Only son of Arceisius, husband of Anticleia and father of Odysseus and Ctimene Od. 1.189, Od. 2.99, Od. 4.111, Od. 8.18, Od. 14.9, Od. 15.353; his parentage and offspring Od. 16.118; Od. 22.185; Odysseus tries him Od. 24.226, he slays Eupeithes 520; etc.
Fem. adj. = next Od. 10.82, Od. 23.318.
Of or pertaining to the Laestrygonians, a gigantic and savage race visited by Odysseus. Of their king Od. 10.106, 199.
In pl., the Laestrygonians (ἴφθιμοι) Od. 10.119.
All O.'s ships but his own destroyed by them Od. 10.121.
(δῖα, ἐρατεινή, εὐρύχορος, κητώεσσα, κοίλη)

div2.p: The realm of Menelaus in general Il. 2.581, Il. 3.239, 244, 443: Od. 4.1, Od. 21.13.

div1.p: See Ἀντιφάτης-2.
Patr. fr. Λάμπος-1. Of Dolops-2 Il. 15.526.
(νύμφη ἐϋπλόκαμος, τανύπεπλος). Daughter of Eelius and Neaera. With Phaethousa in charge of the oxen of the Sun Od. 12.132, 375.

div1.head: Λάμπος-1
div1.p: T. Patr. Λαομεδοντιάδης. Son of Laomedon and father of Dolops-2 Il. 3.147, Il. 15.526, Od. 3.238.

div1.head: Λάμπος-2
div1.p: (δῖος). One of Hector's horses Il. 21.185.

div1.head: Λάμπος-3.
div1.p: One of the horses of the Dawn Od. 23.246.

div1.head: Λαόγονος-1
div1.p: T. (θρασύς). Son of Onetor. S. Meriones Il. 16.604.

div1.head: Λαόγονος-2
div1.p: T. Son of Bias-3. S. Achilles Od. 3.460.

div1.head: Λαοδάμας-1
div1.p: (ἀγλαός). Son of Antenor. S. Aias-1 Il. 15.516.

div1.head: Λαοδάμας-2
div1.p: (ἀγαθός, ἀγαπήνωρ, ἀμύμων). Son of Alcinous Od. 6.170, Od. 8.117, 119, 130, 132, 141, 153, 207, 370.
Daughter of Bellerophon and by Zeus mother of Sarpedon Il. 7.197, 198; slain by Artemis Il. 7.205.

div1.head: Λαοδίκη-1.
div1.p: The fairest of the daughters of Priam and Hecabe and wife of Helicaon Il. 3.124, Il. 7.252.

div1.head: Λαοδίκη-2.
div1.p: Daughter of Agamemnon Il. 9.145, 287.

div1.head: Λαοδόκος-1
div1.p: T. (κρατερὸς αἰχμητής). Patr. Ἀντηνορίδης. Son of Antenor Il. 4.87.
(κρείουσα γυναικῶν). Daughter of Altes and mother by Priam of Lycaon-2 and Polydorus-1 Il. 21.85, Il. 22.48.
Patr. fr. next. Of Priam Il. 3.250.
Of Lampus-1 Il. 15.527.

(ἀγαυός, ἀγήνωρ, ἀμύμων). Son of Ilus-1 and father of Priam, Tithonus, Lampus-1, Clytius-1 and Hicetaon, also of Boucolion (bastard). His horses Il. 5.269, Il. 23.348; wronged Heracles in a matter of horses Il. 5.640, 649; Il. 6.453; wronged Poseidon and Apollo Il. 21.443, 452.
(αἰχμηταί). A Thessalian race. Peirithous and Polypoetes of this race Il. 12.128, 181 (cf. Il. 2.743): strife between the Lapithae and the Centaurs Od. 21.297.
(ἐριβῶλαξ). Prob. a maritime town on the w. of the southern Troad Il. 2.841, Il. 17.301.
See Ληώδης.

div1.head: Λειώκριτος-1
div1.p: G. Son of Arisbas and comrade of Lycomedes. S. Aeneas Il. 17.344.

div1.head: Λειώκριτος-2.
div1.p: See Ληόκριτος.
A promontory (the s. w. termination of Mt. Ida) forming the s. w. angle of the Troad Il. 14.284.
T. (φιλοπτόλεμοι). The inhabitants of Pedasus-2 Il. 10.429, Od. 3.96, Il. 21.86.

(ἀντίθεος, βροτολοιγῷ ἶσος Ἄρηϊ, κρατερός, ὄζος Ἄρηος). A Lapith. Son of Coronus and with Polypoetes leader of the men of Argissa, etc. Il. 2.745; his defence with P. of the wall Il. 12.130, 188; is third in putting the weight Il. 23.837, 841.
-ίδος. Adj. fr. next. Absol., a Lesbian woman Il. 9.129, 271.

(ἐϋκτιμένη). The Aegean island. The island (or more prob. the town thereof) taken by
Achilles Il. 9.129, 271; Il. 24.544; Od. 3.169, Od. 4.342, Od. 17.133.
Λεσβόθεν [-θεν], from L. Il. 9.664.
πέτρη. The White Rock by which Hermes led the shades of the suitors Od. 24.11.
Od. 5.334. See Ἰνώ.
G. S. Antiphus-3 Il. 4.491.
Wife of Tyndareus and by him mother of Castor-1, Polydeuces and Clytaemnestra Od. 11.298.
Also, by Zeus, mother of Helen Il. 3.236.
Patr. Τευταμίδης. A Pelasgian, father of Hippothous-1 and Pylaeus Il. 2.843, Il. 17.288.
Son of Alectryon. A leader of the Boeotians Il. 2.494; slays Phylacus-1 Il. 7.35; Il. 13.91; wounded by Hector Il. 17.601, 605.

(ἀμιχθαλόεσσα, ἐϋκτιμένη, ἐϋκτίμενον πτολίεθρον, ἠγαθέη). The Aegean island, inhabited by the Sinties. Hephaestus's fall on to it Il. 1.593; Philoctetes left there Il. 2.722; Euneus sends wine from it to the Greeks Il. 6.467; Il. 21.230; its king Thoas-2 Il. 14.230; Hera encounters ̔́γπνος there Il. 14.231, 281; Lycaon-2 sold into slavery there to Euneus Il. 21.40, 46, 58, 79; Il. 24.753: a seat of Hephaestus Od. 8.283, 294, 301.
Λειώκριτος-2. Patr. Εὐηνορίδης. A suitor. Answers Mentor-2 in the assembly Od. 2.242; s. Telemachus Od. 22.294.

(Διὸς κυδρὴ παράκοιτις, ἐρικυδής, ἠΰκομος, καλλιπάρῃος). Mother by Zeus of Apollo and Artemis Il. 1.9, 36, Il. 5.447, Il. 14.327, Il. 16.849, Il. 19.413, Od. 3.40, 72; in the Battle of the Gods Hermes declines a fight with her Il. 21.497, 498, 502; her revenge on Niobe Il. 24.607: Od. 7.106, Od. 11.318; Tityus laid violent hands on her Od. 11.580.
Λειώδης. A suitor, son of Oenops. The suitors) seer; abstained from evil. The first to try the bow Od. 21.144, 168; appeals to Odysseus for mercy Od. 22.310, but is slain 320.
Libya, a country in the n. of Africa. Visited by Menelaus, described Od. 4.85; Od. 14.295.
(ὄζος Ἄρηος). Maternal uncle of Heracles, slain by Tlepolemus-1 Il. 2.663.
A town of Phocis Il. 2.523.
A Nereid Il. 18.41.
A town of Rhodes Il. 2.656.
G. The (Epicnemidian and Opuntian) Locrians, inhabiting the coast lands facing the s. and s.w. shore of the n.w. end of Euboea Il. 2.527, 535, Il. 13.686; were archers Il. 13.712.
(ἀργινόεις). A city of Crete Il. 2.647.

div1.head: Λυκάων-2.
div1.p: Patr. Πριαμίδης. Son of Priam and Laothoe and brother of Polydorus-1 Il. 3.333; Apollo takes his form in inciting Aeneas Od. 3.81; sold into slavery at Lemnos to Euneus but ransomed by Eetion-3 Il. 21.40; Achilles comes upon him at the river and slays him Il. 21.35, 116, 127; Il. 22.46, Il. 23.746.
See Lexicon.
Λυκίηνδε [-δε], to L. Il. 7.168, 171.
Λυκίηθεν [-θεν], from L. Il. 5.105.

T. (ἀντίθεοι, ἀσπισταί, ἴφθιμοι, πύκα θωρηκταί). The Lycians, a people of s. w. Asia Minor (s.e. of the Carians) through whose territory the Xanthus-2 ran Il. 2.876, Il. 4.197, Il. 5.482; many slain by Odysseus Il. 5.676; Il. 10.430, Il. 12.315, Il. 16.421; etc.
G (ἀρηΐφιλος, δῖος, κρατερός). Patr. Κρειοντιάδης. Son of Creion-1 Il. 9.84, Il. 12.366; slays Apisaon-2 Il. 17.345, 346; Il. 19.240.

div1.head: Λυκόοργος-1
div1.p: Λύκουργος (ἀνδροφόνος, κρατερός). Son of Dryas-2. Scattered Dionysus and his attendants Il. 7.130, 134, his consequent fate 138.

div1.head: Λυκόοργος-2.
div1.p: Slew Areithous-1 Il. 6.142, 144, gave A.'s armour to Ereuthalion 148.
T. (ἀντίθεος). S. Teucrus Il. 21.275.
Patr. Μαστορίδης-2. Son of Mastor. From Cythera, a follower of Aias-1. S. Hector Il. 15.430.
(ἐϋκτιμένη). A city of Crete Il. 2.647, Il. 17.611.
T. S. Peneleos Il. 16.335, 337.
A town of the southern Troad perh. to be identified with the later Antandros. Taken by Achilles and its king Munes slain and Briseis captured Il. 2.690, 691, Il. 19.60, Od. 3.92, 191.
T. S. Aias-1 Il. 11.491.
The lotus-eaters. Visited by Odysseus Od. 9.84, 91, 92, 96, Od. 23.311.
G. The men of Magnesia described as dwelling about the Peneius and Pelion, led by Prothous Il. 2.756.
A river of Asia Minor falling into the Aegean near Mycale Il. 2.869.
(Μαῖα). Mother by Zeus of Hermes Od. 14.435.
Patr. of Peisandrus-3 Il. 16.194.

div1.head: Μαῖρα-1.
div1.p: A nymph of Artemis, slain by her for an amour with Zeus Od. 11.326.
(ἐπιείκελος ἀθανάτοισιν). Patr. Αἱμονίδης-1. With Polyphontes leader of the ambush at Thebes-1 against Tydeus Il. 4.394, the only survivor 398.
King of Lesbos Il. 24.544.
The s.e. extremity of the Peloponnesus Od. 9.80.
So Μάλειαι Od. 3.287, Od. 4.514, Il. 19.187.
(ἐρατεινή). A town of Arcadia Il. 2.607.
(κραταιός). Son of Melampus and father of Polypheides and Cleitus-2 Od. 15.242, 249.
A district n.e. of Athens facing Euboea Od. 6.80.
T. (ἀκοντιστής). Son of Amisodarus and brother of Atymnius. S. Thrasymedes Il. 16.319.
(καλλίσφυρος). Patr. Εὐηνίνη. Wife of Ides and mother of Cleopatra Il. 9.557.
Son of Euanthes and priest of Apollo at Ismarus. His gifts to Odysseus Od. 9.197.
A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.562.

div1.head: Μαστορίδης-1.
div1.p: Patr. of Halitherses Od. 2.158, Od. 24.452.

div1.head: Μαστορίδης-2
div1.p: Patr. fr. next. Of Lycophron Il. 15.438.
Father of Lycophron Il. 15.430.

(ἰητὴρ ἀγαθός, ποιμὴν λαῶν). Patr. Ἀσκληπιάδης. Son of Asclepius. With his brother Podaleirius chief surgeon of the Greeks and leader of the men of Tricca, etc. Il. 2.732; summoned to attend the wounded Menelaus Il. 4.193, 200; wounded by Paris Il. 11.506, but rescued by Nestor 512, 517, 598, 613, in Nestor's hut 618, 651, Il. 14.3; Il. 11.833.
Patr. of Perimus Il. 16.695.
(κρατερός). Son of Menelaus by a δούλη. His marriage to a daughter of Alector Od. 4.11; Od. 15.100, 103, 122.
Daughter of Creion-2 and the first wife of Heracles Od. 11.269.

(ἀτάλαντος Ἄρηϊ, δουρικλυτός). Patr. Φυλεΐδης. Son of Phyleus and leader of the men of Doulichium and the Echinean Islands Il. 2.627; slays Pedaeus Il. 5.69; leading the Epeians Il. 13.692; Il. 15.302; slays Croesmus Il. 15.520; Il. 15.535; slays Amphiclus Il. 16.313; Il. 19.239.
(ἐϋκτίμενον πτολίεθρον). A Boeotian town Il. 2.501.

div1.head: Μέδων-1
div1.p: G. Bastard son of Oileus-1 by Rhene and brother of Aias-2. Takes the place of Philoctetes as leader of the men of Methone, etc. Il. 2.727, Il. 13.693 (his followers here called Φθῖοι); dwelt in Phylace a fugitive, having slain a kinsman of his stepmother Eriopis Il. 13.695, Il. 15.334; s. Aeneas Il. 15.332.

div1.head: Μέδων-3
div1.p: (πεπνυμένα εἰδώς). A herald of Odysseus left by him at home. Tells Penelope of the plot against her son's life Od. 4.677, 696, 711, Od. 16.412; consorted with the suitors Od. 16.252; their favourite herald Od. 17.172; spared by Odysseus Od. 22.357, 361; his advice to the people Od. 24.439, 442.

(μάντις ἀμύμων). Son of Amythaon and father of Antiphates-3 and Mantius. As the price of the hand of Pero undertook to drive off the oxen of Iphiclus-1 Od. 11.291, but was put in bonds by Ι. 292, his release 294; he drove off the oxen Od. 15.235; while in bonds had been wronged by Neleus Od. 15.230, avenged himself and gave Pero to his brother (who was named Bias) 236, fled to Argos-1 (1) 238, where he married 241.
Father of Amphimedon Od. 24.103.

div1.head: Μελάνθιος-1
div1.p: or Μελανθεύς, Od. 17.212, Od. 20.255, Od. 21.176, Od. 22.152, 159. (αἰπόλος αἰγῶν.) Odysseus's goatherd, son of Dolius-2. Maltreats and abuses the disgnised O. Od. 17.212, Od. 20.1731; Od. 17.247, 369, Od. 20.255, Od. 21.175, 176, 181, 265, Od. 22.135; brings armour and arms to the suitors Od. 22.142, 152, 159, 161; his punishment Od. 22.182, 195, 474.

div1.head: Μελάνθιος-2
div1.p: T. S. Eurypylus-2 Il. 7.36.
(καλλιπάρῃος). An unfaithful hand maid, daughter of Dolius-2. Abuses the disguised Odysseus Od. 18.321, Od. 19.65; rebuked by Penelope Od. 19.89.

div1.head: Μελάνιππος-1
div1.p: T. S. Teucrus Il. 8.276.

div1.head: Μελάνιππος-2
div1.p: T (ἴφθιμος, ὑπέρθυμος). Patr. Ἱκεταονίδης. Son of Hicetaon Il. 15.547, 553; s. Antilochus Il. 15.576, 582.

div1.head: Μελάνιππος-3
div1.p: T. S. Patroclus Il. 16.695.
Son of Portheus Il. 14.117.

(ἀρηΐφιλος, ξανθός). Son of Oeneus and Althaea and husband of Cleopatra. Died before the Trojan war Il. 2.642; killed the Calydonian boar Il. 9.543, strife having arisen with the Couretes conceived anger against his mother and would fight no more 550, 553, persuaded by his wife beats the Couretes off 590.
A town in the realm of Philoctetes n. of the Boebean Lake Il. 2.717.
A Nereid Il. 18.42.
(ἀγλαός, δῖος). Son of Tithonus and Eos. Slew Antilochus Od. 4.188; his beauty Od. 11.522.

(ἀγαθός, ἀγακλεής, ἀμύμων, ἄναξ, ἀντίθεος, ἀρήϊος, ἀρηΐφιλος, βοὴν ἀγαθός, διοτρεθής, δουρικλειτός, ἴφθιμος, κοσμήτωρ λαῶν, κυδάλιμος, ξανθός, ὄρχαμος λαῶν). Patr. Ἀτρεΐδης. King of Lacedaemon. Son of Atreus, brother of Agamemnon, husband of Helen and father by her of Hermione; father also of Megapenthes. His followers enumerated Il. 2.581; had often entertained Idomeneus Il. 3.232; fights Paris Il. 3.340, P. withdrawn by Aphrodite 380; M. wounded by Pandarus Il. 4.127, tended by Machaon 210; takes and spares Adrestus-3 Il. 7.37, but Agamemnon slays him 63; ready to accept Hector's challenge Il. 6.94, but is dissuaded 104; cannot sleep and joins Agamemnon in rousing the chiefs Il. 10.25; with Aias-1 comes to the rescue of Odysseus Il. 11.465; wounds Helenus-1 Il. 13.581, kills Peisandrus-2 601; bestrides the corpse of Patroclus Il. 17.1, kills Euphorbus 45, retires before Hector 108, returns with Aias-1 124, Hector retires before them 129, he shouts for help 248, Athene in the guise of Phoenix-1 urges him on 556, he kills Podes 575, dispatches Antilochus to Achilles 685, the corpse is at last rescued Il. 18.231; takes part in the chariot-race Il. 23.293, Antilochus gains the advantage of him 417, he comes in third 514, accuses A. of foul driving 566, A. pacifies him 586; etc. : after the taking of Troy advised, opposing Agamemnon, a return home at once Od. 3.141, sailed accordingly 157; the death of his steersman off Sounium Od. 3.278; receives Telemachus hospitably at Sparta Od. 4.1, tells him his adventures 333; speeds him home with gifts Od. 15.68; etc.
(δῖος, μεγάθυμος, πλήξιππος). Son of Peteos and leader of the Athenians Il. 2.552, Il. 4.327; in charge of part of the wall Il. 12.331, 373; Il. 13.195, 690, Il. 15.331.
G (εἰδὼς χάρμης). With his brother Anchialus-1 s. Hector Il. 5.609.

div1.head: Μενέσθιος-1
div1.p: G. Son of Areithous-1 and Phylomedousa. Dwelt at Arne. S. Paris Il. 6.9.

div1.head: Μενέσθιος-2
div1.p: (αἰολοθώρηξ). Son of the Spercheius and Polydore, nominally son of Borus-2. A leader under Achilles Il. 16.173.

Son of Actor-2 and father of Patroclus Il. 9.202, Il. 11.605; his charge to his son Il. 11.765, 771, 785; Il. 11.814, 837, Il. 12.1, Il. 16.14, 278, 307, 626, 665, 827, Il. 18.12; Achilles' promise to him Il. 18.324; Il. 18.455, Il. 19.24; brought his son from his home in Opoeis to the house of Peleus Il. 23.85.

div1.head: Μέντης-1.
div1.p: Leader of the Cicones. In his guise Apollo urges Hector to avenge Euphorbus Il. 17.73.

div1.head: Μέντης-2.
div1.p: Son of Anchialus-2 and king of the Taphians. In his guise Athene appears to Telemachus Od. 1.105, 180, 418.

div1.head: Μέντωρ-1
div1.p: (πολύϊππος). Father of Imbrius-1 Il. 13.171.

div1.head: Μέντωρ-2
div1.p: Patr. Ἀλκιμίδης. A comrade of Odysseus in Ithaca left in charge of O.'s house and property. His speech in the Ithacan assembly Od. 2.225; Athene takes his guise Od. 2.267 (urging Telemachus to go to Pylus and Sparta), 416 (accompanying T.), Od. 22.206 (in the fight with the suitors), Od. 24.502 (in the fight with the Ithacans); etc.
T. S. Leonteus Il. 12.193.
Patr. of Ilus-2 Od. 1.259.
T. S. Antilochus Il. 14.513.
Of Percote. Father of Adrestus-2 and Amphius-1 Il. 2.831, Il. 11.329.
A servant bought by Eumaeus with his own funds from the Taphians Od. 14.449, 455.
Son of Talaemenes and a leader of the Maeonians (Μῄονες) Il. 2.864, Il. 17.216.
(πολυτρήρων). A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.582.
A fountain in Greece of unknown site Il. 7.457.
A town (no doubt maritime) app. in the later Messenia Od. 21.15.
The men of prec. Od. 21.18.
Bastard daughter of Priam. Wife of Imbrius-1 Il. 13.173.
A town in the realm of Philoctetes on the e. shore of the Pagasaean Gulf Il. 2.716.

div1.head: Μηκιστεύς-1
div1.p: (ἄναξ). Patr. Ταλαϊονίδης. Father of Euryalus-1 Il. 2.566; he overcame all in the funeral games of Oedipus Il. 23.678.

div1.head: Μηκιστεύς-2
div1.p: Son of Echius-1. Assists Alastor-1 in carrying off the wounded Teucrus Il. 8.333, and Hypsenor-2 Il. 13.422; s. Poulydamas Il. 15.339.
Patr. fr. Μηκιστεύς-1. Of Euryalus-1 Il. 7.28.
(ἐρατεινή). The land of the Maeonians Il. 3.401, Il. 18.291.
A Maeonian woman Il. 4.142.
a Maeonian, one of a people in the basin of the Hermus and the plain of Sardis Il. 5.43.
Μῄονες Τ (ἱπποκορυσταί). The Maeonians Il. 2.864, 866, Il. 10.431.

(ἀγὸς ἀνδρῶν, ἀτάλαντος Ἐνυαλίῳ ἀνδρειφόντῃ, δαΐφρων, δουρικλυτός, ἐΰς, θοῷ ἀτάλαντος Ἄρηϊ, μήστωρ ἀϋτῆς, πεπνυμένος). Son of Molus and traditionally nephew of Idomeneus. ὀπάων of I. and joined with him in the leadership of the Cretans Il. 2.651, Il. 6.165; kills Phereclus Il. 5.59; accepts Hector's challenge but does not get the lot Il. 6.166; kills Adamas Il. 13.567, and Harpalion 650, and Morys and Hippotion Il. 14.514, and Acamas-1 Il. 16.342, and Laogonus-1 Il. 16.603, Aeneas misses him 608; superintends the bringing of wood for the pyre of Patroclus Il. 23.113; takes part in the chariot-race Il. 23.351, comes in fourth 528, wins the archery contest 860, receives a consolation prize for spear-throwing, the contest not taking place 884; etc.
(ἀντίθεος). A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.257.
A Boeotian town Il. 2.507.

div1.head: Μίλητος-1
div1.p: A city of Crete Il. 2.647.

div1.head: Μίλητος-2
div1.p: The city of the Carians near the mouth of the Maeander Il. 2.868.
(ἠνεμόεις). A mountain range forming a promontory off which the n. of Chios lies Od. 3.172.
Of the legendary race of the Μινύαι. Of Orchomenus-1 Il. 2.511 : Od. 11.284.
A river of Nestor's realm Il. 11.722.

(ἀγλαός, Διὸς ὀαριστής, ὀλοόφρων). King of Crete. Son of Zeus and Europa (daughter of Phoenix-2), brother of Rhadamanthys and father of Deucalion-1, Ariadne and Phaedra Il. 13.450, 451, Il. 14.322: Od. 11.322; judging among the Shades Od. 11.568; Od. 17.523; reigned in Cnosus Od. 19.178.
T. A Paeonian. S. Achilles Il. 21.210.
See Lexicon.

div1.head: Μολίων-1
div1.p: ̔ἀντίθεος̓. θεράπων to Thymbraeus. S. Odysseus Il. 11.322.

div1.head: Μολίων-2.
div1.p: In form a patr.; but see under Ἀκτορίων. Of Cteatus and Eurytus-2 Il. 11.709, 750.
Father of Meriones. Traditionally a son of Deucalion-1 and brother of Idomeneus Il. 10.269, Il. 13.249.
T. Came from Ascania, son of Hippotion Il. 13.792; s. Meriones Il. 14.514.

div1.head: Μούλιος-1
div1.p: (αἰχμητής). Son-in-law of Augeias and husband of Agamede. Nestor slew him Il. 11.739.

div1.head: Μούλιος-2
div1.p: T. S. Patroclus Il. 16.696.

div1.head: Μούλιος-3
div1.p: T. S. Achilles Od. 3.472.

div1.head: Μούλιος-4
div1.p: (Δουλιχιεύς). θεράπων of Amphinomus Od. 18.423.
The nine Muses Od. 24.60. See further Μοῦσαι in Lexicon.
(ἀντίθεος). A leader of the Phrygians Il. 3.186.

div1.head: Μύδων-1
div1.p: T. (ἐσθλός). Patr. Ἀτυμνιάδης. Chariot-driver of Pylaemenes. S. Antilochus Il. 5.580.

div1.head: Μύδων-2
div1.p: T. A Paeonian. S. Achilles Il. 21.209.
(αἰπεινή). A promontory of Asia Minor off which the Icarian Samos lies Il. 2.869.
(εὐρύχορος). A Boeotian town Il. 2.498.
See Μυκήνη-1.
Adj. fr. next Il. 15.638.
In pl., the Mycenaeans Il. 15.643.

div1.head: Μυκήνη-1,
div1.p: also Μυκῆναι Il. 2.569, Il. 4.376 (ἐϋκτίμενον πτολίεθρον, εὐρυάγυια, πολύχρυσος). Agamemnon's capital Il. 2.569, Il. 4.52, 376, Il. 6.180, Il. 11.46: Od. 3.304, Od. 21.108.
Μυκήνηθεν [-θεν], from M. Il. 9.44.

div1.head: Μυκήνη-2
div1.p: (ἐϋστέφανος). Said to have been the eponym of prec. Brought into comparison with Penelope Od. 2.120.
(θεῖος, ἐγχεσίμωρος). King of Lyrnessus. Son of Euenus and brother of Epistrophus-2 Il. 2.692, Il. 19.296.
(πολύσκαρθμος) Il. 2.814. Said to have been an Amazon. See Βατίεια.

div2.p: (ἐγχεσίμωροι, μεγαλήτορες, ταχύπωλοι, φιλοπτόλεμοι.) The followers of Achilles at Troy Il. 1.328, Il. 9.185, Il. 11.797, Il. 16.12, Il. 18.10, Il. 19.14, Il. 23.4, Il. 24.449, etc.
Their return Od. 3.188.
Applied with Ἕλληνες and Ἀχαιοί to A. 's followers Il. 2.684.
Distinguished from Ἀχαιοί 564.

div1.p: A town of Elis Il. 2.616.

div1.head: Μυσοί-1
div1.p: T. (ἀγέρωχοι, καρτερόθυμοι). The Mysians, a people e. of the Troad, prob. having the Aesepus-1 as their w. boundary Il. 2.858, Il. 10.430, Il. 14.512, Il. 24.278.

div1.head: Μυσοί-2
div1.p: (ἀγχέμαχοι). A people of the far north beyond Thrace Il. 13.5.
(ἀγλαός). Son of Nomion and a leader of the Carians Il. 2.867, 870, 871.

div1.head: Ναυβολίδης-1.
div1.p: Patr. of Iphitus-1 Il. 2.518.

div1.head: Ναυβολίδης-2.
div1.p: Patr. of Euryalus-2 Od. 8.116.

(θεοειδής, μεγάθυμος). King of the Phaeacians. Son of Poseidon and Periboea-2 and father of Rhexenor and Alcinous. Settled his people in Scheria Od. 7.7; his parentage and progeny Od. 6.56, 62, 63; Od. 8.565.

(εὔπεπλος, λευκώλενος, θεῶν ἄπο κάλλος ἔχουσα). Daughter of Alcinous and Arete. Her dream Od. 7.20; she takes the washing to the river Od. 7.81, she and her maidens play 100, when Odysseus wakens she alone does not flee 139, O. 's appeal to her 149, her reply 187, she encourages her maidens 199, she bids O. prepare to accompany her and gives him counsel and information 255, she leads him to the city 316, her return home Od. 6.2; her farewell to O. Od. 8.457; etc.
A Phaeacian Od. 8.112.
(δῖα). Mother by Eelius of Phaethousa and Lampetie Od. 12.133.

(θεοειδής). The youthful son of Achilles. Brought up in Scyros-1 Il. 19.327 : brought thence by Odysseus Od. 11.506, his exploits at Troy 510, slays Eurypylus-3 520; his marriage to Hermione-1 Od. 4.5.
Adj. fr. Νέστωρ 54, Il. 8.113, 192.
Patr. fr. next. Of Antilochus Il. 7.33, Il. 15.589, Il. 23.353.
Of Thrasymedes Il. 9.81.
In pl. of both Il. 16.317.

(ἀντίθεος, γέρων, Γερήνιος, δῖος, ἡδυεπής, ίππηλάτα, ἱππόδαμος, ἱππότα, λιγὺς Πυλίων ἀγορητής, μεγάθυμος, μέγα κῦδος Ἀχαιῶν, μέγας, οὖρος Ἀχαιῶν, ποιμὴν λαῶν, Πυλοιγενὴς βασιλεύς, ὑπέρθυμος). Patr. Νηλεΐδης, Νηληϊάδης. King of Pylus, son of Neleus, husband of Eurydice and father of Antilochus, Peisistratus, Echephron, Stratius, Perseus-2, Aretus-2 and Thrasymedes. Had reigned already over two generations Il. 1.247; intervenes in the quarrel between Achilles and Agamemnon Il. 1.254; Oneirus appears to Ag. in his form Il. 2.21; he addresses the βουλή Il. 2.77; visited by Ag. in his inspection Il. 4.293; reproaches the Greeks, no champion coming forward against Hector, and tells the tale of the fighting between the Pylians and the Arcadians Il. 6.123; advises the burning of the dead and the building of the wall Il. 6.325; is cut off in the fight Il. 8.80, but is rescued by Diomedes 99; advises the setting of a guard Il. 9.52; advises the restoration of Briseis with gifts Il. 9.94, and the sending of the embassy 162; is wakened by Ag. Il. 10.73, visits the guard 180; carries off the wounded Machaon Il. 11.516; his appeal in his hut to Patroclus and his tale of the fighting between the Pylians and the Epeians Il. 11.655; encounters the wounded chiefs Il. 14.27; his advice to Antilochus before the chariot-race Il. 23.306, is presented by Achilles with a remaining prize 615; etc. : hospitably receives Telemachus at Pylus Od. 3.31, tells, him the tale of his return 102, advises him to go to Menelaus 317, dispatches him 474; restrained the flight of the Greeks when Thetis appeared to take part in the funeral rites of Achilles Od. 24.50; etc.
(ὑλήεν). A mountain in Ithaca Od. 1.186.
In Od. 9.22 u.l. for Νήριτον.
See Νήριτον.
Patr. fr. next. Of Nestor Il. 23.652.

(ἀγαυότατος ζωόντων, ἀμύμων, ἀντίθεος, θεόφιν μήστωρ ἀτάλαντος, κρατερὸς θεράπων Διός, μεγάθυμος). Son (Od. 11.241) of Poseidon and Tyro, husband of Chloris and (Od. 11.285) father of Nestor, Chromius-1, Periclymenus and Pero (in Il. 11.692 he is said to have had twelve sons) Il. 11.683, 717 : Od. 3.4, 409, Od. 11.254, 281; his requirement of Pero's suitors Od. 11.288; his treatment of Melampus Od. 15.229, 233.
Adj. fr. Νηλεύς 597, 682 : Od. 4.639.
Of Nestor Il. 2.20, Il. 10.18, Il. 23.349.
Of Antilochus Il. 23.514.
A Nereid Il. 18.46.
See Lexicon. Νηρεύς͂ the ἅλιος γέρων of Il. 1.556 : Od. 24.58, and the πατὴρ γέρων and γέρων ἅλιος of Il. 18.36, 141.
(ἀκτὴ ἠπείροιο, ἐϋκτίμενον πτολίεθρον). Perh. to be identified with the place of the name mentioned in Thuc. iii. 7. 4. How Laertes took the place Od. 24.377.
(εἰνοσίφυλλον, καταειμένον ὕλῃ). A mountain in Ithaca Il. 2.632 : Od. 9.22, Od. 13.351.
In Od. 1.186 u.l. for Νήϊον. Νήριτον and Νήϊον seem to be the same.
See Ἴθακος.
A Nerei Il. 18.40.
(ἠΰκομος). Her children slain by Apollo and Artemis and she herself turned to stone on Mt. Sipylus Il. 24.602, 606.
Son of Charopus and Aglaia and leader of the men of Syme. His beauty Il. 2.671-673.
(ζαθέη). A Boeotian town Il. 2.508.
(ἄναξ, ἀφνειός, Δουλιχιεύς, ἐΰς). Patr. Ἀρητιάδης. Father of Amphinomus Od. 16.395, Od. 18.127, 413.
An Aegean island, one of the Sporades Il. 2.676.

div1.head: Νοήμων-1
div1.p: T. S. Odysseus Il. 5.678.

div1.head: Νοήμων-2
div1.p: A comrade of Antilochus Il. 23.612.

div1.head: Νοήμων-3
div1.p: (φαίδιμος). An Ithacan, son of Phronius. Lent Telemachus a ship Od. 2.386, Od. 4.630, 648.
Father of Nastes and Amphimachus-2 Il. 2.871.
(sc. ὄρος) (ἠγάθεον). Adj. fr. Νύσα, the mythical mountain sacred to Dionysus Il. 7.133.

div1.head: Ξάνθος-1.
div1.p: The divine name of the river of the Trojan plain w. of Troy called (Od. 3.74) by men Σκάμανδρος.
Zeus his father Il. 14.434, Il. 21.2, Il. 24.693.

div2.p: Ξάνθος?̔βαθυδινήεις, βαθυδίνης, δινήεις, ἐϋρρεῖος̓ 4, Il. 8.560; the ford Il. 14.434, Il. 21.2, Il. 24.693; Od. 3.40, Il. 21.15, 146, 332, 337, 383.

Σκάμανδρος?̔βαθυδινήεις, βαθυδίνης, δινήεις, δῖος, διοτρεφής, ἐΰρροος, ἠϊόεις̓ Il. 5.36; his priest Il. 5.77 : Il. 5.774, Il. 6.329, Il. 11.499, Il. 12.21, Il. 21.124, 223, 305, 603; his springs Il. 22.148.

div1.head: Ξάνθος-2
div1.p: (δινήεις, ῥέων). A river of Lycia Il. 2.877, Il. 5.479, Il. 7.172, Il. 12.313.

div1.head: Ξάνθος-3
div1.p: T. Son of Phaenops-1. With his brother Thoon-1 s. Diomedes Il. 5.152.

div1.head: Ξάνθος-4.
div1.p: One of Hector's horses Il. 8.185.

div1.head: Ξάνθος-5
div1.p: (πόδας αἰόλος). One of the horses of Achilles by Zephyrus out of Podarge Il. 16.149, Il. 19.400, 405, 420.
(ἱερός). A Boeotian town with a grove of Poseidon Il. 2.506.

div1.head: Ὀδίος-1
div1.p: (μέγας). A leader of the Halizonians Il. 2.856; s. Agamemnon Il. 5.39.

div1.head: Ὀδίος-2.
div1.p: A Greek herald Il. 9.170.

Genit. Ὀδυσεῦς 398 (ἀγακλυτός, ἀμύμων, ἄναξ, ἀντίθεος, δαΐφρων, Διὶ μῆτιν ἀτάλαντος, διίφιλος, διογενής, δῖος, δόλων ἆτος ἠδὲ πόνοιο, δουρικλυτός, ἐσθλός, θεῖος, θεοῖς ἐναλίγκιος, θρασύς, Ἰθακήσιος, κλυτός, κρατερός, κυδάλιμος, μεγάθυμος, μεγαλήτωρ, ποικιλομήτης, πολύαινος, πολύμητις, πολυμήχανος, πολύτλας δῖος, πολύτροπος, πολύφρων, πτολίπορθος, πτολιπόρθιος, ταλασίφρων, τλήμων, φαίδιμος). (For the significance of the name see Od. 19.406.) Only son of Laertes and Anticleia, brother of Ctimene, husband of Penelope and father of Telemachus. In command of the ship conveying Chryseis to her father Il. 1.311, 430; Athene urges him to stop the flight homeward of the Greeks Il. 2.169, he deals with Thersites 244, exhorts the host 278; his followers enumerated Il. 2.631; described by Helen to Priam Il. 3.191; visited by Agamemnon in his inspection Il. 4.329; accepts Hector's challenge but does not get the lot Il. 6.168; neglects the disabled Nestor Il. 8.97; is one of the embassy to Achilles Il. 9.169, his speech 225, announces the result 677; wakened by Nestor Il. 10.137, offers to go with Diomedes to penetrate the hostile lines 231 (see further under Diomedes); comes to the help of the wounded Diomedes Il. 11.396, is cut off 401, after doing much execution is wounded by Socus 434, kills him 447, is rescued by Menelaus and Aias-1 465; reproves Agamemnon Il. 14.83; advises against renewing the fight fasting Il. 19.155, 216, superintends the conveyance of the gifts to Achilles 238; his drawn wrestling-match with Aias-1 Il. 23.708, wins the foot-race 755; etc. : his adventures on his way home; the Cicones Od. 9.39, the Lotus-eaters 82, the Cyclops 105, the island of Aeolus Od. 10.1, the Laestrygonians (all the ships lost but his) 80, Circe's island 135, Ocean, the Cimmerians, the Shades Od. 11.13, return to Circe's island Od. 12.1, the Sirens 146, smoke, breakers, roaring 201, Scylla and Charybdis 223, Thrinacia, the oxen of the Sun 260, the ship wrecked by violence of the wind, himself the only survivor 403, Scylla and Charybdis again 430, reaches Calypso's island 447, Hermes comes from Zeus to bid C. let him go Od. 5.29, he builds his raft 234, sets sail 269, Poseidon raises the sea 291, the raft shattered 313, Ino comes to his aid 333, lands in the mouth of a Phaeacian river and falls asleep 451, wakened by Nausicaa's maidens Od. 7.117, his appeal to N. 149, she conducts him to a point near the city 316, he proceeds to the city Od. 6.14, enters the palace of Alcinous 134, who receives him hospitably 167, he views the games and dancing Od. 8.109, is taunted by Euryalus-2 158, answers him 165, they are reconciled 396, 400, he throws the δίσκος 186, hears the lay of Demodocus 266, relates his adventures Od. 9.39, is conveyed with gifts in a Phaeacian ship to Ithaca Od. 13.70; Athene comes to him Od. 13.221, his tale to her 256, she transforms him into a beggar 429; he proceeds to the hut of Eumaeus Od. 14.1, who receives him hospitably 48, his tale to Eu. 192, his tale of the night ambush 462; Telemachus appears at the hut Od. 16.11; Athene appears and retransforms O. Od. 16.155, O. reveals himself to his son 187, is transformed back to a beggar 454; with Eumaeus follows Telemachus to the city Od. 17.200, they encounter Melantheus 212, they reach the city 260; his dog Argus Od. 17.291; he follows Eumaeus into the house Od. 17.336, goes begging round the suitors 365,
his tale to Antinous 415, A. throws a foot-stool at him 462, he is summoned to Penelope 553, declines to go 561; his quarrel with Irus Od. 18.1; abused by Melantho Od. 18.321, Eurymachus throws another foot-stool at him 394; with Telemachus he removes the arms Od. 19.4; Melantho abuses him again Od. 19.66; his tale to Penelope Od. 19.165, P. tests him 215, he tells of her husband and prophesies his return 262; Eurycleia ordered to wash him Od. 19.357, she recognizes his scar 392, 467, how he got the scar 393, she is silenced 479; he interprets P.'s dream Od. 19.535; lies down to sleep in the πρόδομος 1, Athene appears to him 30, Zeus gives him signs 102; Ctesippus throws the foot of an ox at him Od. 20.287; he reveals himself to Philoetius and Eumaeus Od. 21.193; asks to try the bow Od. 21.275, Eu. gives it to him on the orders of Telemachus 359, he strings it 404; kills Antinou Od. 22.8, Eurymachus vainly begs for mercy 45, the fight proceeds 79, Athene appears 205, slaughter of the suitors 297; he summons the unfaithful maids for death Od. 21.431; Penelope comes to him but doubts Od. 23.85, her doubts resolved by his knowledge of the bed 174, he tells her of the trials that await him 264, the pair retire 289, he tells his adventures 310, he charges her with the care of the house and leaves the city 348; he goes to try his father Od. 24.216, his tale to him 303, reveals himself 321, the fight with the Ithacans 520, stopped by Athene 531; etc.
Adj. fr. prec. Od. 18.353.
T. From Cabesus. Sought Cassandra in marriage, promising to expel the Greeks. S. Idomeneus Il. 13.363, 374, 772.
the later Oedipus. King of Thebes-1. His incestuous marriage with Epicaste Od. 11.271.
His funeral games referred to Il. 23.679.
Ὀϊκλήης (μεγάθυμος). Son of Antiphates-3 and father of Amphiaraus Od. 15.243, 244.

div1.head: Ὀϊλεύς-1
div1.p: (θεῖος, πτολίπορθος). Husband of Eriopis and father of Aias-2; by Rhene father of Medon-1 Il. 2.527, 727, 728, Il. 13.66, 694, 697, 701, Il. 14.442, 520, Il. 15.333, 336, Il. 17.256, Il. 23.473, 488, 754.

div1.head: Ὀϊλεύς-2
div1.p: (πλήξιππος) T. With his comrade Bienor s. Agamemnon Il. 11.93.
Patr. fr. next. Of Tydeus Il. 5.813, Il. 10.497.

(δῖος, ιππηλάτα, ἱππότα, μεγαλήτωρ). Ruler of Calydon in Aetolia, son of Portheus, husband of Althaea, father of Tydeus and Meleagrus, and grandfather of Diomedes Il. 2.641; entertained Bellerophon Il. 7.216, 219; the Calydonian boar Il. 9.535, 540, 543, 581; Il. 14.117.

div1.head: Οἰνόμαος-1
div1.p: G. S. Hector Il. 5.706.

div1.head: Οἰνόμαος-2
div1.p: T. Il. 12.140; s. Idomeneus Il. 13.506.
Patr. of Helenus-2 Il. 5.707.
Father of Leodes Od. 21.144.
A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.585.
Adj. fr. next, Oechalian. Of Eurytus-1 Il. 2.596, 730; Od. 8.224.
In Thessaly, the city of Eurytus-1. Its men led by Podaleirius and Machaon Il. 2.730.
Οἰχαλίηθεν [-θεν], from Oe. Il. 2.596.
(τρηχεῖα). A town in the realm of Philoctetes at the extremity of the Magnesian Peninsula Il. 2.717.
(λευκή). A town of Thessaly. Its men led by Polypoetes and Leonteus Il. 2.739.
Fem. adj.=next Il. 2.491.
In pl., the gods Il. 1.399, Od. 3.47.

Οὔλυμπος (ἀγάννιφος, αἰγλήεις, αἰπύς, θεῶν ἕδος, μακρός, μέγας, νιφόεις, πολυδειράς, πολύπτυχος). The Thessalian Mt. Olympus, the seat of the gods Il. 1.44, Il. 3.407, Il. 5.360, Il. 11.77, Il. 13.523, Il. 16.93, Od. 3.5, Il. 24.144, etc. : Od. 1.102, Od. 7.240, Od. 8.331, Od. 11.313, Od. 14.394, Od. 20.55, etc.
(θεῖος, οὖλος). See Lexicon.
Patr. of Phrontis-2 Od. 3.282.
Priest of the Idaean Zeus and father of Laogonus-1 Il. 16.604.
G. S. Hector Il. 11.301.
A Locrian town Il. 2.531, Il. 18.326; the home of Menoetius Il. 23.85.
G (αἰολομίτρης). S. Hector Il. 5.707.

div1.head: Ὀρέστης-1
div1.p: (πλήξιππος) G. S. Hector Il. 5.705.

div1.head: Ὀρέστης-2
div1.p: T. Il. 12.139; s. Leonteus Il. 12.193.

div1.head: Ὀρέστης-3
div1.p: (δῖος, τηλεκλυτός). Patr. Ἀγαμεμνονίδης, Ἀτρεΐδης. Son of Agamemnon and Clytaemnestra Il. 9.142, 284 : avenged his father's murder on Aegisthus and C. Od. 1.30, 40, 298, Od. 3.306, Od. 4.546; Ag. in the Shades asks Odysseus about his fate Od. 11.461.
A town of Thessaly. Its men led by Polypoetes and Leonteus Il. 2.739.
Patr. of Amyntor Il. 9.448, Il. 10.266.
A sim. patr. given to Ctesius Od. 15.414.
A town of Thessaly, prob. lying under Pelion. Its men led by Eurypylus-2 Il. 2.734.

div1.head: Ὄρμενος-1
div1.p: T. S. Teucrus Il. 8.274.

div1.head: Ὄρμενος-2
div1.p: T. S. Polypoetes Il. 12.187.
A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.571.

div1.head: Ὀρσίλοχος-1
div1.p: T. S. Teucrus Il. 8.274.

div1.head: Ὀρσίλοχος-2
div1.p: (πόδας ὠκύς). An alleged son of Idomeneus. Odysseus in his tale to Athene says that he killed him Od. 13.260.

div1.head: Ὀρτίλοχος-3
div1.p: (δαΐφρων). Son of the Alpheius and father of Diocles Il. 5.546, 547 : Od. 3.489, Od. 15.187, Od. 21.16.

div1.head: Ὀρτίλοχος-4.
div1.p: Son of Diocles. With his brother Crethon s. Aeneas Il. 5.542, 549.

A mythical island. Orion slain
here Od. 5.123; app. represented as to the s. of the island Syria Od. 15.404.

div1.head: Ὀρχομενός-1
div1.p: (Μινύειος). A Boeotian town, the capital of the kingdom of the Minyae Il. 2.511, Il. 9.381: Od. 11.284, 459.

div1.head: Ὀρχομενός-2
div1.p: (πολύμηλος). A town of Arcadia Il. 2.605.
A mountain in Magnesia between Olympus and Pelion. See Od. 11.315 under Πήλιον.
A leader of the Phrygians Il. 3.186.
Patr. fr. next. Of Iphition Od. 3.383, 389.
(πτολίπορθος). A Maeonian. Father of Iphition by a naiad Od. 3.384.
(πεπνυμένος). A Trojan elder Il. 3.148.
See Ὄλυμπος.
See Lexicon.
(εὐρύς). See Lexicon.
͂ οὔ τις. Odysseus's name assumed for the Cyclops Od. 9.366, 369, 408, 455, 460.
T. S. Teucrus Il. 8.274.
T. A Paeonian. S. Achilles Il. 21.210.
T. S. Euryalus-1 Il. 7.20.
G. S. Hector Il. 11.302.
Father of Periphas-1 Il. 5.843.
The physician of the gods. Heals Hades Il. 5.401, and Ares 899, 900: the Egyptians descended from him Od. 4.232.
T (ἀλκυλότοξοι, δολιχεγχέες, ἱπποκορυσταί). The Paeonians, a people whose territory lay on the Axius Il. 2.848, Il. 10.428, Il. 16.287, 291, Il. 21.155, 205, 211.
Patr. of Agastrophus Il. 11.339, 368.
(ἐριβῶλαξ, ἐρίβωλος). The land of the Paeonians Il. 17.350, Il. 21.154.
See Ἀπαισός.
See Ἀθηναίη.
A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.250.
All the Achaeans, the Achaeans in gen. (see Ἀχαιός (2) (b)) Il. 2.404, Il. 6.73, 159, 327, 385, Il. 9.301, Il. 10.1, Il. 19.193, Il. 23.236: Od. 1.239, Od. 14.369, Od. 24.32.

Father of Aedon (the proper name does not occur), who was the wife of Zethus and mother of Itylus. A. slew I. by mistake and was subsequently changed into a nightingale (ἀηδών) Od. 19.518; P.'s daughters carried off by a wind (their parents being destroyed), but brought up by Aphrodite Od. 20.66.

(ἀγλαός, ἀμύμων τε κρατερός τε, ἀντίθεος). The Trojan bowman, son of Lycaon-1. Leader of the men of Zeleia Il. 2.827; wounds Menelaus Il. 4.88, and Diomedes Il. 5.95, 795; with Aeneas attacks D. E 168, 171, 246, and strikes him with his spear 280; s. D. E 290.
G. Bears Teucrus's bow Il. 12.372.
T. S. Aias-1 Il. 11.490.
All the Hellenes (with extension of Ἕλληνες to the Greeks in gen.). App hardly to be distinguished from Ἀχαιοί in the same line (see Ἀχαιός (2) (b)) Il. 2.530.
Patr. fr. next. Of Poulydamas Il. 13.756, Il. 14.450, 454, Il. 15.446, Il. 16.535, Il. 18.250.
Of Euphorbus Il. 16.808, Il. 17.70, 81.
Genit. Πάνθου, Dat. Πάνθῳ. An elder at Troy, app. (Il. 16.807) a Dardanian, husband of Phrontis-1 and father of Euphorbus, Poulydamas and Hyperenor Il. 3.146, Il. 15.522, Il. 17.9, 23, 40.

div1.head: Πανοπεύς-1
div1.p: (καλλίχορος, κλειτός). A town or district of Phocis Il. 2.520, Il. 17.307: Od. 11.581.

div1.head: Πανοπεύς-2.
div1.p: Father of Epeius Il. 23.665.
A Nerei Il. 18.45.
A Paphlagonian river Il. 2.854.

often called Ἀλέξανδρος?̔βασιλεύς, δῖος, θεοειδής̓. Son of Priam and Hecabe. Carried off Helen from Menelaus and was her husband at Troy. Appears in the front of the Trojans Il. 3.16, but retires before Menelaus 30, reproached by Hector 38, his duel with M. 340, he is snatched away by Aphrodite and set down in his chamber 380, Helen comes to him 421; Hector comes to urge him to the field Il. 7.321, he goes 503, and joins Η. 514, kills Menesthius-1 Il. 6.8; in the assembly refuses to give up Helen Il. 6.355; wounds Diomedes with an arrow Il. 11.369, and Machaon 505, and Eurypylus-2 581; kills Euchenor Il. 13.660, and Deiochus Il. 15.341; Hector prophesies death to Achilles at the hands of P. and Apollo Il. 22.359; how he flouted the goddesses Il. 24.28: etc.
A mountain of Phocis under which Delphi (Πυθώ) lay. Autolycus dwelt by it Od. 19.432, Od. 24.332.
A town of Arcadia Il. 2.608.
A grace beloved by Hypnos Il. 14.269, promised to him by Hera 276.

-ου. Also genit. Πατροκλῆος 554, Il. 17.670, Il. 23.65, 105, 221: Od. 11.468, Od. 24.16. Acc. -ῆα 602, Il. 16.125, 818, Il. 22.331. Voc. -εες 337, Il. 11.823, Il. 16.7, 126, etc. (ἄλκιμος, ἀμύμων, διΐφιλος, διογενής, δῖος, θεόφιν μήστωρ ἀτάλαντος, ἱππεύς, ἱπποκέλευθος, μεγαλήτωρ, Πατροκλῆος λάσιον κῆρ). Patr. Μενοιτιάδης. Son of Menoetius and comrade of Achilles. Brings out Briseis at the bidding of Achilles Il. 1.337, 345; present with A. when the embassy arrives Il. 9.190; summoned by A. to ascertain who was the wounded man who passed with Nestor Il. 11.602, reaches Nestor's hut 644, on his way back encounters and succours the wounded Eurypylus-2 807, Il. 15.390; delivers Nestor's appeal to A. Il. 16.2; arms at the bidding of A. Il. 16.126, and falls on the foe 257, fights with Sarpedon 427, slays him 480; against A.'s advice drives the foe too far Il. 16.684, approaches the city 703, but retires before Apollo 710; Apollo brings about his end Il. 16.787, he is wounded by Euphorbus 806, mortally wounded by Hector 818, prophesies H.'s death 843, dies 855; the
fight over his body Il. 17.1; Achilles hears of his death Il. 18.15; his corpse is rescued Il. 18.231; the lament of Briseis Il. 19.282; his spirit appears to Achilles Il. 23.65, the material for the pyre collected 110, the pyre 163, the winds summoned to make it burn 192, the funeral games 262; how he had been brought by Menoetius to the house of Peleus Il. 23.85; etc.: Od. 3.110; in the Shades Od. 11.468, Od. 24.16; Od. 24.77, 79.
T (μεγάθυμοι ἀσπισταί, μεγαλήτορες). The Paphlagonians, a people of the s. shore of the Euxine between Heracleia and Cape Carambis Il. 2.851, Il. 5.577, Il. 13.656, 661.
In Cyprus. A seat of Aphrodite Od. 8.363.
Patr. of Ptolemaeus Il. 4.228.
(δουρικλυτός). Patr. Κλυτίδης-2. Son of Clytius-2. A comrade of Telemachus to whom T. committed Theoclymenus Od. 15.539, 540, 544, Od. 17.55, 71, 74, 78, Od. 20.372.

(ἐρικυδής, θεόφιν μήστωρ ἀτάλαντος, μεγάθυμος). A Lapith. Son of Zeus and Dia (see Ἰξιόνιος), husband of Hippodameia-1 and father of Polypoetes Il. 2.741; Eurytion's disturbance at his marriage and the expulsion of the Centaurs Il. 2.742: Od. 21.296, 298; a warrior of Nestor's youth Il. 1.263: Od. 11.631; Il. 12.129, 182, Il. 14.318.
Πείρως. Genit. Πείρεω 484, T. Patr. Ἰμβρασίδης. Father of Rhigmus. A leader of the Thracians Il. 2.844; slays Diores-1 Il. 4.520, 525, s. Thoas-1 527; Od. 3.484.
T. Son of Antimachus. With his brother Hippolochus-2 s. Agamemnon Il. 11.122, 143.
T. S. Menelaus Il. 13.601, 606, 611.

div1.head: Πείσανδρος-3
div1.p: (ἀρήϊος). Patr. Μαιμαλίδης. A leader under Achilles Il. 16.193.

div1.head: Πείσανδρος-4
div1.p: (ἄναξ). Patr. Πολυκτορίδης. One of the suitors. His gift to Penelope Od. 18.299; Od. 22.243; s. Philoetius Od. 22.268.

div1.head: Πεισήνωρ-1.
div1.p: Father of Cleitus-1 Il. 15.445.

div1.head: Πεισήνωρ-2.
div1.p: An Ithacan herald Od. 2.38.

(ἐϋμμελίης, ὄρχαμος ἀνδρῶν). Patr. Νεστορίδης. Son of Nestor. Greets Telemachus at Pylus Od. 3.36; Od. 3.400, 415, 454; accompanies T. to Sparta Od. 3.482; at S. Od. 4.1, 155; eager for departure T. rouses him Od. 15.46, 48; Od. 15.131, 166; they depart Od. 15.182, at Pylus takes T. direct to the ship to avoid Nestor's hospitality 202.
G (μέγας) Il. 4.295.
T (ἴφθιμος). Comrade of Sarpedon, tended him when he was wounded Il. 5.695.
Adj. fr. next of equally disputed meaning.

div2.p: Of Argos-2 Il. 2.681.
Of Zeus of Dodona Il. 16.233.

div1.p: Pelasgians, a name of much disputed meaning.

div2.p: T (ἐγχεσίμωροι) Applied to the men of Larisa Il. 2.840, 843, Il. 17.288 (in these two cases applied in sing. to Lethus).
Also (δῖοι) to a section of the Trojan allies whose position is indicated by Dolon along with that of the Carians and others Il. 10.429.
(δῖοι) In Odysseus's tale to Penelope applied to one of the five divisions of the inhabitants of Crete Od. 19.177.

div1.p: Son of Poseidon and Tyro. Ruler of Iaolcus Od. 11.254, 256.
Father of Alcestis Il. 2.715.
A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.574.
(πλήξιππος). Son of Tantalus and father of Atreus and Thyestes. The sceptre given to him by Hermes and by him to Atreus Il. 2.104, 105.
G (μενοπτόλεμοι). A people of n. Thessaly led by Gouneus Il. 2.749.
(ἱερή). The citadel of Troy containing (Il. 5.446) the temple of Apollo Il. 4.508, Il. 5.460, Il. 7.512, Il. 6.21, Il. 24.700.
Patr. of Deicoon Il. 5.535.

div1.head: Περίβοια-1.
