div1.p: Daughter of Acessamenus and mother of Pelegon by the Axius Il. 21.142.

div1.head: Περίβοια-2
div1.p: (γυναικῶν εἶδος ἀρίστη). Daughter of Eurymedon-3 and mother of Nausithous by Poseidon Od. 6.57.
Father of Borus-2 Il. 16.177.
(ἀγέρωχος). Son of Neleus Od. 11.286.

div1.head: Περιμήδης-1.
div1.p: Father of Schedius-2 Il. 15.515.

div1.head: Περιμήδης-2.
div1.p: A comrade of Odysseus in his ship Od. 11.23, Od. 12.195.
T. Patr. Μεγάδης. S. Patroclus Il. 16.695.

div1.head: Περίφας-1
div1.p: (ἀγλαός, πελώριος). An Aetolian, son of Ochesius. S. Ares Il. 5.842, 847.

div1.head: Περίφας-2.
div1.p: Patr. Ἠπυτίδης. A Trojan herald. Apollo addresses Aeneas in his form Il. 17.323.
T. S. Teucrus Il. 14.515.
G (Μυκηναῖος). Son of Copreus. S. Hector Il. 15.638.
A town of the Troad not far from the mouth of the Practius Il. 2.835, Il. 11.229, Il. 15.548.

div1.head: Περσεύς-1
div1.p: (πάντων ἐριδείκετος ἀνδρῶν). Son of Zeus by Danae and father of Sthenelus-2 Il. 14.320.

div1.head: Περσεύς-2.
div1.p: Son of Nestor Od. 3.414, 444.

(ἀγαυή, ἁγνή, Διὸς θυγάτηρ, ἐπαινή). Daughter of Zeus and Demeter (it is no doubt to be understood that it was to the union in Il. 14.326 that she owed her being) and wife of Hades Il. 9.457, 569: Od. 10.491, 494, 509, 534, 564, Od. 11.47, 213, 217, 226, 386, 635.
Daughter of Oceanus and mother by Eelius of Aeetes and Circe Od. 10.139.
Patr. fr. Περσεύς-1. Of Sthenelus-2 Il. 19.116, 123.
A Boeotian town Il. 2.500.
-εῶο?̔διοτρεφὴς βασιλεύς̓. Father of Menestheus Il. 2.552, Il. 4.327, 338, Il. 12.331, 355, Il. 13.690.
A town, app. of the Troad, not identified Il. 13.172.
T. Bastard son of Antenor. S. Meges Il. 5.69.

div1.head: Πήδασος-1
div1.p: (ἀμπελόεσσα). A town of Pylus Il. 9.152, 294.

div1.head: Πήδασος-2
div1.p: (αἰπεινή, αἰπήεσσα). A town of the southern Troad on the Satnioeis prob. to be identified with Assus opposite the northern end of Lesbos Il. 7.35; taken by Achilles Od. 3.92; Il. 21.87.
T. Son of Boucolion and Abarbaree. With his twin brother Aesepus-2 s. Euryalus-1 Il. 7.21.

div1.head: Πήδασος-4
div1.p: (ἀμύμων). One of the horses of Achilles, taken by him at Thebe-2 Il. 16.152. Killed by Sarpedon Il. 16.467.
(κλυτὸς ἔγχεϊ). Son of the Axius and Periboea-1 and father of Asteropaeus Il. 21.141, 152, 159.
Πηλεΐωνάδε [-δε], to A. Il. 24.338.

(ἀμύμων, ἄναξ, γέρων, δαΐφρων, ἱππηλάτα, ἱππότα). Patr. Αἰακίδης. King of Argos-2. Son of Aeacus, husband of Thetis, and father of Achilles and Polydore. His charge to his son Il. 9.252, Il. 11.783; he received the fugitive Phoenix-1 Il. 9.480; the visit to him of Nestor and Odysseus Il. 11.769; his (and Achilles') immortal horses Il. 16.381, 867, Il. 17.443, Il. 23.278; Epeigeus came as a suppliant to him and Thetis Il. 16.574; his armour, given by the gods Il. 18.84; his parentage Il. 21.189; he received the fugitive Patroclus Il. 23.89; his riches and good fortune Il. 24.534; etc.: Od. 11.478, 494, 505, Od. 24.36.
Adj. fr. Πηλεύς. Of or pertaining to Peleus Il. 18.60, 441.
Adj. fr. next. Of or from Pelion. Of the spear of Achilles given to Peleus by Cheiron Il. 16.143, Il. 19.390, Od. 3.277, Il. 21.162, Il. 22.133.

(εἰνοσίφυλλον). A mountain in Magnesia, s.e. of Ossa. The Centaurs driven from it by Peirithous Il. 2.744 (cf. Od. 21.295-304); Il. 2.757; the spear of Achilles came thence Il. 16.144, Il. 19.391: the threat of Otus-1 and Ephialtes to pile Ossa on Olympus and P. on Ossa Od. 11.315.
(ἀργυροδίνης). A river of Thessaly reaching the sea through the Vale of Tempe Il. 2.752, 753, 757.
-έωο?̔ἄναξ, δαΐφρων̓. A leader of the Boeotians Il. 2.494; Il. 13.92; slays Ilioneus Il. 14.487, 489, 496; slays Lucon Il. 16.335, 340; wounded by Poulydamas Il. 17.597.

(ἐχέφρων, περίφρων, πολύδωρος). Daughter of Icarius-2, sister of Iphthime, wife of Odysseus and mother of Telemachus. Bids Phemius change his song Od. 1.328; her stratagem in the matter of the web Od. 2.94, Od. 19.138, Od. 24.129; hears of her son's departure and of the plot against him Od. 4.675; appears to the suitors and rebukes Antinou Od. 16.409, is put off with fair words by Eurymachus 434; welcomes her son home Od. 17.36, he tells her his story 108; she hears the disguised Odysseus being struck Od. 17.492; summons O. Od. 17.508, who declines to come at that time 560; she appears again in the μέγαρον beautified (Od. 18.187) by Athene Od. 18.158, rebukes her son 215, relates to Eurymachus O.'s parting charge 250, suggests gifts 274, which are sent for 290; when the suitors have gone appears again Od. 19.53, rebukes Melantho 89, converses with Ο. 103, bids Eurycleia wash him 357, he interprets P.'s dream 535; she sets down the bow, etc., for the contest Od. 21.1; is summoned by Eurycleia after the destruction of the suitors Od. 23.1, cannot clearly recognize Ο. 85, to convince her he speaks of his bed 171, she recognizes him fully 205, the pair retire 289, he relates his adventures to her 310, his charge to her before leaving the city 350; etc.
Said to have been in Thessaly. The horses of Eumelus reared there Il. 2.766.
(ἰφθίμη, θαῦμα βροτοῖσιν). Daughter of Neleus. Her father's requirement of her suitors Od. 11.287.
T. S. Odysseus Il. 7.30.
A district lying to the n. of the Thessalian Mt. Olympus Il. 14.226: Od. 5.50.
Father of Aethre Il. 3.144.
Prob. to be identified with Lampsacus (the modern Lampsaki) on the Hellespont Il. 2.829.
The wandering (πλάζω) or the dashing (πλήσσω) rocks (represented also as smoking Od. 12.202) Od. 12.61, Od. 23.327.
(ὑλήεσσα). A mountain dominating Thebe-2 Il. 7.396, 425, Il. 22.479.
A Boeotian town Il. 2.504.
A town of Aetolia Il. 2.639, Il. 13.217, Il. 14.116.
Adj. fr. prec. Of Ancaeus-2 Il. 23.635.
The Pleiades, a cluster of stars in the constellation Taurus Il. 18.486: Od. 5.272.
(ἰητὴρ ἀγαθός). Son of Asclepius. With his brother Machaon chief surgeon of the Greeks and leader of the men of Tricca, etc. Il. 2.732, Il. 11.833.
Dam of Xanthus-5 and Balius (see Ἅρπυια in Lex.) Il. 16.150, Il. 19.400.

div1.head: Πόδαργος-1.
div1.p: One of Hector's horses Il. 8.185.

div1.head: Πόδαργος-2.
div1.p: One of Menelaus's horses Il. 23.295.
(μενοπτόλεμος, ὄζος Ἄρηος). Son of Iphiclus-1 and younger brother german of Protesilaus. On P.'s death succeeded to his leadership Il. 2.704, Il. 13.693 (his followers here called Φθῖοι).
T (ἀφνειός τʼ ἀγαθός τε). Son of Eetion-2 and boon companion of Hector Il. 17.575; s. Menelaus Il. 17.578; Il. 17.590.
(Son) of Poeas. Of Philoctetes Od. 3.190.

div1.head: Πολίτης-1
div1.p:
(βοὴν ἀγαθός). Son of Priam and
Hecabe. Swift of foot Il. 2.791; Il. 13.533, Il. 15.339, Il. 24.250.

div1.head: Πολίτης-2
div1.p: (ὄρχαμος ἀνδρῶν). One of the companions of Odysseus in his ship Od. 10.224.
Patr. of Amopaon Il. 8.276.
T. Patr. Ἀντηνορίδης. Son of Antenor Il. 11.59.

div1.head: Πόλυβος-2
div1.p: (δαΐφρων). Father of Eurymachus Od. 1.399, Od. 2.177, Od. 15.519, Od. 18.349, Od. 21.320, etc.

div1.head: Πόλυβος-3.
div1.p: Dwelt in Thebes-2. The presents given by him and his wife Alcandra to Menelaus and Helen Od. 4.126.

div1.head: Πόλυβος-4
div1.p: (δαΐφρων). Made the ball with which the Phaeacians played Od. 8.373.

div1.head: Πόλυβος-5
div1.p: (δαΐφρων). One of the suitors Od. 22.243; s. Eumaeus Od. 22.284.
Wife of the Egyptian Thon. Her gift of drugs to Helen Od. 4.228.
(κρατερόφρων, πὺξ ἀγαθός). Son of Tyndareus and Leda, brother of Castor-1 and Clytaemnestra and half-brother of Helen. See under Κάστωρ-1.
(καλή). Daughter of Peleus, wife of Borus-2, and by the Spercheius mother of Menesthius-2 Il. 16.175.

div1.head: Πολύδωρος-1
div1.p: (ἀντίθεος). Patr. Πριαμίδης. Son of Priam and Laothoe and brother of Lycaon-2. S. Achilles Od. 3.407, 419, Il. 21.91; Il. 22.46.

div1.head: Πολύδωρος-2.
div1.p: Nestor beat him at spear-throwing Il. 23.637.
Patr. of Ctesippus Od. 22.287.
T. Son of Eurydamas-1. With his brother A bas s. Diomedes Il. 5.148.

div1.head: Πολύιδος-2
div1.p: (ἀγαθός, μάντις). Father of Euchenor Il. 13.663, 666.
(καλή). Nestor's youngest daughter. Washed Telemachus Od. 3.464.
Patr. of Peisandrus-4 Od. 18.299, Od. 22.243.

div1.head: Πολύκτωρ-1
div1.p: (ἀφνειός). Given as his father's name by the disguised Hermes to Priam Il. 24.397.

div1.head: Πολύκτωρ-2.
div1.p: See Ἴθακος.
(χορῷ καλή). Daughter of Phylas and by Hermes mother of Eudorus. Afterwards wife of Echeclees Il. 16.180.
T. Patr. Ἀργεάδης. S. Patroclus Il. 16.417.
(ἀντίθεος). Son of Oedipodes and Epicaste. Asks the Mycenaeans for aid in attacking his brother Eteocles Il. 4.377.
Patr. Τεκτονίδης. Father of Amphialus Od. 8.114.
(θεοειδής). Son of Agasthenes and a leader of the Epeians Il. 2.624.
Patr. of Apheidas Od. 24.305.

(κρατερός, μενοπτόλεμος). Son of Peirithous and Hippodameia-1. With Leonteus leader of the men of Argissa, etc. Il. 2.740; Il. 7.29; his defence with L. of the wall Il. 12.129, 182; wins the prize in putting the weight Il. 23.836, 844, 848.
(ὑπέρθυμος). Son of Mantius and father of Theoclymenus Od. 15.249, 256; succeeded Amphiaraus in his seership Od. 15.252; fled to Hyperesia Od. 15.254.

div1.head: Πολύφημος-1,
div1.p: also called simply Κύκλωψ (ἄγριος, ἀθεμίστια εἰδώς, ἀνδροφάγος, ἀντίθεος, κρατερός, μεγαλήτωρ, μένος ἄσχετος, πέλωρ). One of the Cyclopes (q.v.), son of Poseidon and Thoosa (Od. 1.71). Had only one eye (Od. 9.333, 383, 397). Odysseus visits his cave in his absence Od. 9.216; his cave and flocks described Od. 9.218; he returns to the cave and finds O. and his companions there Od. 9.233; his greeting and subsequent barbarous behaviour Od. 9.252; is blinded Od. 9.371; O. and his surviving companions escape him Od. 9.424; he prays to Poseidon for vengeance Od. 9.528; etc.

div1.head: Πολύφημος-2
div1.p: (ἀντίθεος). A warrior of Nestor's youth Il. 1.264.
T (ἀντίθεος). Il. 13.791.
(μενοπτόλεμος). Son of Autophonus. With Maeon leader of the ambush at Thebes-1 against Tydeus Il. 4.395.
A Phaeacian Od. 8.113.
θεράπων of Alcinous Od. 6.179, 182, Od. 8.65, Od. 13.50, 53.
Father of Agrius, Melas and Oeneus, and grandfather of Tydeus and Meleagrus Il. 14.115.

(ἄναξ, γαιήοχος, ἐννοσίγαιος, γαιήοχος ἐ., κλυτὸς ἐ., ἐνοσίχθων, κρείων ἐ., εὐρυσθενής, κυανοχαίτης). Son of Cronus and Rhea, and brother of Zeus, Hades, Hera and Demeter. Father (1) by Iphimedeia of Otus-1 and Ephialtes; (2) by Periboea-2 of Nausithous; (3) by Tyro of Neleus and Pelias; (4) by Thoosa of Polyphemus-1, and (5) of Cteatus and Eurytus-2. By lot (Il. 15.187, 190) got the sea as his realm. With Hera and Athene tried to put Zeus in bonds Il. 1.399; complains to Z. of the building of the Greek wall Il. 6.445, with Apollo subsequently destroys the wall Il. 12.17, 34; proceeds from Samothrace to the ships Il. 13.10, and encourages the Greeks 43, retires by order of Zeus Il. 15.218; in the Battle of the Gods challenges Apollo Il. 21.436, who declines 461; etc.: his bitterness against Odysseus on account of his son Polyphemus-1 Od. 1.20, 68; Telemachus finds the Pylians sacrificing to him Od. 3.4; destroys Aias-2 on the Gyraean rock Od. 4.502; raises the sea against Odysseus on his passage to Phaeacia Od. 5.291, Od. 6.271; in the tale of Demodocus releases Ares Od. 8.344; lay with Tyro in the Enipeus Od. 11.241; lay with Iphimedeia Od. 11.305; turns the Phaeacian ship to stone Od. 13.159; etc.
Adj. fr. prec. Il. 2.506.
In neut. Ποσιδήϊον, a temple of P. Od. 7.266.

(ἀγαπήνωρ, ἀγαυός, ἀμώμητος, ἀμύμων, ἐγχέσπαλος, μεγάθυμος, πεπνυμένος). Patr. Πανθοΐδης. Son of Panthous. Comrade of, and born in the same night with, Hector; excelled in counsel (Il. 18.249). Advises against attempting the ditch with chariots Il. 12.60; unsuccessfully advises H. to give up the attack Il. 12.210; advises H. to retire Il. 13.725; slays Prothoenor-2 Il. 14.449; slays Mecisteus-2 Il. 15.339; slays Otus-2 Il. 15.518;
eludes the spear of Meges Il. 15.521; wounds Peneleos Il. 17.600; unsuccessfully advises H. to retire to the city Il. 18.249; etc.
A river (now Bergaz Chai) flowing into the Hellespont on the Asiatic side Il. 2.835.
Applied to a wine of unknown growth Il. 11.639: Od. 10.235.
Of Paris Il. 3.356.
Of Antiphus-3 Il. 4.490.
Of Helenus-1 Il. 7.76, Il. 13.586.
Of Doryclus Il. 11.490.
Of Deiphobus Il. 13.157.
Of Lycaon-2 Od. 3.87.
Of Polydorus-1 Od. 3.408.

(ἀγακλεής, ἄναξ, γέρων, δαΐφρων, διοτρεφὴς βασιλεύς, ἐϋμμελίης, θεοειδής, θεόφιν μήστωρ ἀτάλαντος, μεγαλήτωρ, μέγας). Patr. Δαρδανίδης, Λαομεδοντιάδης. King of Troy. Son of Laomedon, grandson of Ilus-1, and great-grandson of Tros-1, who was son of Erichthonius, who was son of Dardanus-1, who was son of Zeus. Father (1) by Hecabe of Deiphobus, Hector, Helenus-1, Laodice-1, Paris and Polites-1; also (though Hecabe is not here named) of Cassandra; (2) by Castianeira of Gorgythion; (3) by Laothoe of Lycaon-2 and Polydorus-1; (4) by unnamed mothers of Agathon, Antiphonus, Antiphus-3, Chromius-2 and his brother Echemmon, Dius, Hippothous-2, Mestor, Pammon, and Troilus; and (5) of Cebriones, Democoon, Doryclus, Isus and Medesicaste, all described as bastards. At the beginning of the war had fifty sons Il. 24.495 (cf Il. 7.244), eleven of whom were by one mother, presumably by Hecabe Il. 24.496. Twelve daughters and their husbands lived with him Il. 7.248. Sitting on the wall he summons Helen to point out the Greek chiefs Il. 3.161; is summoned to the plain to perform the oath-sacrifice Il. 3.250, returns 303; his palace described Il. 7.242; advises sending to the Greeks to propose a truce for the burning of the dead Il. 6.368; his charge to the gate-keepers Il. 21.526; sees Hector in danger from Achilles Il. 22.25, and vainly beseeches him to take refuge 38; Iris sent by Zeus bids him go to the ships to ransom Hector's corpse Il. 24.171, Hecabe vainly dissuades him 201, his sons prepare his chariot 265, he departs 322, he encounters Hermes 349, he reaches the hut of Achilles 448, who receives him graciously 507, he retires to rest 643, he returns to the city with the corpse 689; etc.: Od. 3.107, 130, Od. 5.106, Od. 11.421, 533, Od. 13.316, Od. 14.241, Od. 22.230.

div1.head: Προθοήνωρ-1.
div1.p: A leader of the Boeotians Il. 2.495.
G Son of Areilycus-1. S. Poulydamas Il. 14.450, 471.
(θός). Son of Tenthredon and leader of the Magnetes Il. 2.756, 758.
T. S. Teucrus Il. 14.515.
Husband of Anteia. (See under Βελλεροφόντης) Il. 7.157, 160, 163, 164, 177.

Daughter of Erechtheus, king of Athens (grandson of the hero of the same name), and wife of Cephalus. She is siad to have been unwittingly killed by C. with an unerring dart given to her by Artemis. Named Od. 11.321.
Patr. Ἀλεγηνορίδης. A Boeotian. S. Acamas-1 Il. 14.476, 482, 503.
T. S. Patroclus Il. 16.399.
Father of Astynous-2 Il. 15.455.
A Phaeacian Od. 8.112.
T. S. Odysseus Il. 5.678.
A Phaeacian Od. 8.113.

(ἀρήϊος, μεγάθυμος). Son of Iphiclus-1 and elder brother german of Podarces. Leader of the men of various towns lying about the w. coast of the Pagasaean Gulf. Was slain in landing first of the Greeks and was succeeded by Podarces Il. 2.698, 706, 708; the position of his ships Il. 13.681; fighting round his ship Il. 15.705; the ship set on fire Il. 16.122, the fire extinguished 286, 293.

(Αἰγύπτιος, γέρων ἅλιος νημερτής, ἴφθιμος). The Old Man of the Sea, a servant of Poseidon and father of Eidothee Od. 4.365, 385; his transformations on being seized in Pharos by Menelaus and his comrades Od. 4.454, his advice to Μ. 471, tells of the fates of Aias-2and Agamemnon 491.
A Nereid Il. 18.43.

div1.head: Πτελεός-1
div1.p: A town of Pylus Il. 2.594.

div1.head: Πτελεός-2
div1.p: (λεχεποίης). A town of the realm of Protesilaus Il. 2.697.
Patr. Πειραΐδης. Father of Eurymedon-1 Il. 4.228.
A supposed (dwarfish) race represented as warred on by cranes Il. 3.6.
(ἠγαθέη, πετρήεσσα). A town of Phocis, later called Delphi Il. 2.519, Il. 9.405: Od. 8.80.
Πυθώδε [-δε], to P. Od. 11.581.
(ἀτάλαντος Ἄρηϊ, Πυλαιμένεος λάσιον κῆρ). Father of Harpalion and leader of the Paphlagonians Il. 2.851; s. Menelaus Il. 5.576; Il. 13.643. (He is represented as alive in Il. 13.658.)
T (ὄζος Ἄρηος). Son of Lethus. A leader of the Pelasgians (1) Il. 2.842.
T. S. Aias-1 Il. 11.491.
T. S. Patroclus Il. 16.696.
A town of Aetolia Il. 2.639.
See Lexicon.

(αἰπὺ?̔ἐϋκτίμενον̓ πτολίεθρον, ἠγαθέη, ν̓μαθόεις, ἱερή, Νηλήϊος). Nestor's capital and kindom, on the w. coast of the Peloponnesus, of uncertain site Il. 1.252, 269, Il. 2.77, 591, Il. 9.153, 295, Il. 11.682, 689, 712, 716: Od. 1.93, 284, Od. 2.214, 308, 326, 359, Od. 3.4, 485, Od. 4.599, 633, 639, 702, 713, Od. 5.20, Od. 11.257, 285, 459, Od. 14.180, Od. 15.42, 193, 226, 236, 541, Od. 16.131, Od. 17.109, Od. 21.108, Od. 24.152, 430.
Πυλόθεν [-θεν], from P. Od. 16.323.
In Il. 5.397 app. a different P. is meant.
T. S. Polypoetes Il. 12.187.
Leader of the Paeonians Il. 2.848; s. Patroclus Il. 16.287.

div1.head: Πύρασος-1
div1.p: (ἀνθεμόεις). A town in the realm of Protesilaus with a τέμενος of Demeter Il. 2.695.

div1.head: Πύρασος-2
div1.p: T. S. Aias-1 Il. 11.491.
T. S. Patroclus Il. 16.416.
See Κώκυτος.

(ἀντίθεος, ξανθός). Son of Zeus and Europa (daughter of Phoenix-2) and brother of Minos Il. 14.322: in the Elysian Shades Od. 4.564; the Phaeacians conveyed him to visit Tityus, app. in Euboea Od. 6.323.
Ῥέα. By Cronus mother of Zeus, Hades, Poseidon, Hera and Demeter Il. 14.203, Il. 15.187.
A harbour of Ithaca Od. 1.186.
Mother by Oileus-1 of Medon-1 Il. 2.728.
(ἀντίθεος). Son of Nausithous, brother of Alcinous, and father of Arete. No male heir Od. 6.63; Od. 6.146.

div1.head: Ῥῆσος-1.
div1.p: King of the Thracians; son of Eioneus-2. His horses Il. 10.435, he and his comrades s. Diomedes and Odysseus 474, 494, 519.

div1.head: Ῥῆσος-2.
div1.p: An unknown river Il. 12.20.
T (ἀμύμων). Son of Peiroos. S. Achilles Od. 3.485.
A town of Arcadia Il. 2.606.
An unknown river Il. 12.20.
G (ἀγέρωχοι). The Rhodians Il. 2.654.
(εὖ ναιετόωσα). A city of Crete Il. 2.648.
A river flowing through Phrygia and falling into the Euxine Il. 3.187, Il. 16.719.
The island home of Aias-1 Il. 2.557, Il. 6.199.
(ἀμύμων). Father of Tyro Od. 11.236.
(with u.l. Σάμος 246, Od. 9.24, Od. 16.249),

div1.head: Σάμος-2
div1.p: Il. 2.634 (with u.l. Σάμη)· 671, 845, Od. 15.29. Mod. Cephallenia, Cephalonia (παιπαλόεσσα). An island forming part of the realm of Odysseus Il. 2.634.
In Od. associated with Doulichium, Zacynthus and Ithaca Od. 1.246, Od. 9.24, Od. 16.123, 249, Od. 19.131.
The home of Ctesippus Od. 20.288.
The channel between Ithaca and S. Od. 4.671, 845, Od. 15.29.
Σάμηνδε [-δε], to S. Od. 15.367.

div1.head: Σάμος-1
div1.p: (ὑλήεσσα). The Thracian Samos, Samothrace Il. 24.78, 753.
So Σ. Θρηϊκίη 12.

(ἀντίθεος, δῖος, χαλκοκορυστής). Son of Zeus by Laodameia (Il. 7.199) and with Glaucus-2 leader of the Lycians Il. 2.876; reproves Hector Il. 5.471, 493; is wounded by Tlepolemus-1 and slays him Il. 5.629, 633, 647, 655, 658, 663, Hector neglects him 683, he is rescued by his comrades 692; Il. 12.101, 292, 307; his address to Glaucus-2 Il. 12.310; Il. 12.379, 392; breaks the wall Il. 12.397; Il. 14.426; Zeus foretells his death Il. 15.67; Il. 16.327, 419, 433, 445, 464; wounds the horse Pedasus-4 Il. 16.466; misses Patroclus Il. 16.477; is mortally wounded by P. Il. 16.479, appeals to Glaucus-2 492, 496, dies 502; Il. 16.522, 533, 541; the fight over his body Il. 16.553, 559, 638, 649, it is taken by the Greeks and stripped 663, Zeus charges Apollo with his funeral rites 667, 678; Il. 17.150, 162; Achilles sets down his armour as a prize Il. 23.800.
(ἐϋρρείτης). A river of the southern Troad falling into the Aegean a little north of Cape Lecton Il. 7.34, Il. 14.445, Il. 21.87.
T. Patr. Ἠνοπίδης. Son of Enops-1 and a naiad. S. Aias-2 Il. 14.443.

(ἁδιναί, θεσπέσιαι). Mythical beings (app. from the dual (Od. 12.52, 167) two in number) with irresistibly seductive voices. Described Od. 12.39, 42, 44, 52, 158; Odysseus passes their island safely Od. 12.167, 198, Od. 23.326.
(πολυκτήμων πολυλήϊος). Father of Amphius-2; dwelt in Paesus Il. 5.612.
Patr. of Euenus Il. 2.693.

div1.head: Σελλήεις-1.
div1.p: A river of the Troad not identified Il. 2.839, Il. 12.97.

div1.head: Σελλήεις-2.
div1.p: A river in the country of the next, or according to others in Elis Il. 2.659, Il. 15.531.
u.l. σʼ Ἑλλοί?̔ἀνιπτόποδες χαμαιεῦναἰ. The interpreters or priests of the oracle of Zeus at Dodona Il. 16.234.
Daughter of Cadmus and by Zeus mother of Dionysus Il. 14.323, 325.
A Paphlagonian town Il. 2.853.
A city on the n.w. of the Hellespont, a little above Abydus on the other side Il. 2.836.
T. Son of Ithaemenes. S. Patroclus Il. 16.586.

div1.head: Σθένελος-1
div1.p: (ἀγλαός). Patr. Καπανηϊάδης. Son of Capaneus and companion of Diomedes Il. 2.564; acting as chariot-driver to D. Il. 4.367, 403, Il. 5.108, 111, 241, 319, 835, Il. 8.114; drives off Aeneas's horses Il. 5.319; replies to Agamemnon in his inspection Il. 4.403, is rebuked by D. 411; Il. 9.48, Il. 23.511.

div1.head: Σθένελος-2.
div1.p: Patr. Περσηϊάδης. Son of Perseus-1 and father of Eurystheus Il. 19.116, 123.
See Σιδόνιοι.
Σιδών Od. 15.425 (εὖ ναιομένη, πολύχαλκος). A maritime city of Phoenicia Od. 13.285, Od. 15.425.
Σιδονίηθεν [-θεν], from S. Il. 7.291.
Σιδόνες Il. 23.743 (πολυδαίδαλοι). The inhabitants of prec., celebrated as craftsmen Il. 7.290, Il. 23.743: visited by Menelaus Od. 4.84; Od. 4.618, Od. 15.118.
Perh. the country in w. Sicily in habited by the Sicani of history Od. 24.307.
Perhaps a people on the coast of Italy opposite Ithaca and the same as the Siculi of history. App. they were slave-dealers Od. 20.383.
In sing. of the female servant who attended to Laertes Od. 24.211, 366, 389.
(εὐρύχορος). In Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.572; the home of Echepolus-2 Il. 23.299.
A river of the Trojan plain n. of Troy Il. 4.475; its junction with the Scamander Il. 5.774; Il. 5.777, Il. 7.4, Il. 12.22, Od. 3.53, Il. 21.307.
(ἠΐθεος θαλερός). Patr. Ἀνθεμίδης. Son of Anthemion. Named from prec. (Il. 4.477). S. Aias-1 Il. 4.474, 488.
(ἀγριόφωνοι). The inhabitants of Lemnos Il. 1.594: Od. 8.294.
A mountain of Lydia, a branch of Tmolus. Niobe turned to stone here Il. 24.615.
(κέρδιστος ἀνδρῶν). Patr. Αἰολίδης. King of Ephyre-2. Father of Glaucus-1 Il. 7.153, 154: tormented in the Shades Od. 11.593.
Σκαιαί alone Il. 3.263.

div1.head: Σκαμάνδριος-1
div1.p: T. (αἵμων θήρης). Son of Strophius. A great hunter. S. Menelaus Il. 5.49.

div1.head: Σκαμάνδριος-2.
div1.p: Hector's name for Astyanax Il. 7.402.

div1.head: Σκαμάνδριος-3.
div1.p: Adj. fr. next Il. 2.465, 467.
See Ξάνθος-1.
The port of Cythera Il. 10.268.
A Locrian town Il. 2.532.

(πετραίη). Daughter of Crataeis. A destructive female monster inhabiting a high rock opposite to the rock of Charybdis. The rock described Od. 12.73; S. described Od. 12.85; Od. 12.108, 125, 223, 231; Odysseus passes between S. and Charybdis losing six comrades to S. Od. 12.235, 245, 261, Od. 23.328; Od. 12.310; O. comes again to the rock Od. 12.430, escapes Σ. 445.

div1.head: Σκῦρος-1.
div1.p: The Aegean island. Neoptolemus brought up there Il. 19.326: Odysseus took him thence to Troy Od. 11.509.
Σκυρόθεν [-θεν], from S. Il. 19.332.

div1.head: Σκῦρος-2
div1.p: (αἰπεῖα). A place (prob. not the same as prec.) taken by Achilles Il. 9.668.
A Boeotian town Il. 2.497.
The mouse-god, identified by the Greeks with Apollo. Called ἀργυρότοξος 37, 451. Protector of Chryse, Cilla and Tenedos Il. 1.39.

(κυδάλιμοι). App. a people inhabiting part of Lycia or a neighbouring country. Bellerophon's fight with them Il. 7.184; Isandrus killed fighting with them Il. 7.204: Poseidon descries Odysseus from their mountains Od. 5.283.
(ἱρόν). The s.e. point of Attica Od. 3.278.
(εὐρεῖα, καλλιγύναιξ). The chief city of Lacedaemon Il. 2.582, Il. 4.52: Od. 1.93, Od. 2.214, 359, Od. 11.460, Od. 13.412.
Σπάρτηνδε [-δε], to S. Od. 1.285.
Σπάρτηθεν [-θεν], from S. Od. 2.327, Od. 4.10.
See also Λακεδαίμων (2).
A Nereid Il. 18.40.
(ἀκάμας, διιπετὴς ποταμός). A river flowing through Hellas into the Malian Gulf. Father by Polydore of Menesthius-2 Il. 16.174, 176; the lock of Achilles dedicated to the river Il. 23.142, 144.
(μεγαλήτωρ χαλκεόφωνος). A Greek of very powerful voice Il. 5.785.
A town of Arcadia Il. 2.606.
Son of Nestor Od. 3.413, 439.
Father of Scamandrius-1 Il. 5.49.
A town of Arcadia Il. 2.608.

(ἀάατον Στυγὸς ὕδωρ, κατειβόμενον Στυγὸς ὕδωρ, ὅρκος δεινός, Στυγὸς αἰπὰ ῥέεθρα). The terrestrial Styx was a river and cataract in Arcadia (but the Titaressus is called (Il. 2.755) a branch of the Styx). The name transferred to the chief river of the underworld Il. 8.369: Od. 10.514.
The Styx invoked in oaths (with app. confusion between the upper and under rivers) Il. 2.755, Il. 14.271, Il. 15.37: Od. 5.185.
τά. A town of Euboea Il. 2.539.
An island to the n. of Rhodes.
Σύμηθεν [-θεν], from S. Il. 2.671.
A mythical island, the home of Eumaeus, app. represented as to the n. of Ortygia. Described Od. 15.403.
Patr. Βουκολίδης. Father of Iasus-1 Il. 15.338.

div1.head: Σχεδίος-1.
div1.p: Son of Iphitus-1. With his brother Epistrophus-1 leader of the men of Phocis Il. 2.517; s. Hector Il. 17.306.

div1.head: Σχεδίος-2.
div1.p: Son of Perimedes-1. Also described as a leader of the men of Phocis. S. Hector Il. 15.515.
(ἐρατεινή, ἐρίβωλος). The new home of the Phaeacians to which (Od. 7.8) they were brought by Nausithous Od. 5.34, Od. 6.79, Od. 13.160.
A Boeotian town Il. 2.497.
T (δαΐφρων, εὐηφενής, ἱππόδαμος, ἰσόθεος φώς). Patr. Ἱππασίδης-1. Son of Hippasus. Wounds and with his brother Charops is killed by Odysseus Il. 11.427, 428, 440, 450, 456.
By the Gygaean Lake father of Mestheles and Antiphus-2 Il. 2.865.
Patr. of Mecisteus-1 Il. 2.566, Il. 23.678.

(θεῷ ἐναλίγκιος αὐδήν, θεῖος, ὀτρηρός, πεπνυμένος). A herald of Agamemnon. Sent with Eurybates-1 to bring away Briseis Il. 1.320; sent to bring the Greek oath-sacrifice Il. 3.118; sent for Machaon to attend to Menelau Il. 4.192, 193; with Idaeus-1 stops the fight between Aias-1 and Hector Il. 6.276; Il. 19.196, 250, 267, Il. 23.897.
Son of Zeus and father of Pelops. Tormented in the Shades Od. 11.582.
(ἐριβῶλαξ). App. a town of the Maeonians Μῄονες( 44.
(βαθύς, ἠερόεις). The gulf in which the Titans were confined. Described Il. 8.13, 481.
A Locrian town Il. 2.533.
(ληΐστορες, φιλήρετμοι). The inhabitants of next, a piratical and slave-dealing race. Their king Mentes-2 Od. 1.105, 181, 419; Od. 14.452, Od. 15.427, Od. 16.426.
The largest of a group of islands lying between the island Leucas and Acarnania Od. 1.417.
A town of Arcadia Il. 2.607.

(ἄναξ, μάντις ἀλαός). The blind seer of Thebes-1. He only in the Shades had his mental powers unimpaired (Od. 10.493). Odysseus
sent to the Shades by Circe to consult him Od. 10.490, 524, 537, 565, Od. 11.32, 50, 89, 165, 479, Od. 23.323; he appears to O. Od. 11.90; his converse with O. Od. 11.92, 139, 151; O. remembers his advice Od. 12.267, 272; O. relates to Penelope his advice and the troubles which he foretold Od. 23.248.
Patr. of Polyneus Od. 8.114.
Patr. Ἁρμονίδης. Father of Phereclus Il. 5.59.
(ἀγαυός, ἀμύμων). Father of Aias-1 and Teucrus Il. 8.283, Il. 13.177, Il. 17.284, 293: Od. 11.553.
Perhaps in Cyprus Od. 1.184.

An Aegean island in sight of Troy Il. 1.38, 452; sacked by Achilles Il. 11.625; the cave between T. and Imbros where Poseidon shackled his horses Il. 13.33: Nestor puts in there on his return from Troy Od. 3.159.
Father of Prothous Il. 2.756.
Patr. of Phemius Od. 22.330.
Patr. of Axylus Il. 7.13.
G (ἀντίθεος). S. Hector Il. 5.705.

(ἀμύμων, ἄναξ, κοίρανος λαῶν). Son of Telamon. The Grecian bowman, app. full brother of Aias-1 (see κασίγνητος (1) (a) in Lex.) Il. 7.31; shows his archery against the Trojans Il. 8.266, 273, 281, 292; aims at Hector Il. 8.300, 309; H. wounds him Il. 8.322, he is rescued by Aias-1 330; Il. 12.336, 350, 363, 371, 372; wounds Glaucus-2 Il. 12.387, Il. 16.511, and Sarpedon Il. 12.400; Il. 13.91; slays Imbrius-1 Il. 13.170, 182; Il. 13.313, Il. 14.515, Il. 15.302, 437; aims at Hector Il. 15.458, but his string breaks 462, 466, 484; is beaten by Meriones in the archery contest Il. 23.859, 862, 883.
Patr. of Lethus Il. 2.843.
(μήτηρ). Associated with Oceanus in the rearing of Hera Il. 14.201, 302.

(δαΐφρων, θεοειδής, θεοείκελος, ἱερὴ ἲς Τηλεμάχοιο, κυδάλιμος, μεγάθυμος, μεγαλήτωρ, πεπνυμένος, φαίδιμος). Only child of Odysseus and Penelope. Referred to by his father at Troy Il. 2.260, Il. 4.354: in his absent father's house in Ithaca receives Athene who comes in the likeness of Mentes-2 Od. 1.113, she advises him to go to Pylus and Sparta 279; he calls an assembly Od. 2.1; prepares for the journey Od. 2.337, departs accompanied by Athene in the likeness of Mentor-2 413; they reach Pylus Od. 3.1, he addresses Nestor 79, who bids him go to Sparta 323, he departs with Peisistratus 481; they reach Sparta Od. 4.1, next day he tells Menelaus his errand 316, M. detains him hospitably 587; Antinous and companions lie in wait for him at Asteris Od. 4.774, 842; Athene urges him to go home Od. 15.10, he and Peisistratus depart 182, on reaching Pylus P. goes to his home leaving T. at the ship 193; Theoclymenus approaches him Od. 15.223, and is taken on board 279, they sail for Ithaca 284; T. lands near Eumaeus's hut to avoid the suitors and dispatches the ship to the city Od. 15.495; he reaches the hut and finds his disguised father there Od. 16.11, his father reveals himself 187; he leaves him and departs for the city Od. 17.1, is received by the maids and Penelope 31, disposes of Theoclymenus 71, tells his mother how he has fared 108; his sneeze Od. 17.541; P. reproaches him for allowing ill usage of the disguised Odysseus Od. 18.215; he and O. remove the arms Od. 19.4; he arranges the contest for the suitors Od. 21.118; he orders Eumaeus to give the bow to Ο. 369; arms for the fight and takes his stand beside his father Od. 21.431, kills Amphinomus Od. 22.91, brings arms 101, kills Euryades 267, is wounded by and kills Amphimedon 277, kills Leocritus 294, saves Phemius and Medon-3 354, carries out the slaying of the unfaithful maids 461; he leaves the city with his father Od. 23.367, his father's address to him and the fight with the Ithacans Od. 24.506; etc.
Patr. Εὐρυμίδης. A seer among the Cyclopes Od. 9.509.
(αἰπὺ πτολίεθρον). The city of the Laestry gonians Od. 10.82, Od. 23.318.
Patr. fr. Τήλεφος, king of the Mysians-1. Of Eurypylus-3 Od. 11.519.
The ‘steep hill’ of T. may poss. have been not far from Lampsacus, the modern Lampsaki Il. 2.829.
(περιμήκετος). A mountain range w. of Sparta Od. 7.103.
(ἀγαυός). Son of Laomedon. Husband of Eos and father of Memnon Il. 11.1, Od. 3.237: Od. 5.1.
(τειχιόεσσα). A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.559.
(Τιτάνοιο λευκὰ κάρηνα). A town of Thessaly. Its men led by Eurypylus-2 Il. 2.735.
(in the MSS. Τιταρήσιος) ἱμερτός, καλλίρροον ὕδωῤ. Now the Europus, flowing into the Peneius (in Il. 2.755 called a tributary of the Styx). The waters of the two rivers do not mingle Il. 2.751.
(ὑποταρτάριοι). The sons of Uranus and Ge, confined by Zeus in Tartarus. Here's oath by them Il. 14.279.
Called Οὐρανίωνες 898; also ἔνερθε θεοί 274, ἐνέρτεροι θεοί 225.
(Γαιήϊος υἱός, ἐρικυδής). Son of Ge. Rhadamanthys conveyed by the Phaeacians to visit him, app. in Euboea Od. 6.324; laid violent hands on Leto and was tormented by vultures in the Shades Od. 11.576.

div1.head: Τληπόλεμος-1
div1.p: (δουρικλυτός, ἠΰς τε μέγας τε). Patr. Ἡρακλεΐδης. Son of Heracles and Astyocheia. Leader of the Rhodians Il. 2.653, 657, 661; fights with Sarpedon Il. 5.628, 632, 648, and is slain 656, 660, 668.

div1.head: Τληπόλεμος-2
div1.p: T. Patr. Δαμαστορίδης-1. S. Patroclus Il. 16.416.
(νιφόεις). A mountain range of Lydia s. of Sardis Il. 2.866, Od. 3.385.
A town of Argos-2 in Hellas, near the mouth of the Spercheius Il. 2.682.
G (αἰχμητής). An Aetolian. S. Hector Il. 5.706.
Τρίκη (ἱππόβοτος). A town of Thessaly. Its men led by Podaleirius and Machaon Il. 2.729, Il. 4.202.
See Lexicon.
A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.561.
(διοτρεφής). Patr. Κεάδης. Father of Euphemus Il. 2.847.

div2.p: The city of Troy (otherwise called Ἴλιος) (εὔπυργος, εὐρεῖα, εὐρυάγυια, εὐτείχεος, ὑψίπυλος, Τροίης ἱερὰ κρήδεμνα?̔ἱερὸν πτολίεθρον̓?̔λιπαρὰ κρήδεμνἀ 129, Il. 2.141, Il. 6.71, Il. 8.241, Il. 9.28, 46, Il. 13.433, Il. 16.100, 698, Il. 17.155, Od. 3.316, Il. 21.375, 544, Il. 22.478, Il. 24.256, 494, 774: Od. 1.2, Od. 4.146, Od. 5.39, Od. 11.510, Od. 13.137, 248, 388, Od. 14.469.
Τροίηνδε [-δε], to T. Il. 6.390, Il. 22.116, Il. 24.764.
With ἀπό 492: Od. 9.38.

div1.p: (ἀλαυοί, ἀγέρωχοι, ἀγήνορες, αἰχμηταί, ἀσπισταί, ἱππόδαμοι, μεγάθυμοι, μεγαλήτορες, πύκα θωρηκαί, ὑπερηνορέοντες, ὑπέρθυμοι, ὑπερφίαλοι, φιλοπτόλεμοι, χαλκοχίτωνες).

div2.p: App. a separate clan of Trojans (the men of Zeleia) Il. 2.826.
So Τρώων υἷες 38.
The Trojans proper distinguished

div3.p: From the Dardanians and allies Il. 3.456, Il. 6.348, 368, Il. 8.497.
From the Lycians and Dardanians Il. 8.173, Il. 11.286, Il. 13.150, Il. 15.425, 486, Il. 17.184.

div1.p: Τρῳάς. Fem. adj.

div2.p: Absol. in pl., (the) Trojan women (βαθύκολποι, ἑλκεσίπεπλοι) Il. 7.442, Il. 6.297, Il. 18.122, Il. 22.105, 514, Il. 24.215, 704.
Trojan Il. 10.11, Il. 23.464.
In a sense corresponding to Τρῶες (2) Il. 16.369, Il. 17.724, Il. 21.296.

div1.p: (ἱππιοχάρμης). A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.257.

div1.head: Τρώϊος-1
div1.p: Τρῳός-1.

div2.p: Trojan, like Τρωϊκός (2) Il. 5.461, Il. 13.262, Il. 16.393.
Absol. in fem. pl., (the) Trojan women (ἐϋπλόκαμοι) Il. 3.384, 411, 420, Il. 7.380, 385, Il. 18.339, Il. 22.57, 430, 434, 476: Od. 4.259.

div1.head: Τρώς-1.
div1.p: Son of Erichthonius and father of Ilus-1, Assaracus and Ganymedes. His horses Il. 5.265; Od. 3.230, 231.

div1.head: Τρώς-2
div1.p: T. Patr. Ἀλαστορίδης. S. Achilles Od. 3.463.

(ἀγαυός, Αἰτώλιος, δαΐφρων, δῖος, ἱππηλάτα, ἱππόδαμος, ἱππότα, μεγάθυμος, σακέσπαλος). Patr. Οἰνεΐδης. Son of Oeneus and Althaea, married to a daughter (Deipyle) of Adrestus-1 and father of Diomedes. His mission to the Cadmeians Il. 4.384, Il. 10.285; described Il. 5.800; perished at Thebes-1 Il. 7.222, buried there Il. 14.114; etc.: Od. 3.167.
Husband of Leda and by her father of Castor-1 and Polydeuces Od. 11.298, 299.
And of Clytaemnestra Od. 24.199.
Also nominal father of Helen Il. 3.236 (daughter of Zeus).

(βασίλεια γυναικῶν, εὐπατέρεια). Daughter of Salmoneus and wife of Cretheus. Brought into comparison with Penelope Od. 2.120; by Poseidon mother of Pelies and Neleus Od. 11.235, 254; by Cretheus mother of Aeson, Pheres and Amythaon Od. 11.235, 258.
A monster put in bonds by Zeus in the country of the Arimoi Il. 2.782, 783.
Made a shield for Aias-1 Il. 6.220.
The Hyades, a group of stars near the Pleiades Il. 18.486.
A town of Phocis Il. 2.521.
(πίων). App. a district of Maeonia (Μῃονίη) Od. 3.385.
(υ). Patr. of Castor-2 Od. 14.204.
(ῦ). A Boeotian town Il. 2.500, Il. 5.708, Il. 6.221.
(ἰχθυόεις). A river of Maeonia (Μῃονίη) flowing into the Hermus Od. 3.392.
Patr. of Itymoneus Il. 11.673.
T. S. Odysseus Il. 11.335.
T (ποιμὴν λαῶν). S. Diomedes Il. 5.144.

div1.head: Ὑπέρεια-1.
div1.p: A fountain believed to have been in the town of Pherae. The people living about it led by Eurypylus-2 Il. 2.734; Il. 7.457.

div1.head: Ὑπέρεια-2
div1.p: (εὐρύχορος). The old home of the Phaeacians, near the Cyclopes Od. 7.4.
(ἱππόδαμος, ποιμὴν λαῶν). Son of Panthous. S. Menelaus Il. 14.516, Il. 17.24.

A town in Agamemnon's realm
Il. 2.573.
̔γπερησίηνδε [-δε], to H. In reference to the flight of Polypheides hither Od. 15.254.
Ὑπερίων. See Lexicon.
See Lexicon.
(ἐϋκτίμενον πτολίεθρον). A Boeotian town Il. 2.505.
Lying under Mount Neium (Neritum). Of Ithaca Od. 3.81.
Lying under Mount Placus. Of Thebe-2 Il. 7.397.
A Boeotian town on the Euripus Il. 2.496.
A town of Elis Il. 2.616.
Patr. fr. next. Of Asius-2 Il. 2.837, 838, Il. 12.96, 110, 163.
Father of Asius-2 Il. 13.759, 771.
Patr. Γυρτιάδης. A leader of the Mysians-1. S. Aias-1 Il. 14.511.

div1.head: Ὑψήνωρ-1
div1.p: T. (δῖος). Son of Dolopion. S. Eurypylus-2 Il. 5.76.

div1.head: Ὑψήνωρ-2
div1.p: G. (ποιμὴν λαῶν). Patr. Ἱππασίδης-2. Mortally wounded by Deiphobus Il. 13.411.
Daughter of Thoas-2. By Ieson mother of Euneus Il. 6.469.
(νύμφη ἐϋπλόκαμος). Daughter of Eelius and Neaera. With Lampetie in charge of the oxen of the Sun Od. 12.132.
One of the horses of the Dawn Od. 23.246.
King of the Sidonians. The mixing-bowl given by him to Menelaus Od. 4.617, Od. 15.117.
Daughter of Minos and wife of Theseus. Having calumniated her innocent stepson Hippolytus and being detected made away with herself. Named Od. 11.321.

(ἀγαυοί, ἀγχίθεοι, ἀντίθεοι, δολιχήρετμοι, μεγάθυμοι, ναυσικλυτοί, φιλήρετμοι). A people, their home called Scheria, represented (Od. 7.204) as being the outermost of civilized communities. Their transference from Hypereia-2 to Scheria Od. 7.3; their city described Od. 7.262; their ships and seamanship Od. 7.270, Od. 6.34, 108, Od. 8.557, Od. 13.76; their intolerance of strangers Od. 6.32; the skill of their women Od. 6.109; their skill in dancing and ball-play Od. 8.260, 370; conductors home of strangers and Poseidon's threat thereanent Od. 8.564, Od. 13.125, he turns to stone the ship that had borne Odysseus 159; etc.

div1.head: Φαῖνοψ-1.
div1.p: Father of Xanthus-3 and Thoon-1 Il. 5.152.

div1.head: Φαῖνοψ-2.
div1.p: Father of Phorcys-1 Il. 17.312.

div1.head: Φαῖνοψ-3.
div1.p: Patr. Ἀσιάδης. Son of Asius-2. Favourite guest-frend (ξεῖνος) of Hector Il. 17.583.

div1.head: Φαιστός-1
div1.p: (εὖ ναιετόωσα). A city of Crete Il. 2.648: part of the fleet of Menelaus wrecked near it Od. 3.296.

div1.head: Φαῖστος-2
div1.p: T. Son of Borus-1. S. Idomeneus Il. 5.43.
T. Il. 13.791; s. Antilochus Il. 14.513.
A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.582.
An island off Egypt Od. 4.355.
Patr. of Apisaon-1 Il. 11.578.
No doubt the mod. Katakolo Od. 15.297.
An unknown town, app. of Pylus or Arcadia Il. 6.135.
Son of Thessalus and with his brother Antiphus-1 a leader of the men of Nisurus, Cos, etc. Il. 2.678.
King of the Thesprotians Od. 14.316, Od. 19.287.
A town of Arcadia Il. 2.605.
A town of the realm of Eumelus lying w. of the Boebean Lake Il. 2.711: Od. 4.798.
Son of Tecton. A skilled craftsman; built ships for Paris. S. Meriones Il. 5.59.

div1.head: Φέρης.-1
div1.p: Son of Cretheus and Tyro Od. 11.259. He was father of Admetus.
A Nereid Il. 18.43.
(μάχης εὖ εἰδὼς πάσης). Son of Dares. With his brother Idaeus-2 attacks Diomedes Il. 5.11, s. Diomedes 15.
(θεῖος ἀοιδός). Patr. Τερπιάδης. A bard who sang among the suitors under compulsion Od. 1.154, 337, Od. 16.252, Od. 17.263; spared by Odysseus Od. 22.331; Od. 24.439.

div1.head: Φηραί-1
div1.p: (ζάθεαι) A town of Pylus Il. 9.151, 293.

div1.head: Φηραί-2
div1.p: Φηρή (ἐϋκτιμένη). The home of Diocles Il. 5.543: represented as a half-way stage between Pylus and Sparta Od. 3.488, Od. 15.186.

div1.head: Φῆρες.-2
div1.p: See Κένταυροι.
See Φηραί-2.
Patr. fr. Φέρης. Of Eumelus (grandson) Il. 2.763, Il. 23.376.

Locative Φθίηφι 323 (βωτιάνειρα, ὲριβῶλαξ, ἐρίβωλος, μήτηρ υήλων). The chief part of the realm of Peleus, of undefined position and extent, lying n. of Mt. Othrys and w. of the Pagasaean Gulf Il. 1.155, Il. 2.683, Il. 9.253, 363, 395, 439, 479, 484, Il. 11.766, Il. 16.13, Il. 19.299, 323: Od. 11.496.
Φθίηνδε [-δε], to Ph. Il. 1.169, Il. 19.330.
G (μεγάθυμοι). Adj. fr. prec. Applied absol. to the followers of Medon-1 and of Podarces Il. 13.686, 693, 699.
(ὄρος ἀκριτόφυλλον). A mountain of Caria not identified Il. 2.868.
Patr. of Demouchus Od. 3.457.

(ὄρχαμος ἀνδρῶν, δῖος). Odysseus's herdsman. Greets the disguised O. Od. 20.185; Od. 20.254; ordered to close the gate of the courtyard Od. 21.240, closes it 388; slays Peisandrus-4 Od. 22.268, and Ctesippus 285; Od. 22.359.

(ἀγλαός, ἄναξ, τόξων ἐῢ εἰδώς). Son of Poeas (see Ποιάντιος). Leader of the men of Methone, etc., but left at Lemnos suffering from the bite of a water-snake and his place taken by Medon-1 Il. 2.718, the Greeks destined to bring him to Troy to their aid 725: his safe return from Troy Od. 3.190; his skill in archery Od. 8.219.

App. a patr. Menelau tells
how on an unspecified occasion in Lesbos Odysseus overcame him in wrestling Od. 4.343, Od. 17.134.
or Φλεγύαι (μεγαλήτορες). A people represented as warred on by Ares Il. 13.302.
See Ἀπόλλων.
(ἀγαυοί, ναυσίκλυτοι, πολυπαίπαλοι). The Phoenicians, a maritime and trading people, the inhabitants of prec. Il. 23.744 : Od. 13.272; carried off Eumaeus Od. 15.415, 419, 473.
See also Σιδονίη, Σιδόνιοι.
In sing., Phoenician Od. 14.288.
In fem., Φοίνισσα Od. 15.417.
Phoenicia, a country on the coast of Syria between Mt. Lebanon and the sea Od. 4.83, Od. 14.291.

div1.head: Φοῖνιξ-1
div1.p: (ὰντίθεος, ἄττα γεραιέ, γέρων ίππηλάτα, Διῒ φίλος, διοτρεφής, παλαιγενής) Son of Amyntor and an ancient retainer of Peleus. Chosen to lead the embassy to Achilles Il. 9.168, his speech to Α. 432, tells how he fled from his father to Phthia, how Peleus received him well and how he brought up Achilles 478, he remains with Α. 658; a leader under A. Il. 16.196; in his form Athene exhorts Menelaus Il. 17.555; in the chariotrace set to note the running Il. 23.359, etc.

div1.head: Φοῖνιξ-2
div1.p: (τηλεκλειτός). Father of Europa, the mother by Zeus of Minos and Rhadamanthys Il. 14.321.
See under Φοίνικες.

div1.head: Φόρβας-1.
div1.p: App. King of Lesbos. Father of Diomede Il. 9.665.

div1.head: Φόρβας-2
div1.p: (πολύμηλος). Father of Ilioneus. His riches Il. 14.490.

div1.head: Φόρκυς-1
div1.p: (δαΐφρων). Son of Phaenops-2. A leader of the Phrygians Il. 2.862, Il. 17.218; s. Aias-1 Il. 17.312, 318.

div1.head: Φόρκυς-2
div1.p: (ἅλιος γέρων, ἁλὸς ἀτρυγέτοιο μέδων). Father of Thoosa Od. 1.72; his haven in Ithaca Od. 13.96, 345.
Patr. of Agelaus-1 Il. 21.257.
Father of Noemon-3 Od. 2.386, Od. 4.630, 648.

div1.head: Φρόντις-1
div1.p: (δῖα) Wife of Panthous Il. 17.40.

div1.head: Φρόντις-2
div1.p: Patr. Ὀνητορίδης. Menelaus's pilot Od. 3.282.
T (αἰολόπωλοι, ἱππόμαχοι). The Phrygians, a people on the Sangarius and about Lake Ascania Il. 2.862, Il. 3.185, Il. 10.431.
(ἀμπελόεσσα). The land of the Phrygians Il. 3.184, 401, Il. 16.719, Il. 18.291, Il. 24.545.

A town in the realm of Protesilaus lying about ten miles w. of the Pagasacan Gulf Il. 2.695, 700; the home of Medon-1 Il. 13.696, Il. 15.335: the home of Phylacus-2 and Iphiclus-1 Od. 11.290, Od. 15.236.
Patr. fr. Φύλακος-2. Of Iphiclus-1 Il. 2.705, Il. 13.698.

div1.head: Φύλακος-1
div1.p: T. S. Leitus Il. 7.35.

div1.head: Φύλακος-2.
div1.p: Husband of Clymene-3 and father of Iphiclus-1 Od. 15.231.
Father of Polymele; brought up Eudorus Il. 16.181, 191.
(Διῒ φίλος, ἱππότα). Father of Meges Il. 2.628, Il. 10.110, 175, Il. 15.530, Il. 23.637.
(βοῶπις). By Areithous-1 mother of Menesthius-1 Il. 6.10.
A handmaid of Helen at Sparta Od. 4.125, 133.
G. The men of Phocis, in which Delphi (Πυθώ) was situated Il. 2.517, 525, Il. 14.516, Il. 17.307.

div1.head: Χαλκίς-1
div1.p: A town of Euboea Il. 2.537.

div1.head: Χαλκίς-2
div1.p: (ἀγχίαλος). A town of Aetolia Il. 2.648.

div1.head: Χαλκίς-3
div1.p: (καλλιρέεθρος). See Κρουνοί.
Patr. of Elephenor Il. 2.541, Il. 4.464.
Father of Bathyclees Il. 16.595.
(δῖα θεάων, λιπαροκρήδεμνος). In Il. the wife of Hephaestus Il. 18.382.
See χάρις (5) in Lexicon.
(ἄναξ). Father of Nireus by Aglaia Il. 2.672.
T Patr. Ἱππασίδης-1. Son of Hippasus. With his brother Socus s. Odysseus Il. 11.426.

(δεινή, δῖα, ὀλοή) A destructive female being inhabiting a whirlpool under a rock opposite to the rock of Scylla. The rock and whirlpool described Od. 12.101; Od. 12.113; Odysseus passes between Scylla and Ch. Od. 12.235, 260, Od. 23.327; Od. comes again to Ch. and again escapes Od. 12.428, 430, 436, 441.
(δικαιότατος Κενταύρων). A Centaur. Gave medicaments to Asclepius Il. 4.219; taught Achilles their use Il. 11.832; furnished Peleus with a spear from Pelion Il. 16.143, Il. 19.390.
T. S. Odysseus Il. 11.423.
(ἀμαιμακέτη). A monster of divine origin described Il. 7.180. Reared by Amisodarus Il. 16.328; killed by Bellerophon Il. 7.179
(παιπαλόεσσα). The Aegean island Od. 3.170, 172.
(περικαλλής). Daughter of Amphion-3 and wife of Neleus Od. 11.281.

div1.head: Χρομίος-1.
div1.p: Son of Neleus Il. 4.295: Od. 11.286.

div1.head: Χρομίος-2.
div1.p: Son of Priam (his mother not named). With his brother Echemmon s. Diomedes Il. 5.160.

div1.head: Χρομίος-3
div1.p: T. S. Odysseus Il. 5.677.

div1.head: Χρομίος-4
div1.p: T. S. Teucrus Od. 8.275.
A leader of the Mysians-1 Il. 2.858.
A town of the southern Troad, prob. near the mouth of the Satnioeis Il. 1.37, 100, 390, 431, 451.
(καλλιπάρῃος). Fem. patr. fr. next. Captured by Achilles at Thebe-2 and given to Agamemnon Il. 1.369; Il. 1.111, 143, 182; sent back to her father Il. 1.310, 439.

The priest of Apollo at Chryse, father of prec. Comes in vain to the ships to ransom his daughter Il. 1.11, 370; prays to Apollo Il. 1.37; Calchas declares that to stay the plague
his daughter must be restored Il. 1.93; she is restored Il. 1.442, 450.
Daughter of Agamemnon Il. 9.145, 287.
An island n.w. of Chios Od. 3.171.
An epithet or the name of Calypso's island of unknown meaning Od. 1.85, Od. 7.172, Od. 6.244, 254, Od. 12.448, Od. 23.333.
A Boeotian town Il. 2.501.
(ἀκαλαρρείτης, ἀψόρροος, βαθυδίνης, βαθυρρείτης, βαθύρροος, Ὠ. ποταμός).

div2.p: Personified. A god Od. 3.7.
Associated with Tethys in the rearing of Hera Il. 14.201, 302
Father (Il. 18.399) of Eurynome-1 and (Od. 10.139) of Perse.
θεῶν γένεσις Od. 14.201, 302. γ. πάντεσσιν Il. 14.246.
Parent of all waters Il. 21.195 (but see Ξάνθος-1).
δῶμʼ Ὠκεανοῖο Il. 14.311.

div1.p: A Phaeacian Od. 8.111.
A rock on the confines of Bouprasion Il. 2.617, Il. 11.757.
A town of Aetolia Il. 2.639.
See ̔́ωρη (1) in Lexicon.
A Nereid Il. 18.48.
(Ὠαρίων) (κλυτός, πελώριος). Carried off by Eos Od. 5.121, slain by Artemis 123; his beauty Od. 11.310; carries on his hunting in the Shades Od. 11.572.
The constellation Il. 14.486, 488: Od. 5.274.
κύων Ὠρίωνος, Sirius X 29.
G. S. Hector Il. 11.303.

div1.head: Ὦτος-1
div1.p: (ἀντίθεος). Son of Poscidon (nominally of Aloeus) and Iphimedeia. With his brother Ephialtes imprisoned Ares in a jar Il. 5.385: the size and beauty of the brothers Od. 11.308, they threaten to pile Ossa on Olympus and Pelion on Ossa 315.

div1.head: Ὦτος-2
div1.p: G. S. Poulydamas Il. 15.518.
Patr. Πεισηνορίδης. Father of Eurycleia Od. 1.429, Od. 2.347, Od. 20.148.
